summary: A stage director and his actor wife struggle through a grueling divorce that pushes them to their limits.

reviews.content: A masterpiece with a strong story, good cast and perfect ending.

Excelente película, una joya cinematográfica y de lo mejor del catalogo de Netflix. Es una película muy buena, emotiva y entretenida. Cuenta una historia bastante triste sobre un matrimonio que decide divorciarse y como llevan a cabo el juicio por esto. Esta cargada de escenas muy emotivas, logrando conmoverme en bastantes momentos. También cuenta con actuaciones brillantes de Adam Driver, Scarlett Johansson y Laura Dern; actuaciones dignas de un Oscar. Es una cinta que logra atraparte desde el primer momento, y si bien es lenta y puede resultarte aburrida, en mi caso me entretuvo mucho y su ritmo lento no me aburrió para nada, se toma todo el tiempo posible para que empatices con los personajes y puedas juzgarlos y fijarte que hicieron mal y bien. También hay que destacar el soundtrack, que en parte es gracias a este que es muy emotiva la película. La considero una cinta ideal para ver con tu pareja y opinar sobre las acciones de cada uno o que te puede servir, como leí, para charlar sobre los errores que hay en esa pareja y solucionarlos. En conclusión, me parece una cinta brillante, llena de momentos emotivos y memorables, con actuaciones excelentes y con una trama bastante fuerte y cargada de emoción. Muy recomendada.

"Marriage Story" is a touching and powerful film that explores the complexities of relationships and the difficulties of divorce. Outstanding performances by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson, along with masterful direction by Noah Baumbach, make this a must-see for anyone who values powerful and emotionally resonant cinema.
Professional actor and actress who go through the life obstacles with passion and love.
This film is really emotional.

I have finally watched this movie, and I have to say, it's incredible. It tells a heartwarming story of a couple that is now tearing apart, but you can feel what they are feeling about each due to the magnificent acting from Scarlett and Adam. It's so amazing, beautiful, sad and funny that you can't not love this movie. Although it's longer than it should be, I don't regret watching it.
Its a great and heartfelt movie.... And ask yourselves why?... I love it

It's elongated more than it could handle, and in the wrong places. The second half of the movie could've handled extended scenes, but not the first part at all, especially when the psychological factor was forced into it in a shallow way, before it was completely discarded in the second half in favor of pure drama, and in my opinion it should've all been about the drama. Ray Liotta's performance, though relatively brief, redeemed Marriage Story and its unnecessary extension of useless scenes.

Absolutely astounding movie, 5 stars. Some of the best acting I've ever seen, great storyline, great writing, this movie is generally awesome. In fact, if anyone says this movie is bad I immediately don't trust them. That's how good this is.

Excellent movie depicting the bitter sweet in marriage; very realistic how a compatible marriage with an abundance of love including children can turn south in a heart beat; highly recommended, funny too, very funny.
This movie is a somatic nightmare for anyone sensitive to arguing and my heart goes out to the people that think this is relatable, love and compassion to all.

An outstanding cast, let by Driver and Dern. Not like other films (e.g., Mrs. Doubtfire) that do the "nowadays it's worse for the dads" routine; instead, it paints a rich, layered, complicated picture of American family life in which institutions clash and people get caught in the crossfire.
This movie is an incredible movie and I think everyone should watch it
I want to put a band-aid on my heart
incredible. the directing blew me off and the acting from adam driver is incredible.
Excellent performances from the two leads especially. Emotional.
The movie tells a simple story that's both poignant and satisfying. Evenhanded in the treatment of the two main characters.

Coinvolgente, intenso. Driver e Johansson superlativi. Regia impeccabile, sapiente utilizzo delle inquadrature. La discesa nella spirale dolorosa di una separazione tra due persone viene raccontata con delicatezza, planando sulle vite dei personaggi per pennellarne le fragilità e i sentimenti che emergono sempre più chiaramente col passare dei minuti. Rabbia, sconforto, difficoltà a lasciarsi andare, piccoli gesti significativi, sguardi che si incrociano annodandosi con l'odio o con la tenerezza, disagio, inadeguatezza, solitudine, paura, voglia e difficoltà nel ripartire e nel rinunciare. Le colpe e le assoluzioni dei protagonisti vengono esposte con empatia, lasciando allo spettatore non il giudizio ma il compito di sfiorarle con uno sguardo umano per intercettare le miriadi di sfaccettature di una relazione, scoprendone o riconoscendone la moltitudine di riflessi e cercando di comprenderla profondamente. Anche quando questa si avvia alla conclusione, e forse soprattutto allora, se ne può cogliere pienamente la vastità delle variegate emozioni che la compongono.
One of those movies that make you want not to do something. Great performances by the leads, and the movie proves that a simple drama can still work in cinema.
Bummer of a movie but well acted
Anything with Scarlett Johannasen is worth watching.  But the melodrama became tiresome after a while.
Scarlett Johansson ruins this movie. She's awful but it's NB's fault.
The best acting performance from Adam Driver! With the best movie song ever adapted: Being Alive!

I cried.  That's all I have to say.  Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson give the best performances of their careers that I've seen.  And not only are they each great in their own scenes, but when they are on screen together and they have their conversations whether it be joyous or downright awful.  The "Everyday I wake up and I hope you're dead!" scene was without a doubt my favorite and the most well acted in the entire film.  While it's not for everyone because it is over 2 hours and it's very performance driven, Marriage Story is absolutely phenomenal.
powerfull yet beautifull movie full of emotions and great top notch acting

excelente película. la quería ver hace mucho tiempo y finalmente le dediqué el tiempo que se merecía, hasta rebobinando para repetir las escenas que más me atraparon. merecido el Oscar a Laura Dern porque su actuación fue fabulosa y merecidas las nominaciones a Scarlett Johansson, Adam Driver y a la película en general. hermosos planos, hermosa construcción de personajes, hermosa también la montaña rusa de emociones por la que me hicieron viajar; me reí, me enojé, lloré y esto es exactamente lo que necesito para que una película realmente me guste porque me hizo sentir algo y me hizo amar el cine una vez más. creo que si esta película tiene una moraleja, es quizás, que más allá de que una pareja se ame y quiera terminar en buenos términos, los duelos y los cambios son inminentes y no vienen acompañados de paz y armonía; siempre un cambio de este tipo trae consigo una avalancha de emociones y de momentos feos por los que hay que pasar para terminar de romper lo que ya está quebrado y que, de ahí, pueda surgir algo mejor. espero que más gente pueda disfrutar de esta película que hoy para mí, fue la primera de muchas vistas!
An absolute amazing movie. This is a must-watch,   and will definitely tear at the heart.
An excellent slow burn featuring superb performances - Laura Durn delivers one of the most fantastic monologues of this generation.

I checked this out a couple of years ago but quickly turned it off since it didn't hold my interest. Since then I got a lot more into movies and decided to revisit it recently and I was pleasantly surprised! Scarlett Johansson performed very well and so did Adam Driver (who I am actually not normally a fan of since I find him to lack charisma, but not in this movie). You really feel for his character and buy into him really caring about his son. The casting in general was noteworthy and I found it interesting how it wrapped itself up, and it was very emotional. And to top it off, I'm much more scared now of getting a divorce one day too, hopefully not!
So boring. What a snooze fest. Had no interest in this duo.

Fabulously portrayed and acted.  Really compelling.  What I hate about it is that it doesn't offer any proactive effort on the part of either partner to save this family.  That is almost always a possibility, and by far better than just going on to the next relationship as dysfunctional people.  I mean, we're all dysfunctional to some degree; the challenge is to stick with it, to seek answers, to learn to be unselfish, to learn to accept and validate...and to become always more functional.  It is possible, I know by experience.  Why not go for "alive" at all costs?  Why not seek healing?  Why not act like adults and let the child have as functional a childhood as possible?  There is a lot of good stuff out there - the Gottman Institute for one - it would be completely plausible for two intelligent, warm, real people to seek reconciliation and to always be glad they did.  Instead we have to nod to the prevailing weltzschmerz and go on singing our sad little tune.

2 years-- 2 years ago Passionately acted and funnier than one might initially assume, the film thrives during the interplay of struggling characters that allow the performers to shine, particularly Laura Dern as she steals every scene.

pqp o que eu mais amei nesse filme é a imparcialidade, ele não coloca ninguem como certo ou errado, ele so mostra todos os lados, mostrando que o divorcio não é bom pra ninguem, mas no final é necessario

Deep and touching film with wonderful interpretations that make it even more incredible, the film is very sad as you obviously expect, but it is a manageable and watchable sadness that makes you appreciate the film more.
Terrific acting from Driver & Johansson to the veterans playing small roles.
Yeah, this is better than CATS.
The acting, the plot, and the scenes were so real. It was an up-close view into how two amiable people can end up in a messy divorce when they start listening to folks they shouldn't listen to.

This film portrayed divorce pretty well, showing how divorce can bring out the worst in people, although I think a deeper meaning of this film is that both of the main characters are terrible people disguised behind a superficial good person. The acting was very good and illustrated an emotional roller coaster pretty well. The film however dragged and was boring at times, and the plot was pretty decent.

This is a touching and realistic story about the separation of two lovely people. This is not a film for fans of the Avengers. This is a slow-moving drama with a lot of empathy and sensitivity. The protagonists do an outstanding job in their roles. In a minor role, Adam Driver shines. Scarlett Johansson, as usual, is wonderful. Even if you are happily married, you should not miss this. Simply to learn a few more things to add to your relationships in order to avoid being like them.
This movie is really good. This is what i imagine a divorce would look like. I enjoyed the movie and it broke me, its just really sad. Ive found a new fear in live, divorce.
I really didn't "get" the appeal of this movie.

Adam Driver is absolutely mesmerizing with such a brutally sad performance, If he wasn't going up against Joquin Phoenix's Joker then he would have the best actor Oscar in his cabinet. Scarlett Johansen is also brilliant, together they unite to make such a heartbreaking but sad truth of love. It doesn't gloss over the hard-hitting truths of lost love, there's no end where they end up falling into each other's arms. It tells the truth about people losing that romantic connection, though they both 'love' each other and care, it's not in the way it once was, and it's incredibly hard to accept that. The film so realistically depicts this in its acting and writing, it's painfully relatable for most.

This movie is perfect from start to finish, it reflects us and highlights that most of the movies about him get the perfect stuff, the ones I've seen. He hurt the repulsion, the show, the tension of a partner who betrayed you, hurt you the same perfect and much more, the uncontrollable anger of the characters is clearly and Scarlett and Adam who deliver a work with a quality that you rarely see. see. The film shows us the busy and complicated life of an ex-couple that was not working out for a long time. Noah Baumbach delivers a dynamic, generous, sometimes publicized and sad work, and often in a single scene a complex, confused and angry reality of theirs. The film recognizes with sensitivity and empathy how people fail as couples, parents and people, how they go and how they come. The soundtrack is full of sensations and sensations, in the scenes it works excellently, with heartbreak, loss and melancholy, but it doesn't convey the feeling that it will get better, good things and better things to come. The work gives us much more than a film about a duty, it gives us a story and reflection of a rich and well-developed cinematography. The technical part of the film in general is great, from the photography to the costumes.

A masterclass in acting. This was one of the best performances I’ve ever seen from not only one, but two people. I heard about this film so I figured I might as well watch it since I already had a Netflix subscription. I went in with medium expectations because based on the description it didn’t seem like my type of movie. Boy was I wrong. The plot drew me in quickly and I was constantly wondering what was gonna happen next. I didn’t think a film like this could keep me on the edge of my seat but it did
Adam Driver was sensational in this film. Scarlett Jo was too. Brilliant story, sad, funny - all the emotions!

This film is raw and emotional. The story feels real and tangible thanks to the great acting by Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver. The script is well written and the soundtrack is beautiful. I can understand that this movie is not for everyone, but I loved it.

first I have to commend Noah Baumbach for his exceptional direction and script, he works each element present in the context of the film with mastery, making the situations unfold in a way that holds the viewer, but part of this immersion that the film brings is thanks to the actors, especially Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver for their incredible performance, they manage to convince that each conversation each attitude brings a significant weight to the narrative and that this will affect both characters in the future.  Apart from these three strengths of the film, the soundtrack, cinematography and dynamics of the film are very good.

I am not a fan of Scarlett Johansson or Adam Driver, but I found their passionate performances riveting. And let's not forget my Laura Dern, she's simply sublime, a well deserved  2020 Oscar win. Cudos to director Noah Baumbach for brilliantly delivering a story full of heartache and anger, without ever being preachy or taking sides - we never see the reason for the breakup on screen- so neither one is labeled as good or bad.  You just share in the pain of each, awkwardly eavesdropping as they stumble, and still you can't turn away.
Not my type of movie.

Películas como "Marriage Story" me hacen amar los conflictos minimalistas, apoyándose casi completamente de los conflictos internos muy bien marcados de los protagonistas. Haciendo a la película directa, y siempre con un propósito en cada escena; mostrando pequeñas cosas o acciones que de poco a poco llevan al increíble clímax de la película, apoyándose y confiando totalmente en los actores, con planos cerrados y creando un suspenso únicamente con los gestos de los protagonistas, siempre teniendo un buen balance y nunca sintiéndose exagerados. Marcando muy bien tanto los puntos altos como los bajos de los personajes en el trascurso de la historia, con este realismo que debe tener este género. Uno de los contras que le encuentro a la película es que del segundo acto hacia delante, la película nos muestra más el lado humano del personaje de Adam Driver, haciendo que empaticemos más con él; Dejando de lado al personaje de Scarlett Johansson, que aunque nunca la prescribimos como de cierta manera "el antagonista de la historia", si se nota una evolución menor en su personaje, haciendo que empaticemos más con el. Los personajes de apoyo aunque no tienen un peso real en la historia, están bien marcados y teniendo un propósito claro en la película. Para mi la principal virtud de esta película esta en contarnos únicamente la historia del "Matrimonio" de los protagonistas, haciendo a la película personal, no necesitando un extenso cast, ni sets "increíbles" para contar una historia; la historia se engrandece únicamente con estos dos personajes, entendiendo el conflicto de cada uno y viendo de una manera super natural como se vuelve la trama central de la película.  Sientes que conoces a estos personajes, ya sea en como los planos abiertos están realizados o en la decoración de los sets. Una historia pequeña pero una historia que necesitamos ver más en los cines, una historia que sentimos real entre todo el blockbuster que vemos hoy.
Meh, not very exciting

una obra maestra, sumamente conmovedora y sentimental. Marriage story muestra el divorcio de una manera cruda y realista como solo Noah Boumbach lo puede hacer; el excelente desarrollo de los personajes hace que se tenga una apreciación única de estos y, así mismo, las magistrales interpretaciones del reparto permiten sentirnos como los personajes, comprenderlos, sentir su frustración, y, incluso, llegamos a tomar partido en esta batalla en la que no hay reglas; también va mostrando como va afectando la vida de los involucrados y como influyen las demás personas de su circulo familiar, laboral y amistoso, destruyendo cualquier tipo de esperanza. La increíble y extraordinaria dirección y fotografía hacen que te metas de lleno en la historia y sientes como si estuvieras ahí presente. Su memorable banda sonora te adentra en su atmósfera emotiva y la mezcla de todos estos, componen una verdadera orquesta de emociones y un bello retrato familiar. Para terminar, aparte de ser un reflejo de la realidad nos deja claro como es la falta de comunicación lo que extingue una relación y no "la falta de amor". En conclusión una cinta maravillosa, emotiva e irónicamente romántica. 9,2 de 10

Marriage Story is a film that perfectly captures the heartbreak of divorce. It's the perfect melancholy film with phenomenal cinematography, soundtrack, and packed with career best performances by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson. Marriage story is quite simply, phenomenal.
Sad, hard to watch, very well acted.
La actuación de Scarlett y Adam son increíbles, te sumergen de llego en la historia, te identificas con ellos y el duelo que van llevando a través de su separación.
Marriage Story is a masterpiece; phenomenally acted, fantastic screenplay, beautifully shot and edited, and extremely emotional. Amazing.

Painfully relatable emotional ride with many highs, lows, & immutable truths (like working with lawyers is unavoidably frustrating). A must-watch for anyone in - or out - of a relationship, especially if you have children. #nitrosMovieChallenge

Noah Baumbach seems to want to present us with the story of how a divorce could be if both parties tried their best to be amicable whilst, at the same time, fighting to be who they want to be as people. The result is a somewhat odd blend of tones, light and humorous at times, and then suddenly dark and bitter. You might think that sounds kinda realistic, but the reality is it feels a bit… off, like there aren't a lot of powerful moments because of Baumbach's conscious effort not to take it too far in either direction. That being said, there are a few moments that hit exactly as they should (there's a fantastic argument scene) and I found that the film worked best when it explored the stronger, raw emotions of the individual characters – love, hate, anger – instead of documenting the process of divorce itself (lawyers, houses, money etc.). As for the performances, they're solid all around, but it's Adam Driver that steals the show.
A must watch, the acting in the is fucking class

Cool indie film from reputable director. I liked the premise and plot of the story. Loved performances of both Johanson and Driver. Kind of a slow watch but very emotional and profound. Not for everybody.

Starts off fine, but not long after that I was not impressed, as both characters are thrown in a bad light, which can ruin a story for me if I dislike the main characters. Though, the movie did a good job of bringing it back and even make you appreciate these imperfect characters. There's something contrived yet real about them and their situation. Could certainly be better, but I ended up being more impressed than I thought I was when it started out bad, so that was a plus for me. A bittersweet tale about a situation that is devastating and far too common. Perhaps it even makes a bit too much light of it, but it did well enough for three stars.
10/10 acting. decent story.

This movie 2+ hours of unremitting, film-school Oscar bait. Johansson and Driver both offer cringingly flat performances, supported by the enticingly hate-able Dern and Liotta. Baumbach should stick to directing films with Greta Gerwig and should lay down his pen, never to write again.
A very nice drama investigating the grey area between love and hatred, resentment and joy revolving around a loving couple who separate their lives.
Watched it because everyone hyped it but not really memorable, more boring.

Funny, Scalding, Stirring all at once.  Built around two tremendous performances with Johannsson and Driver capture life in all of it's emotional detail and complexity in the process making a statement about how our society works.

What a depressing movie. I held strong and did not cry (this time), I really enjoyed this and goes to show, there are definitely no winners with wrongs being done on both sides. Not all partnerships will make the distance and divorce lawyers make this expensive "I will NOT not be rich!". It does make me want to re-watch Kramer vs Kramer.
Noah Baumbach's most overrated film. Yes, some of it is great, but most of it is off... it has nothing on Squid.

This is a beautiful movie, showing the heartbreak in relationships. I like that the movie shows the conflict from both sides like all relationship problems. Great acting from Scarlett Johansson, Adam Driver and Laura Dern.
Here's a movie with acting so well done, you completely forget the fact that it is only actors playing a role.

This is probably one of my favourite films of all time even though i generally dont like romance and this is because of the amazing character development, story and dialogue as well as the fact that the story was directed in a way that it wasn't cliche and avoided all expectations with the end of this romance film not being about them coming back together, but accepting that they are divorced now and that they should cherish their son and everything they have.
A great movie to make you realize how awful the process of divorce can be.

Marriage Story is a reverse love story full of heartbreak, anger, and tender moments. Baumbach captures the messy reality of divorce: court costs, scheming lawyers, and CPS visits perfectly and the acting is incredible! I really love this movie!!
Decent.  I like all the lead actors, so I was predisposed to like it.  Unfortunately, the topic area, the dissolution of a marriage, isn't a very cheery topic.  It was well done.

To call Marriage Story "Kramer versus Kramer 2.0" is an insult. Not for the reason Kramer vs. Kramer is not a masterpiece, but because these two films are more different than similar.

Marriage story doesn't just succeed at tapping into your emotions. Noah Baumbach found a perfect way to show the life, the process, and the pain of two people getting a divorce. Whether it is in the production design where a scene is taking place, an unforgettable line in the screenplay, or the lovely score in the background. It is unique in the way of showing the anger and hate being overpowered by the love and friendship between these two people. This is brought to life by the remarkable performances of Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson.

To also judge this film just by the fight scene Film Twitter turned into a viral meme is a complete disrespect to the film itself. It is the minor scenes where we are impacted most, such as:

- Charlie does not know what to order during the lawyers' meeting 
- Charlie waiting for his child on Halloween, falling asleep on the couch dressed as Frankenstein in the process.
- Nicole rushing to her room after talking to Charlie and breaking down into sobs from pain and anger after a small argument. 
- Laura's Derns iconic 2 minute monologue about the standards and pressure society puts on mothers compared to fathers (where after viewing that scene, I immediately knew she had the Oscar).

These scenes are what make the film more beautiful and heartbreaking. Rather than just seeing five minutes out of the 2 hour and 17 min. runtime, experience all its beauty completely.

Marriage Story is absolutely fantastic. The grip of reality and emotions conveyed was truly impressive. Scarlett and Adam are at their absolute bests, and they steal the show. I think the movie will lose some audience members during viewing because it hits very heavily on the potential negatives that relationships can endure, some members have not experienced the "downs" such as this movie showcases, so the inability to relate makes this movie seem "depressive" and "slow". It is unfortunate because this movie is anything but that, it is a fantastic movie.
I cannot believe the ratings this is getting - it was boring and shrill

A masterpiece of a drama. Emotional and impactful. It portrays divorce as a very difficult time in a familys life. How it can tear a family apart. The acting is magnificent. I felt sorry for both Scarlett and Adam's characters. The argument scene was very intense and I loved it. An absolute must watch 10/10
Phenomenal if you like dramas. It's real life and expressed correctly. No romantic BS here . Just real. Amazing ! I appreciate this film from personal perspective! So we'll done.
80/100 i think that 80 is a really good score, really good movie holy shit

If you want to know what it means to act, you should see this film. Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver under Noah Baumbach direction built an amazing story about two souls. Johanssson and Driver do a superb work, but indeed all the cast is almost perfect. Roles of Laura Dern and Alan Alda are outstanding.
This film was painful to watch, but that was the whole point. Great!

A masterpiece of a film with high emotional stakes and connections to represent a slowly breaking marriage yet a bond that stays forever between two characters portrayed by spending cast Adam Driver and Scarlett Johannson compels you to a realistic and sorrowful story making you cry and smile throughout the entire runtime. There are scenes that leave you breathless and broken with its beautiful execution.
This movie stressed me out so bad. This is far from "entertainment."
This movie is awesome. The whole cast is doing an amazing job.

Do you want to be in a relationship with someone for the rest of your life?
First, watch this movie. Then make your final decision.
One of the best films Netflix has ever made.

Ok, it's interesting to see from both sides what led them to divorce.  But why all the shouting, geez!  Scarlett is a good actress, even in this.  I really like Adam Driver but feel he was miscast.  But the worst part was the secondary characters who were almost all over-acted, some almost cartoonish.  The mother figure was ridiculous.  The little kid was fine.  Laura Dern looked great, but was so unreal (or maybe that's how they are in Hollywood?!).  Could've done with better direction.
una drama excelente en el que se pueden sentir los sentimientos de cada escenas gracias a las grandes actuaciones y una gran historia

This film is one of the only times that the run time has hurt its rating. 'Marriage Story' is an great story with a great message spoken by great actors through great directing and screenwriting, but it is too long. While it is interesting to see the story unfold, it also becomes tiring waiting for it to conclude. If you are willing to put in the time and deal with some draggy scenes, watch this film because the majority of the movie is so well made that you will be happy once the credits begin to roll.
Loved the opening scene!!
This film is heart-wrenching. I personally thought it perfectly documented the struggles and emotional rollercoasters behind divorced parents working together to raise their son.

Marriage Story - 9/10. Marriage Story is a story that has been done before. But what makes the film different from other divorce films such as Kramer vs Kramer is the use of comedy and creating a lighter visual experience. Don't get it wrong though, Marriage Story is a sad film overall, but it's the comedy that helps alleviate the pain of seeing people fall out of love. Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver do a splendid job of digging into their characters and providing growth throughout the duration of the film. They display a variety of emotions and play their characters in a very grounded nature. Laura Dern is a definite standout as the cocky but well intentioned divorce lawyer for Scarlett's character in the film. Azhy Robertson, who plays the son of the couple, does a great job of playing the child who just can't seem to grasp the magnitude of what his parents are going through. The real star of the movie however is definitely Noah Baumbach. He delivers a story that could have been dreadful to watch, but provides it in such a way that by the time the movie ends, it leaves in a bittersweet mood. A delightfully sad film, go watch it once it's up on Netflix! One of my favourites during the festival!
Its acting is certainly what made this tolerable.  Watching two people squabble with each other is hardly what I'd call entertaining but its well acted petty squabbling at least.

This film was phenomenal. This is a very accurate depiction of divorce and the stress that it causes. There aren't just mindless arguments in the movie, the characters are worried about the future of their child and what their relationship has come to. The legal process was very accurate as it shows that sometimes taking your relationship issues to lawyers can make your issues worse. Shortly after the court scene, the best scene in the movie follows. The argument scene was one of the best scenes that I have ever seen. The emotions, the power, the way it was shot. The scene was just raw. It was painful to see these characters' lives fall apart after we saw everything they were going through and also knowing what their child was going through. The performances by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson were one of the best acting performances I have seen in my life. 10/10, fantastic movie!

9.25/10. Performances of heart-breaking sincerity and depth meet a screenplay that explores the pain and cruelty that divorce can cause those who've lost love to inflict on one another. It's searing honesty will resonate with anyone who has been in, been the child of, or has seen a loved one experience the suffering of a failed marriage. Directed with clear vision and emotional nuance, never making villains of either parent - both are flawed, but equally devastated by a tortuous marathon neither would wish on the other. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are award worthy in the roles of failed lovers who have no interest in hurting each other, while the supporting cast are stellar as they manipulate the two into becoming enemies. A painful, affecting experience with the power to simultaneously open wounds and prove that healing those wounds is possible.

Macta llega Macta llega, aquí está el tuyo con una loba. Esta película va para tu mami que tiene divorcios, hijos y demandas por cuota de alimentos, comprale un buen tarro de helado, apaguen la luz y llévale pañuelos para que se recoja las lágrimas de recordar al desgraciado que le arruinó la vida

Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver shine in Noah Baumbach's bittersweet drama as a theater director and an actress, parents of a 8-year-old, who are getting through a complicated divorce. Apart from the leading duo, I also liked the brilliant portrayal of lawyers: Laura Dern as seemingly sincere Scarlett's representative, Alan Alda as somewhat forgetful old-fashioned lawyer and Ray Liotta as a courtroom shark… Based on the clips, I expected a difficult drama, but I also got a couple of comic scenes, such as the one in the courtroom towards the end, which is a nice bonus.

Marriage Story takes its simple premise and impressively shows us all the not-so-simple intricacies lurking below, ones that I think a lot of people can identify with whether they've been married or not. https://letterboxd.com/josephtomastik/film/marriage-story-2019/

Writer-director Noah Baumbach is clearly coming at this from personal experience, but this picture revolves around powerful performances from Johansson and Driver who carry the entire film. Not that it needed carrying, of course. The script and plot are so desperately real that it almost makes your soul ache watching it. There'll be few better films about love, anguish and divorce. Adam Driver's confusion, anger and helplessness create such emotion in his scenes that the film is totally captivating. Award winning and deservedly so.
I wish every couple would watch this movie calm down and just come to an agreement. In the end the only ones who win in those kind of divorces is time and your attorneys.

This film is one of the only times that the run time has hurt its rating. 'Marriage Story' is an great story with a great message spoken by great actors through great directing and screenwriting, but it is too long. While it is interesting to see the story unfold, it also becomes tiring waiting for it to conclude. If you are willing to put in the time and deal with some draggy scenes, watch this film because the majority of the movie is so well made that you will be happy once the credits begin to roll.

If you have ever been through a divorce, or were a children of divorce, I can not imagine this movie will not be painfully realistic to you.   The entire cast, including Adam Driver, Scarlett Johansson, and Alan Alda are terrific and moving.  Laura Dern plays her part as the "Balls to the Wall" attorney with joy.   Ray Liotta steals every scene he is in.  The film deals with the issues of the transformation of a family through the lens of a divorce in the most moving way since Kramer V. Kramer.   Noah Baumbach is a terrific filmmaker and this is his most approachable film to date.   This movie made me angry.   It brought me to tears.   It was one of the best of last year.
It was very emotional. I loved it and I would love watch it again someday. The Actors did a great job. It felt so real. It's worth to watch it

The performances all felt natural enough, but I found the film hard to get into. All that really occurs is centered around divorce, and having divorce thrown at you for two hours at a time is rarely going to add up to a positive experience. All of the dialogue and such felt natural, but comparing it to Meyerowitz (the only other Baumbach film that I had seen), I sort of felt like it was that film but without the comedy. I never really felt moved to tears when it was clear that Baumbach crafted certain moments to have that exact effect. All in all, I can sort of comprehend why this was so well-received, but in the end it was not for me.
Tensão do início ao fim!!! Laura Dern destrói com uma interpretação única e exatamente no tom!
This movie broke my heart! That's all I have to say. If you haven't already go watch it, you won't regret it.

Rarely all the hype lives up to the actual film nowadays and even less often the trailer captures the essence of a picture rather than mis-selling it. It's funny yet heartbreaking, well-made yet light/casual/real. 10/10 performances from all the cast propel this uniquely raw study of divorce.

Seems like it should have been titled Divorce Story, but maybe the last scene suggests a possible reconciliation.  Then again, maybe it was just two adults acting like adults.  The acting is superb, the emotions in the movie and from the movie to the audience are palpable.  Not much comedy, but some good feelings along the way.  More a drama than anything else.

Excellent movie.  I wasn't a fan of Adam Driver UNTIL I saw this.  He is AMAZING.
It's more drama than comedy, and I was enthralled with the characters and the story, when this type of film would usually start to bore when longer than two hours.  This never bored me.  Complex humans played by excellent actors.

A very well executed film I ultimately did not like. Divorce is a difficult concept to portray and even harder to base a film on. The acting is sublime, and there's even a surprisingly good dark humor at play at times. Nevertheless, the film seems more like an attempt to face a challenge to portray something hitherto unexplored, than its own thing with its own message. The film lacks a stronger point to really be something special. As it stands, the film is a depressing affair depicting how even good people can sink very low in this situation. That may hold some value but is definitely not a must-watch.
This movie was very moving. Emotionally. I was a child of divorce and this movie was relatable. Scarlett and Adam give amazing performances.

Absolutely great. Acting, writing, directing, all flawless. 
The fight scene is renowned for a reason. I get chills just remembering such original and talented work of art.
It's so emotionally raw at times that you miss the genuinely hilarious moments. #alanalda

I believe that Marriage Story's writing and acting are its best qualities. I would never have guessed that blockbuster actors Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver would deliver such powerhouse performances like they do here.

Noah Baumbach's incisive and compassionate look at a marriage breaking up and a family staying together. (Written by Netflix)

Marriage Story is one of the best if not the best films that talk about two couples who get separated/divorced. Everything about is real and genuine especially the dialogues. It also has very few comedy in it so the film doesn't seem dull/boring which gave the film a special taste. 

Firstly, in my opinion, this is Scarlett Johansson's best performance so far. She succeeded in giving us that great character of the wife Nicole. She gave us one of the best long take scenes of the film, especially that the film has many of these scenes. But, this one specifically was the best because it was focused on her and just her, it felt so real/genuine with her beautiful acting. Adam Driver also gave us one of the best performances of his career for sure. anytime when he was crying or shouting, it all felt so real. In any scene where the two actors were together, it felt like a boom because both of their performances were better than the other, and the famous scene where the two were having an argument, proves it.

Secondly, Noah Baumbach is such an amazing director and screenwriter. When you watch a Noah Baumbach film, it will be obvious because his scripts are written in a way that would make any scene or dialogue seem so real/genuine. His way of directing too is so unique and amazing especially in this film, the cinematography and the transitions were so smooth and well done. This film's dialogues really reminded me of Frances Ha (2012) that was directed by him and written by him & his partner Greta Grewing who is also an amazing screenwriter, and we saw how amazing she is in Lady Bird (2017) and Little Women (2019) that were both directed by her. Noah Baumbach & Greta Grewing are some of the best directors & screenwriters. 

One thing I didn't like about the film is that I felt like sometimes the story of one side only wasn't being told as much as the other side which seemed unfair and we didn't get to know what this person thinks or what their opinion is as much as we did with the other side. Also, I felt like I needed to know more about their backstory or about other situations that would explain to the audience more about their relationship/love. But, all reasons for the two getting divorced were very reasonable and presented in a way that people nowadays would relate to which made the film unique, related, and so real with all of its dialogues & scenes.

A beautiful film that's filled with great acting performances, directing, cinematography, and a little bit of comedy to cool down the energy of the film.

My rating is 9/10

"TAKES MY BREATH AWAY" LOVE FILMS
by Timothy J. Verret

I'm as drawn to love films as a beautiful and majestic horse is drawn to water. I create so much about and from the notion of love that it sometimes is hard for me to take a decent, deep breath. Here are 10 (actually 11) films about love (or the lack thereof) that "take my breath away" and heal my still-sometimes-very-broken heart (BOTH!):

1. SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE (1998):
This would indeed be my all-time favorite love film because it's got Shakespeare and it's got that message: "Love is the ONLY inspiration." This film is inspired by a great and awe-inspiring love for acting, writing, directing, and how passion engages all of these things in one love film. Even if this film was not an ode to why Shakespeare wrote sonnets in the first place, the scene where Viola is onstage in a staged production of Shakespeare's ROMEO AND JULIET and William is lovingly looking at her from the wings is more than enough of a reason why I adore this love film. Viola loves William, William loves Viola, and the music takes us away to just this one moment of two looks and two smiles all looked and smiled in the name of a beautiful, all-encompassing love. That scene alone "takes my breath way" every time I see it. Even though this film is #10 on my all-time favorite films' list, it is solidly #1 on my all-time favorite love films' list (I guess you could say, "so the last shall be first, and the first shall be last" [Matthew 20:16]). 😉

2. SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE (1973):
Swedish director Ingmar Bergman is not known for gushy and silly love films, but this film IS a very serious love film because Bergman gives us both the glory and grime of a marriage dissolving. In true and typical Bergman fashion, each scene of this film is a very serious "take my breath away," because the truth and turmoil at the heart of this marriage ending are about as real as my hand in front of my face. Liv Ullmann and Erland Josephson as Marianne and Johan give towering performances. I will never forget the scene where Marianne and Johan go to the lawyer's office to sign the divorce papers and literally get into a fist fight. After the fight (and the marriage) is over, they both with their tattered hair and hearts sign the divorce papers. This film is as stunning as it is sacrificial. Marriage IS sacrifice and when that's not there, stunning is any marriage's dissolvement. I probably could have listed a handful of Ingmar Bergman films that explore the theme of this kind of intense love, but I have to keep this list as brief as possible.😉

3. MARRIAGE STORY (2019):
Very much like SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE, this film is haunting and often horribly uneasy to sit through. Scarlett Johansson as Nicole and Adam Driver as Charlie give exceptionally riveting performances as a married couple with way too big egos (she is an actress and he is a theatre director and if that's not "way too big egos," I don't know what is). I will never forget the scene where Nicole goes to Charlie's apartment and they are in the throws of so much anger and so much hurt that the walls of Charlie's apartment are about to come down. Johansson's Nicole delivers to Driver's Charlie the line that is THE line where love hoped to save this marriage and love can't save this marriage intersect, "You're so merged with your own selfishness, you don't even identify it as selfishness anymore!" That line "took my breath away" because I totally identified with it. A marriage on its way to a divorce is all about selfishness unidentified anymore. The proclaimed egos of both partners "win out" and when ego "wins out," everything is "lost in" a marriage war of two "way too big egos."

4. THE DANISH GIRL (2015):
It's so cool that this film is #4 on this list, as #4 is my spiritual number. It's also cool that this film is #4 on my all-time favorite films' list, as well. The story of Gerda and Einar (Lily) Wegener is what love films should always be about: The sacrifice one partner needs to make for a marriage to survive (often times in a marriage, both partners have to make sacrifices). Gerda makes the ultimate sacrifice by accepting that her husband, Einar, believes he is a woman and wants to have an operation to become Lily, the woman he always was on the inside. Anyone else that I can think of in Gerda's position would have said in response to this, "no way, no how….this marriage is OVER!" Gerda loves Einar so much that she is willing to do just about anything (and she does) to keep their love alive. Alicia Vikander (Oscar winner for Best Supporting Actress) is an absolute and complete revelation in her performance as Gerda, and Eddie Redmayne completely and totally seals the deal in his performance in this film to make him my all-time favorite actor next to Joaquin Phoenix. I swear I could go on and on about how this film "takes my breath away" at every twist and turn where love is concerned but, once again, I'm needing to be brief here.😉

5. YENTL (1983):
Very similar to THE DANISH GIRL, this film is not your conventional love film. It's about a woman who loves this man who thinks a woman is a man, this man who loves another woman who is also a woman but since he can't have this other woman, the man asks a woman to marry this other woman so he can be close to this other woman, and a woman who this man thinks is a man marries this other woman, and if none of that "takes your breath away," I'm not sure what ever would! This film "takes my breath away" because it's simply about the lengths and heights and depths we find ourselves reaching for in the throes (or thrown) of love. And because I am a huge Barbra Streisand fan and this is Barbra's best film EVER, I can't think of any other love film that pleases and excites me more than this one. And never mind that it is mainly because of Barbra Streisand and my love for her that helped me to believe that I could ever be someone someday who could love someone someday. Now, that "takes my breath away."

6. WHO'S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? (1966):
While most in a million years would never call this film a "love film," I do because it's a film about the absence of love in a marriage, the absence that is SO common in a lot of marriages, and an absence so penetrable that the married couple in this film actually make up that they have a child to keep the marriage bearable. Edward Albee's play and Mike Nichols' film adaptation are what I love most about stories where love has flown the coop (if it was ever in the coop in the first place), i.e., the dissection and probing of the insides of people who are losing their identity because love has become nonexistent while brutality and mean-spiritedness are what's left to exist. Elizabeth Taylor, known for her striking beauty, goes from "riches to rags" in her physical beauty and gives us an "ugly" Martha, a force of nature who is as forceful as she is vulnerable. Taylor, Best Actress Oscar winner) gives what I consider the very best female performance ever captured on film. Richard Burton as George and George Segal as Nick are also excellent, but it's the other female performance of Sandy Dennis as Honey (Best Supporting Actress Oscar winner) that makes this love film truly one that "takes my breath away" every time I see it….and I've seen it a lot!😉

7. TESS (1980):
If there can be any love film that is truly lovely to look it, it would be this film. Based on Thomas Hardy's classic novel of the same name, Roman Polanski directed this film that makes the novel come breathtakingly and beautifully alive. This film "takes my breath away" not just because it's pretty to look at but also because it is rapturous and daring to expose seduction between a man and a woman as actually rape, and how that one act of domination produces shame that stays with the victim. I know that one's shame is to be nailed to The Cross of Jesus but for some, death is the one way, and maybe the only way, to be rid of that shame. Nastassja Kinski as Tess might not be the best actress who ever lived, but Polanksi knew exactly what he was doing by casting her in the title role. Because Kinski was a relative unknown and maybe because Polanski knew she wasn't the greatest actress around, it was precisely these two very things that allowed Kinski to inhabit Tess as bright-eyed innocent, and naïve. A well-known and a great actress would have destroyed these precious traits, so thank God Polanski and Kinski didn't. There's one scene of a closeup of Tess with the brightest yellow sun behind her that to this day, every time I see a sun like that, it "takes my breath away," and I call it, "the Tess sun." LOVE THAT! ❤️

8. THE WAY WE WERE (1973):
It certainly makes sense that I would have two Barbra Streisand films on this list but even if I didn't love Streisand, this film would be on it anyway and probably most others' "love film" list. It's the ultimate love story of the girl over there and the guy over here and how there and here come together and we are all the better for being present to witness that. The odds are that two beautiful actors like Redford and Streisand couldn't possibly go wrong in a beautiful love film that ends with a closing scene that still "takes my breath away." Streisand's Katie and Redford's Hubbell are looking at each other after having separated when famous Streisand takes that famous hand and famously brushes away that famous hair from Redford's famous face. "See ya', Katie." "See ya' Hubbell." See me balling my eyes out.😥😥

9. CASABLANCA (1942):
While not the film I would have included on my "take my breath away" love films' list, I'm including it because it's on the top of the list for two of my favorite people and because any film with an actor or actress with the last name of "Bergman" should be on any film list I compile (see #2 for that "other Bergman" film). That said, I have seen this film and I remember loving it very much. Many "love film" aficionado's are divided into two camps where this film's ending is concerned: One group wants Rick to let Ilsa board that plane to Lisbon with Laszlo for The Resistance, while the other group says, "C'mon! Rick and Ilsa forever! We're not talking about The Resistance here! We're talking about love!" This film reminds us that love doesn't always end as victorious as The Resistance, but what we cannot "resist" is that we loved in the first place. That is usually enough for any kind of love to take flight.

10. IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT (1934) and SOMEWHERE IN TIME (1980):
I admit I was torn between which of these films to include to round out the top 10 "take my breath away" love films, until it dawned on me that both films have something very much in common: The element of time when and where love is lost and/or found. IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT is simple enough to say love can happen one night, whereas SOMEWHERE IN TIME says one night is fine, but true love cannot be contained by the element of time. Love can happen one night, sure, and then more nights can happen after that, but sometimes you have to go "somewhere in time" to find that love again. Whether one night or "somewhere in time," love alters us to our very core and we do search time and space to find it, but there are no guarantees that the Jericho Walls (reference to the ending of IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT) will stay up or come down when love happens in just one night or "somewhere" outside of space and time for a lifetime.

Now, I'm not currently in a love relationship (unless you count Jesus) but if I were, my partner would need to have seen AT LEAST one of these films. If not, watching AT LEAST one of these films is essential if any partner who loves me expects to "take my breath away." 😉❤️

En la actualidad la separación o el divorcio entre parejas se ha vuelto algo muy recurrente. Sin embargo, el proceso que esto implica se puede tornar muy difícil para ambas partes, ya que significa cortar relaciones con esa persona que alguna vez amaste.
Por ello, el director y escritor, Noah Baumbach, decide buscar retratar en su cinta "Historia de un Matrimonio (2019)" el doloroso proceso de divorcio por el que pasan Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) y Charly (Adam Driver). Una pareja que tiene que buscar la mejor manera para convivir juntos, a fin que su hijo no se vea afectado por los problemas de ellos.
Una historia que es narrada de excelente forma, ya que permite que como espectadores conozcamos las perspectiva o punto de vista de ambos protagonistas en este problema. Esto, debido a que la cinta nos plantea un desarrollo donde cada personaje tiene su momento para exponer sus aspectos positivos o negativos como persona, a través de sus acciones y diálogos, para que así, podamos empatizar con ellos y elegir o no un bando al cual darle la razón.
Y es que la cinta te sumerge en el mundo de los personajes mostrando muchos detalles de su diario vivir y por ende la perspectiva de cada uno. Con ello, el filme llega a tocar puntos sensibles y emocionales en la audiencia, sin la necesidad de haber vivido una experiencia similar, porque plantea situaciones y problemas que se sienten muy humanos.
Además, la película siempre te deja claro que se trata de una historia que puede suceder en la realidad a cualquier pareja. En este sentido, "Historia de un Matrimonio" llega a conmover por la empatía y rasgos humanos que generan los protagonistas a través de sus actores y su puesta en escena.
Ya que, tanto Scarlett Johansson como Adam Driver logran adentrarse en los sentimientos de dolor y pérdida que origina una ruptura matrimonial. Dos actores que son conocidos por sus papeles como la Viuda Negra y Kylo Rem en las populares cintas de Marvel y Star Wars. Pero que en este filme logran conseguir una actuación diferente a la que estamos acostumbrados a verlos.
Así mismo, la puesta en escena es buenísima ya que, por ejemplo, la fotografía logra generar el sentimentalismo intenso que manifiesta cada personaje. Esto debido a los encuadres que se realizan en que por momentos enfocan sus rostros y en otras veces pequeños detalles de sus acciones. Y así, poco a poco te llevan de la mano por los motivos, recelos y miedos que sufren sus personajes, resultando así un clímax increíble, pero a la vez angustioso en el que se ven involucrados.
En definitiva, "Historia de un Matrimonio" se vuelve una reflexión sobre la empatía, explorando desde un punto en el que ya es demasiado tarde. De esta forma la cinta se vuelve un el proceso de los protagonistas en darse cuenta de esta importante lección, ya que la empatía involucra tener en cuenta los sentimientos de los demás o como dicen ponerse en los zapatos de esas personas.
Ya que al final de cuentas las razones que se plantean en ambos personajes durante el filme son bien genuinas y llegan al punto en el que no importa de qué lado estemos porque en realidad no hay un victorioso y nadie puede ganar en este proceso de separación.

Noah Baumbach escribió y dirigió ésta película que definitivamente me ha dejado sin palabras. 
Scarlett Johansson y Adam Driver interpretan a una pareja que está por divorciarse; la historia nos muestra en un inicio las bellas cualidades de cada personaje de ésta historia y cómo poco a poco van transformándose en lo que más odian con tal de ganar ésta batalla, lo que no saben los que han pasado por algo así, es que no hay ganadores en un divorcio. El director hace un excelente trabajo plasmando esto en la pantalla y nos confronta con ésas realidades, ése dolor, ése duelo, ése sentimiento de pérdida es mostrado de manera convincente. Una película intensa, fuerte y práctica, no desperdician un sólo segundo. 
Lo más fácil hubiera sido narrar la misma historia de siempre, donde uno de los involucrados es el villano y hacernos tomar partido; éste no es el caso, ambos son tan buenos y malos... ambos pierden, aún ganando y ésa es la virtud de ésta magnífica película.

Like all Noah Baumbach's films, I'm split on it. It seems like it is heartfelt and thoughtful, deep, enlightened, warm, complex, philosophical---but after viewing I feel like I've been eating potato chips rather than having a substantial nourishing meal. Clearly he's talented and not stupid. The writing is fine. He has directorial skills. But there's a superficiality and faint whiff of nihilism around him that you won't find in, say, Wes Anderson,  Richard Linklater, Jim Jarmush. And while someone like Scorsese is nihilistic he (a) struggles with that and (b) is unabashed about it. Something about Noah Baumbach's posturing about being humanistic gets up my nose. His work is carefully crafted but, to me, ultimately somewhat hollow--possibly because most of his work is about himself, thinly veiled to be about humanity and the human condition but ultimately his own view of the world and humankind arising directly from his own lived experiences---passed off as insightful, but perhaps just under the surface lurks semi-smug self-preoccupation and narcissism. Rendered---but not created. He's good at what he does. tho. And performances from all the cast are outstanding.

Curon is a horror series on Netflix, that was released this year. It has received many positive reviews due to the story it tells. The story takes place in a small town in Italy. This story mainly shows the contrast between good and evil, and how a person can be compassionate or aggressive. In it there are disappearances, murders and a lot of violence scenes. 
This series tell us the story of Anna, who is a single mother who lives with her two teenage children and for different reasons they had to move to Curon, the town where Anna, the mother, grew up. When they arrive to the town everything unfolds in a calm way, but slowly the story becomes more tense and strange things begin to happen. 
In my opinion, I think it´s a series that you should watch because it uses good actors, that maybe are too recognized, but they perform very well in their role. Another good point is that the town is very emblematic, this means that the cloudy and dark landscapes are attached to a horror story, and the music that it uses is surprising. It is an unpredictable series and if you like dark humor and horror this is your series.

In short, it's a tiresome and dull look at a crumbling marriage.  Noah Baumbach was extremely lucky by the generous reviews and acclaim he has received from this film. 
From a filmmaker's standpoint, this film was many notches below Scenes from a Marriage by Ingmar Bergman or Kramer vs. Kramer. A Marriage Story was too derivative of what we have already seen and there were no exemplary traits that made it stand out from the films that came before it. It was self-indulgent and visionless. When thinking back on the film, there is one scene that comes to mind that stands out but is not distinct. The scene, which is the most talked about, takes place in the very drab apartment where they let out their emotions. This scene felt like a rehearsal or improvised exercise for actors rather than a cinematic, well-written scene where the words make you feel. Rather, it was the actors doing their jobs well, with the wrong dialogue. The writing gives me no reason to feel empathy for them.
The apartment was an accurate portrayal of a typical badly designed apartment in LA but the realism of it was uninspiring and bleak. Sure, that could have been the point and probably his intention but is realism and bleakness what we need in cinema? Where are the days when films felt like an escape and not some depressing rollercoaster through a dismal life? It would be one thing if Noah Baumbach wanted insight into these kinds of relationships from a sociological standpoint and was an upbeat positive person (the opposite of the characters), but he is in fact just taking from his own sad experiences that frankly have been done far better and don't deserve this type of attention. 
Overall, there was an unnatural feeling to the whole film that placed oneself in between a film and theater and an audition room. I appreciate some of Noah Baumbach's work but this one was a miss for me, he can do better. Unlike the Meyerowitz stories, the casting was off and although the actors performed well, I didn't believe in their initial reason for being together or their cry-baby emotions that felt contrived. 
My last question is, who cares about some random couple in LA going through a divorce? There are more important stories to be told that involve realism. Noah Baumbach, stop being so self-absorbed.
This movie felt very personal, I constantly felt like I was in the room with them. Incredible directing and acting!

This is such a beautiful movie! While it is clear from the start that the movie talks about the separation process of a couple, it is trully able to tell their whole marriage story. It tells you how they met, when and why they fell in love, what started to feel wrong at some point and what lead to the break up, all that in a very sutil way (while it feels like just a divorce story is being told, maybe no such story can be told without describing the whole relationship). It does not try to convince you that they might get together and play with your expectation that they will do so at some point, it is mostly interested in "studying" the feelings and actions of a divorce. Nicole and Charlie love each other. They do have problems, they do seem confident about their decision of divorcing, they do get too involved in the process but, in the end, they love each other. Right from the very first scenes, the incredibly beautiful descriptions each character makes of the other already shows how much love and care is still there. This is such a rich montage in my view, not only for the beautiful soundtrack and the rythm of images but for how it is able to describe the characters and also show how they view each other. Charlie already seems to be more critic while Nicole almost worships her husband. The movie shows the divorce process in such a raw and real way, making it so clear that there will never be a true winner in this case because they love and care about the family; any result will feel like a loss. Things escalate without intention, what also sometimes seems unavoidable in a situation full of tension and misunderstood feelings. There are several powerful scenes besides the initial montage: the long conversation that turns into a fierce argument (the only one in which feelings are actually showed), Charlie singing Being Alive with an excruciating amount of feeling, Charlie reading a book for his kid lying at the same bed in which Nicole weeps at the side, Charlie and their son reading the initial letter wrote by Nicole. This is a sad, soul-crushing experience but that feels extremely real and shows with precision the complexity of feelings and events surrounding a divorce. I really loved it.

Considering the painful subject matter and some truly awful situations the characters find themselves in, I found this movie – for the most part –hilarious and uplifting. People make mistakes, but there is empathy and redemption for them.

The theme of the film was mature, and at times hard to follow, though it undoubtedly succeeded in many areas, including score and acting. Other than a few electric and dramatic scenes, the film felt slow, and it really did just pass the time.
Not only were Driver's and Johansson's performance exceptional, the emotion and underlying themes of this moving story set it far above other drama/romance movies.

With amazing acting performances from Kylo Ren and Black Widow and beautiful music, Marriage Story is a movie that I truly adore. This movie isn't just a divorce story about two people yelling at each other for the entire movie. It shows you what really goes on during a couple's struggles from both sides. Neither one is the "bad" guy and both want what's best for their kid and also each other. It also shows you the legal battles that goes behind a lot of divorces which was really interesting to see. The music was beautiful and it was one of my favorite parts of the movie. Another part that I think is underappreciated is the cinematography. The entire movie looks like a moving photograph. It represents the fact that when you look at one, you remember what happened behind that photograph and the memories begin to start flowing in. It made the movie really feel like it was about the whole family and not just a single person. I also love how they did then ending. It didn't feel depressing or bad at all. In the end you're not mad or angry at one of them, you just hope the best for both of them and that's it. The acting is amazing and I adore everything about this movie. I highly recommend watching it.

Scarlett Johansson, Adam Driver, Laura Dern, Ray Liotta, Alan Alda; obscenely talented cast. Johansson and Driver had the perfect chemistry to make you believe they were two halves of a failing marriage. Absolutely loved how the big-shot lawyers (Liotta and Dern's characters) changed the energy when on screen, particularly during the courtroom scenes. Also, have to give Noah Baumbach the credit he deserves for crafting the brilliant dialogue in this film. Haven't ever been through a divorce so I can't speak to the accuracy, but I really loved how real all of the characters felt based on the way they interacted with one another and how their behavior changed towards their child as the plot progressed. No good guys, no bad guys, but lots of animosity. Definitely one to give a chance if you're a fan of the casts' other work, or really just if you have some time to spare.

Bambaugh's bitter-sweet comedy about a failing marriage is faultlessly acted and painfully honest about how love can survive the cruelties of divorce. So much here is so nuanced and subtle: even the (very funny) cameos of Laura Dern, Ray Liotta and -especially - Alan Alda as a trio of venal lawyers never stray into caricature. Randy Newman contributes a lovely melancholy score. But of course it's the central coupling of Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver that is pitch-perfect. Has either of them done anything as heartbreaking and true?

I realize this was nominated for awards.  BUT.  Whoever dreamt up this film was definitely not thinking about "entertainment."  It's unnerving when the only comic relief you get in a film so brutal as this is just for one single second out of two hours of emotional bludgeoning, and it's a guy accidentally slicing his arm open. Normally I would never laugh at something like that. It really is unsettling to think that's "funny."  I totally surprised myself when I laughed out loud.

It's absolutely true that Scarlett Johansson, Adam Driver, Laura Dern, Alan Alda, Ray Liotta, and Julie Hagerty give strong performances, and this is a strong movie.  I like strong, but strong when it means unrelenting brutalizing of the audience is not for me.  What this really could have used is Wally Shawn moments of pure comic relief.

Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson star in the original Netflix drama Marriage Story.  Contrary to the title, the film is actually about a bitter divorce; while in marriage counseling Charlie Barber is ambushed with divorce papers and has to scramble to combat his wife's high priced lawyer who's coming after everything.  Driver and Johansson give good performances and are backed by a strong supporting cast that includes Laura Dern, Ray Liotta, and Alan Alda.  Yet it gets too dark and ugly to enjoy, as the characters just get meaner and more spiteful.   Marriage Story takes on some heavy subject material, and it's not pretty.

This is a well-crafted film that would have been better named Divorce Story. It's slow and sad, focusing on realism in the portrayal of the characters than it does on having an interesting or meaningful story. It often seems to actively avoid portraying anything meaningful, and instead portrays nihilistic existentialism as the inescapable norm. It's solidly produced in all other respects.

Closest comparison: It's like While We're Young (2014) with more futile shouting.

I just saw Marriage Story and I have to say I liked it more than I thought. Sure, Scarlett Johanson's and Adam Driver's performances deserve to be celebrated, but the one who gives the best performance is Laura Dern, who is as wonderful as ever. In general, the film seemed to me that it re-proposes themes already touched in movies like Kramer vs. Kramer and A Separation, but it does it with a sufficiently original style. The final result is a very pleasant film, masterfully shot by Baumbach, who has a very delicate and discreet eye. In particular, I appreciated the choice not to give in to the typical patheticism of so many melodramas, which would have made the film unbearable to watch. Ultimately, while not a masterpiece, I have to say that Marriage Story is a very good work that shows, with discreet realism, a painful slice of life.

Good scripting, directing and acting, you can see the quality behind the movie.

For all its trying to be "real", I think at least one of the characters who are getting a divorce should have realistically tried to avoid the divorce and reunite with the partner. Instead, they don't talk to eachother on this level. Even Charlie, who initially seems to consider it only a temporary separation, does not even mention an intention of reunion, sometime in the future. From either side, there's no hint of will of working out the differences and find a compromise, of exploiting the separation for the good of the couple and the family.

Even though it's easy to relate to both the main characters and share their point of view, Nicole is portrayed in a slightly more negative light. She breaks the promise to do without lawyers, which may not have been such a bad thing had she told Charlie she had changed her mind instead of deploying tricks to get an early upper hand. She even goes as far as to mortgage her mom's house to pay the lawyers. That would be understandable under dire circumstances, but not when your husband is begging you to find a consensual agreement and not throw money out of the window, that could instead be saved for the child's future. He is instead depicted as slightly more responsible, and only resorts to the top-dollar lawyer after having been thoroughly battered and humiliated together with his earlier, more humane lawyer.

Marrige Story was written and directed by Noah Baumbach and it stars Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver as a married couple seeing their marriage fall apart while getting a divorce. This movie has some of the best acting of the year, for sure. I never got to see a weak link in the cast. This is not the type of movie you'd expect given the circumstances of the story. You barely even get to see them fighting, they do only twice during the entire movie. It's very beautifully shot, and some takes are dragged out creating some beautiful images throughout the movie. Nonetheless, this is not a movie for everyone, as it is a slowly paced, character driven movie with few "exciting" moments. I personally had a great time watching this movie. One of the best movies of last year in my book.

i myself, as someone who never liked the idea of marriage, see this movie as something that holds great importance, and a wake-up call for the people who are swamped with emotions that couldn't sort themselves out of the mess. of course, me as a young millennial, living in an international big city, has been in an open relationship and believes in polyamory myself, isn't interested in kids and dislikes marriage as a system - it might seem easy for me to get over the ideas, but the challenges presented in the movie are very real, for people who indeed decided to go down the isle: when interests become more intertwined, when there are kids, when the time has been long that it's next to impossible to reverse the roles and expectations established through time in the relationship, the only way out is to break it off, but even that is not easy, and breaking it off by no means is equal to not having feelings anymore. what the lawyers were doing were negotiations, they of course, pointed out the parts that were positive towards their own customer, but as more and more dirty truths (or lies) were spilled out, neither of them was totally innocent without fault, although they both appeared to be genuinely good people. although the ending was really emotional that i was almost crying, and it kinda ended with a positive light, the drama, hurt, betrayal, power and control, the struggle between one's own identity and the role in the relationship and family, those things had left permanent marks that in no way could be lightened by the slightly happy ending. my takeaways on practical marriage and relationship advice would be, first, there's no secret - don't think that you can cheat and hide well, most likely the lies you've told will ultimately come back to you, no matter how innocent your intentions might have been; second, it's very important to be able to maintain one's own identity in a relationship, and compromises especially on the big decisions in life cannot be one sided, and this is particularly important for women who face more pressure from both the society and their intimate partners; third, be as clear as possible about each person's responsibility, the kids can be the most tricky thing, but maybe it would be easier if there were two kids, i'm not very sure. in general, a decision to share a life with someone else is a huge one, don't take it lightly, don't let infatuation be the sole factor in this decision.

I was not expecting this movie to turn out the way it did, nor did I expect it to make me feel the way I did. The beginning starts out as something you would think is what real love seems like, and when you are introduced to the characters, they completely change in the movie based on the beginning. The story is basically a husband and a wife going through struggles in their marriage, in the beginning, you wouldn't think they were having problems at all. 
The acting between the husband and the wife towards each other did not feel fake or like you could tell it was written for a movie. It made me feel like I was in real life and it showed the actual reality of a lot of lives that I have never thought of. There is one scene in particular that I think was the one the best acting I've ever seen, and the movie itself was done very well. 
I liked the storyline and how it continued to play out throughout the movie. My favorite part was probably the ending. At first honestly, I thought I hated it, but you think you hate it because you wish the story would have turned out differently. But you know that, again, in reality, the ending is really how it would be in real life. It made me so angry at the end but that's what made it so good. I would usually cry or feel sad for the couple, but instead, I was angry but also content because I knew that's really what life is like. It is definitely a movie for older kids and adults. Honestly, the use of all the language makes the movie so much better and adds more emotion. My parents also enjoyed the movie and thought the acting was very well done.

Noah Baumbach's shrewdly toxic deconstruction of an American divorce is made more harrowingly to sit through with his sharp-witted writing and deliriously heartbreaking performances from Oscar nominees, Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson.

Aside from the performances, this thing is a hot mess. First, it's not at a "marriage" story at all, but a poorly plotted and executed divorce story. Worse, the film doesn't present a credible motivation for the characters' situation, nor for any of the decisions the characters make. These problems are there from the opening's misdirection where we are treated to how much the protagonists like each other only to shift, with no explanation, into the current setting where they are, inconsistently, alienated. Then, again for no credible reason, Nicole turns to a divorce lawyer and then both characters turn into unidimensional victims of the writer's screed against divorce lawyers. That leads to an unrealistic set piece of everything turning vicious in the courtroom in a way no judge I know would allow. Another set piece follows when Nicole and Charlie, again incredibly, brutally lash out at each other verbally, only to have things end with a predictably bittersweet conclusion where Nicole and Charlie, apparently reconciled to their separation, exchange sad looks. And then there's the rather bizarre back-to-back scenes where Nicole and Charlie both, rather poorly, take on Sondheim numbers. These scenes come out of nowhere, go nowhere, and contribute nothing at all to the story. I suppose, given how badly the rest of this is written, these songs might have been the writer's lazy attempt to use these songs as a commentary on the characters' inner states. But, just like most of the rest of this, they're just another couple of scenes that fail to work. Disappointing.

Dern deserves a solo lead Oscar worthy best actress award film next as proven by her Oscar win for best supporting actress. Others might not relate to divorce issue as it differs from audience but Marriage Story deserves an Oscar Best Picture nomimation because what presented in this film is a real-life struggles of living in separation and divorce. It presented to us how really hard it is - financially draining and also how extreme it will test your character.
