Marriage Story captures both sides of the story for once, which is kind of rare I would say in the cinematic world. Charlie and Nicole start the story by writing about each other, the things they love about each other when they are in one of the therapist sessions. Nicole declines to share her writings and Charlie was keen on sharing his but Nicole was no longer interested in Charlie or his thoughts. What sounds like a perfect marriage, slowly shows us how the two ends up destroying each other in ways they never thought they could. 
Charlie has always been dependent on his work, his life revolved around his theatre. His choices were based on what he thought would be best, Nicole never had a say and it was getting to a point where she felt she was nothing but worthless as an individual. The writer and the director of the movie have played with emotions, not everything is sad and dull, there is a lot of humor as well. The scene where Nicole wants to serve Charlie with the papers has to be one of the best scenes in the movie, it shows the complete chaos that happens in a family. 
The couple had agreed to solve everything by themselves and make sure that their son does not feel the wrath of the divorce. But when Nicole moves back to LA, she becomes a totally different person, in her terms she's finally free and can make decisions and choices of her own. Henry, their son slowly loses interest in his father as he enjoys his mother's company more. Charlie does not give up on his son easily, he in fact fights for him till the very end. 
You get to experience the true bitter nature of both the characters when they involve the lawyers. Nicole's lawyer Nora is well known to get the best possible deals for her clients, while Charlie struggles to find a lawyer at first, he later finds someone who was very lethargic in nature. Charlie eventually hires Jay after he realizes Nicole is ready to destroy him no matter what. 
A scene where Charlie and Nicole go against each other is probably one of the most emotional scenes of the movie as you get to understand how bad they could taint each other. The movie ends with possibly one of the best sequences in which Henry is reading the notes that Nicole had made in the first scene of the movie, Charlie reads it and eventually bursts into tears and Nicole stands behind him equally emotional. Marriage story is indeed a complete circle.

A startling exploration of marital union, gender roles and our disconnected society as a whole, this 2019 dramatic triumph from writer-director-producer Noah Baumbach boasts the hallmarks of an auteur at the top of his game: raw, emotional performances from expertly-casted actors, simple yet gripping cinematography that pulls few punches, and an understated score which gives us that warm, fuzzy feeling when you reconnect with a sorely missed loved one. The film is equal parts devastating and inspiring as it unravels, rewarding moviegoers on their first or fifth watch with a heartbreaking and hilarious family experience.

As a child of divorce, this film is a remarkably realistic and visceral depiction of what divorce is truly like. Throughout the film, the viewer witnesses the good intentions of former spouses be ripped apart by the legal process of divorce and replaced with cruelty, apathy, and unequal conditions. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson gave the best performances of their careers. From screaming matches to the small, intimate moments between the former couple, Driver and Johansson provided so much emotional weight for Noah Baumbach to work with. Laura Dern gave an excellent performance as the cutthroat divorce attorney trying to get her client everything she ever wanted, completely overriding any sentiment Nicole may have still had for Charlie. Despite Charlie's deplorable actions during their marriage, the viewer sympathizes his plight as his world is turned upside down and his son is permanently brought to L.A., a testament to Driver's incredible work with the character. While the apartment meeting scene is by far the most emotionally impactful, there were countless scenes in the film where Charlie and Nicole's pain, anguish, and resignation could be palpably felt. Baumbach did a fantastic job getting the best performances out of Driver and Johansson and his subtle camera shifts during purely conversational scenes helped sell the realism of the film. I was thoroughly overjoyed at the ending as in real life, divorce is not merely bitter arguments and loathing one another (at least in some cases). The love was still present between Nicole and Charlie, it just manifests itself through their mutual love of their son - which is how divorce should be. Overall, Marriage Story is an excellent movie and a testament to how impactful realism in the film industry can be.

This isn't my kind of movie (drama) but I had to check it out after seeing the incredible ratings it's received.  It's kind of funny though, as it's been on my list for a while, and of all days to watch it, I unknowingly picked Valentine's Day.  It wasn't until a friend pointed out the irony that I realized the choice I subconsciously made.  So it's an excellent movie.  The performances are so genuine that it feels so real.  You feel like you know the family and they're your friends.  You feel for them during the tougher times, they melt your heart during the good times, and they make your blood boil during the hostile parts.  It's a rollercoaster ride of emotions.  I absolutely do not agree with Laura Dern winning the Oscar for best supporting actress.  She didn't stand out at all imo, and if anything I though Ray Liotta did a more memorable job that her.  I'm shocked she won the award.  I feel like this movie experience for ppl going through a divorce will be akin to hearing an Adele song.  You feel like the art is made specifically for you... like the art is about your life.  Just like how divorced women felt attached to Eat Love Pray way back when.  It's that kind of movie.  But it's not made just for them... it's made for everybody.  In some way or another, bc of how genuine the viewing experience feels, most ppl will be able relate to the movie.  Lastly, I totally think Scar Jo deserved the Oscar for best actress.  She totally hits it out of the park.  And it's such an "Oscar" role too.  I'm a big fan of hers so I was a bit perturbed when she didn't win.  So that's my take for the day... Oscars suck and Marriage Story rocks.  I definitely recommend watching this movie whether you're single, married, going through a break up, or married for > 50 years.  This movie is for everybody.  I'm a horror addict, so if this movie appealed to me, it can appeal to anyone.

This is a must see and if you have Netflix, there is no excuse not to experience it. I'm really surprised that everyone is calling Johansson's and Driver's performances some of the best of their careers. I thought the acting was pretty terrible--Driver's especially. Maybe it's because all I see when I look at him is Kylo Ren or maybe it's because monotonous villainy encompasses the entire spectrum of his acting ability? In any case, that big fight scene where they're yelling back and forth made me laugh because of how ridiculous it was--not believable and not as "real" as the movie attempts to portray their relationship. Not to mention Driver looks like he's seriously struggling to make himself cry. It was depressing from start to finish, and Driver's affair made me unable to empathize with him at all; despite Johansson's character flaws, his deception and betrayal were undeserved, and I couldn't see past those aspects once they were brought to light. Dern was the exact same character she played in Big Little Lies, so her performance wasn't impressive in the least. The custody battle was engaging, but Johansson's case didn't seem to hold water for me, which made the drama all the more forced. Since when is it acceptable to move across the country with your child and enroll them in school in a different state during a custody battle? I don't know much about custody law, but I'm pretty sure that's not customary. Lastly, the 2.5-hr run time dragged on for what felt like an eternity. I've seen movies that portray a real-life strained marriage much more effectively that weren't anywhere close to receiving Oscar nominations, so I'm not sure why this one made the cut.

It was a little hard for me to get into this at first, and it also gets a bit depressing with all the divorce proceedings, but damn.. the acting in this by both the leads, powerful stuff indeed. I'd probably favor this a little bit towards Adam Driver, because he was absolutely phenomenal here but ScarJo does her best work in this too I'd say. I'd recommend giving this a watch.

Perhaps the greatest accomplishment from director Noah Baumbach in the 2019 Netflix film "Marriage Story" is the telling to two synonymous, yet vastly opposing narratives between two compelling protagonists. Career performances from both Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson elevate the film's magnitige through their dialogue and emotional range. Now Oscar-winning actress Laura Dern was the film's greatest surprise, portraying a hospitable, yet manipulative divorce attorney to Nicole. At no point was there a definitive right or wrong to either Charlie or Nicole's viewpoints, a testament to Baumbach's effectiveness in storytelling. "Marriage Story" left me with a variety of emotions, and I would recommend the devastatingly beautiful film to all moviegoers who appreciate the authenticity of human relationships.

The plot is so ridiculously simple that I'm most sure how this movie eve got made, but this movie is fantastic. This movie feels is so real that it almost feels like a documentary, the acting is absolutely impeccable and because the plot is so simple you can never predict what's coming next. It's a shame that neither Adam driver or Scarlett Johansson won an Oscar for this movie as this seems like possibly the peak of their careers. All in all great film, somehow sad, heartwarming, and frightening all at the same time.

Love the cast. Didn't like the movie. I really wanted to like it but it just irritated me. People screwing each other and being so hateful. Lawyers playing on every little insecurity and flaw to stick it to the other one. He was pitiful losing his son and trying to be a good Dad. Scarlett's character said he was a great Dad but she did everything she could to make it hard for him to spend time with his son during the separation time. He was treated like such an outsider. I think the first film I remember crying at was Kramer v Kramer; I don't know how old I was, but I remember being in the same room as it when the TV was showing it one Christmas. I don't think I fully understood it - but I know what stayed with me so powerfully was the way I sensed it articulating something of my own fear of my own parents splitting up. Not that I ever had any reason to think that would happen - it didn't. But I remember the fear. 

Many years and 20 years of my own marriage later, Marriage Story doesn't evoke the same fear, but it does evoke both a kind of sadness as to the way it portrays what so many go through, a kind of recognition of the sort of slow escalations that all of us experience in almost any sort of relationship. It's the simple - yet complex - story of a couple's marriage in breakdown ... they start in couple's counselling and ends in divorce, following the negotiation of the details along the way. 

It seems odd to cast the film among the performance industry - he is a theatre director, she an actress; at times that's in danger of tipping the film into the sort of conflicts most of us don't have to deal with, but in the end there's enough truth there to make this feel like an 'everyman' sort of relationship.

The whole film hints occasionally at the heightened realities of musicals - the framing, the tight close-ups and tracking shots following the long speeches of one or the other, maybe even the colour palette at times suggesting the 1950s/60s musicals golden era. When Adam Driver's character, near the film's end, sings a Sondheim song in a bar, that sense is bought closer to the heart; like musicals, the film is unashamed in trying to move us and does so.

Much of this is quite remarkable - Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are outstanding, both of them simultaneously sympathetic and repellant, highlighting the reality that the film doesn't force us to choose one side or the other; or if it does, the way we jump is down to our own biased, not the film's. The film's standout moment, an argument that starts amicably and ends in words that can't be unsaid, is the sort of sequence you feel as if you're privy to someone else's private pain, laundry that should only aired in private hung out for all to see. It's remarkable in performance, direction and writing - and everything else besides. 

The film also mines comedy out of some of the most painful situations; the moment Adam Driver's character is served with divorce papers is almost farce-like in its execution, yet the tonal shift within the scene never jars. Much within the film is funny, because people are funny; there's always a hint of joy, even in the midst of great pain. 

This, I think, is where the hope in the film comes from; given where we are almost certain the film will end right from the first scene, the light touches of humour and the moments of clarity amidst the recriminations, claims and counterclaims point us to the human capacity to be better versions of ourselves even when so much seems to be falling around us. Like the best films, it's never one thing entirely - it's a love story about a divorce, a drama with very good jokes and comedic scenes, a musical with only one song. It's a film about one particular relationship, that allows us to see every relationship (not just marital ones)  in a fresh light.

Despite its annoyingly vague title, Marriage Story is actually about a divorce. On one level writer-director Noah Baumbach's latest film feels like a divorce procedural. We follow a young attractive couple (Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver) as they agree to keep things simple and not involve lawyers, then involve lawyers, begin a custody battle, and try to navigate all of the emotional and legal complexities of legally dissolving a marriage. On another level, Marriage Story is a showcase of brilliant performances ranging from subtle to ostentatious, comical to moving. I enjoyed Marriage Story far more than I expected though I hesitate to recommend it since very few people (myself included) are able to have a good time by watching people argue and get divorced for over two hours. The divorce gets rocky but the film doesn't so much and if you are in the right mood for a relationship/divorce drama you'll find a decent, somehow, feel good movie.

This is the kind of movie that hangs entirely on its performances. Fortunately, the leads and supporting players all turn in strong performances. Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver have both earned Oscar nominations for their performances as the wife and husband seeking to uncouple themselves while remaining involved with their eight-year-old son and maintaining their careers. Both earn and lose and then earn back your sympathy. Charlie (Driver) is a successful New York theater director whose latest avant-garde production is headed to Broadway. Nicole (Johansson) once starred in a popular Hollywood movie but since meeting and marrying Charlie has committed herself to the stage. A Los Angeles native, Nicole has always wanted to spend more time on the West Coast and now has landed a role in a pilot that will likely become a series. Charlie thinks of them as a New York family and expects Nicole and their son to move back to New York once the pilot is done. When Nicole decides to officially file for divorce the real conflict between them begins.

Baumbach's script does not overtly take sides though it leans toward Charlie, especially toward the end of the film. The explosive climatic argument between Nicole and Charlie gives a chance for both actors to express intense emotions, but it is Driver who gets to let out overwhelming pathos. A court appointed observer—played with welcome awkward comic deadpan by Martha Kelly—is assigned to visit and interview both parents, but we only see the visit Charlie. Charlie does his best to present as an ideal father before the visit falls into dark comedy. In a wonderfully delivered monologue early in the film, Nicole gives us her backstory, both life events and emotional. After this scene the perspective shifts to Charlie and never really shifts back to Nicole. We are as blindsided as Charlie is by claims on money and custody by Nicole's lawyer.

Nora, Nicole's flashy and smoothly confident high-powered lawyer, is played with impressive ease by Laura Dern, who has earned a Best Supporting Actress nomination. We're just as charmed and dazzled by her as Nicole, and just as stung by her as Charlie. Alan Alda delivers some great low-key comedy as Charlie's first divorce lawyer. He's old enough that his hands shake but also old enough to know how bad a divorce can get, and how it will likely end, so, he recommends just starting there. On the complete opposite end of the spectrum is Ray Liotta as Charlie second divorce lawyer, a high powered and extremely expensive pit-bull. He speaks with such speed and ridiculous intensity that he can't help but be funny and believable as a ruthless lawyer. Julie Hagerty is a welcome presence as Nicole's actress mother. She has so much flighty warmth that she secretly helps Charlie find a divorce lawyer.

I'm sure certain viewers that have been through a divorce or even a bad breakup will find something relatable with the characters and situation in Marriage Story. I wouldn't be surprised if other viewers find these characters and their situation unrelatable. Nicole and Charlie, though not wealthy, are in a very upper middle class bracket. They are so accomplished that momentous life changing events like landing a starring role in a TV show and earning an Emmy nomination for directing (Nicole) and winning a MacArthur "genius" grant (Charlie) are just background plot points. Whether you can relate or not, the performances from Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver are of such a rare quality as to keep you invested in their emotional journey.

This was a cute / realistic movie. The two main characters were very believable. The script kept very important factors about a marriage separation feel as compelling as a much darker movie would tackle more serious topics. Typically these type of "life" dramas don't appeal to me because they are not relatable. Rather then focus on the reliability the story gives you a duality of opposite sides dealing with the same things. Relationships that we all have had once upon a time ago. Acting was surprisingly really good, coming from two actors that I particularly don't get excited for. Production was practical and lighting was source full and not exactly breath taking but there was that sense of realism that I spoke about, with a current day look.

Before I start this review, I would like to state that I am writing this review the day before the 2020 Oscars. Because of this, I have no idea which of the 8 contestants will win Best Picture. I know that Ford Vs Ferrari doesn't stand a chance, that Jojo Rabbit was probably nominated out of pity, and that Joker is a long shot. Honestly, if it were up to me, none of the nominees would win. Not a single one of my four favorite films of this year were nominated. Dark Waters, Knives Out, Harriet and Avengers: Endgame all missed the boat. However, if I had to choose which one of the actual Oscar nominees would win, I would, without a moment's reflection, choose Marriage Story. The reason this movie is great is because it doesn't actually feel like a movie. Every second of this movie feels like it's actually happening. This is, in part, because of the actors. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson both give perfect performances. Nothing they do feels faked or scripted. There is a scene early on in the movie where Johansson's character has a monologue directed at Laura Dern's character, and it's so well done, it doesn't even feel like a monologue; it feels like a real person, not a character, speaking her mind. Every actor and actress in this movie feels like they are really there, thinking the things they are saying, from the two leads, to the supporting cast (especially Laura Dern), all the way down to seemingly irrelevant featured characters (such as Jazmine Cephas Jones and Martha Kelly's characters). There are several songs performed in the film, and to an outsider, they may seem underperformed or unprofessional. However, that's what makes them work. They aren't being done to wow the audience, they are being done to show that these characters are basically real people, with talents, but also flaws. This is a wonderful film with great performances, great writing and just a general sense of greatness overall.

An absolute gut-wrenching look at the ending of a marriage. Marriage Story finds lure with it's talented director and screenwriter Noah Baumbach's vision through a cast of top-notch actors. A character study that allows each actor to shine and deliver their best work to date. A must see film!

Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver’s performances were magical. The story flowed together very well. The soundtrack was nice and appropriate. There was a bit of foreshadowing to show how a relationship grows over time. The character development is very well done. A must see film.

With "Marriage Story," Writer/director Noah Baumbach goes to a dark place to assess the end of a life shared by two unhappy people, taking over two hours of screentime to assess the difficulties of a specifically challenged marital union. "Marriage Story" is richly detailed, tastefully balanced with some needed comedy, and consistently attentive to the inner lives of the lead characters, who endure all the dehumanization of the divorce process in America. And yet, through the gloom and rising anxiety, Baumbach always preserves the heart of the moment, fleshing out the struggle of legal and emotional separation.

The film stars Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver. Laura Dern, Alan Alda, and Ray Liotta co-star.

Johansson locates surprising areas of honesty for the character, working wonderfully with Baumbach's observant screenplay. Johansson plays an interesting foil, so long in the shadow of her high-profile husband despite being the face of his success in many ways. You can see the pain on her face, but it slowly turns defiant as she discovers a new life and a new (or perhaps rediscovered) sense of self in California. Her performance is Sublime.

Driver has grown into one of the most respected actors of his generation a fearless and magnetic screen presence capable of making you believe everything he's saying no matter the context. He spends much of the film in a bemused haze as their divorce proceedings turn from civil to contentious, unable to understand how things went so sour despite his role in fracturing their relationship. It's the sort of skillful and soulful performance that's expected of him now, and he doesn't disappoint. Their chemistry is undeniable, and their performances sell the emotion of the script with ease.

While Driver and Johansson take up most of the space in the room, there's still enough oxygen for some fun and quirky supporting turns, be it Wallace Shawn's unfathomably horny thespian or Merritt Wever and Julie Hagerty as Nicole's sister and mother, respectively. But it's Dern, decked out in slinky, aggressive power dresses and extreme heels, who effortlessly steals the movie away whenever she enters a scene. She has great fun sparring with Liotta and Alan Alda (as a grandfatherly and mostly inept lawyer who may not be up for the job. "Marriage Story" is all about its performances, and those performances are flawless in every sense of the term.

"Marriage Story" manages to come out on the other side with a sense of calm and understanding, making an extraordinarily difficult viewing experience worth the pain to see how people can keep living even when life is determined to beat all the spirit out of you. The result is a near-perfect piece of transcendent art and one of the true standouts of 2019. 9.5/10

One of the year's best and most balanced movies, Marriage Story succeeds at being both laugh-out-loud funny and heartbreakingly sad. Here, Noah Baumbach shines in his very human and authentic depiction of two genuinely good - if flawed - people trying to navigate their way through an increasingly turbulent divorce. It seems apparent there's an autobiographical element to the movie: Noah began conceiving the film just a few years after his divorce from actress Jennifer Jason Leigh. According to the director himself, his ex wife likes the film a lot. His compassionate and empathic depiction of Nicole is noteworthy. 

Marriage Story feels like it could come straight from Woody Allen's oeuvre. Annie Hall comes closest, I think. But that's probably partly down to switching back and forth between NYC and LA. But watching Noah Baumbach's latest, one is most obviously reminded of Kramer vs Kramer. It's a testament to Marriage Story, then, that after watching it, Kramer vs Kramer feels dated (in fairness, it is forty years old) and Marriage Story feels superior. 

The film vilifies neither Nicole nor Charlie; instead, showing them as victims: victims of an unfair and outdated legal system that cruelly plays both parents off against one another. Insidiously, it strips those fighting for custody of their money, thus creating a desperate situation. The movie illustrates the ensuing escalating tensions through the increasingly unhealthy interaction between the two protagonists, which moves from strained, to quarrelsome, to full-on noxious. But Noah's script is punctuated with humorous and lighthearted moments to balance out the darkest parts.

Both actors are amazing throughout, and so deserving of the accolades they're receiving. But Driver is phenomenal. He elicits real emotion from the viewer, especially in those scenes with his son, which see him try ever so hard to win over his kid's approval. In one stand-out scene, Charlie grabs the microphone and sings Being Alive. It's incredibly engaging, and revealing, too. In another stand-out scene, he finds the notes of his wife, a list of all his greatest qualities, which she had previously refused to share with him. It's beautifully devastating, and Driver communicates the bittersweetness of this simply and powerfully. It's this scene echoes the movie's vibe: hopeful and redemptive even in despairing times.

Well acted by the two main leads, but the real actors people should look to in this movie are Laura Dern and Ray Liotta.  As the lawyers for Johansson and Driver's characters, they really bring it and show us how the process of divorce is messy and is a hard fought battle on all sides.  Well I don't think I connected with this movie as much as other people, I still enjoyed it.
This entire film is just completely dominated by Adam Driver's insanely amazing award winning performance in this film.

This movie is an accurate portrayal of a marriage ending. I loved watching the performances. Nicole coming out from under the relationship is all too real. The movie does seem to be more from Charlie’s point of view, and I do miss seeing more of Nicole’s story, however it is never sympathetic to Charlie.

They both like everyone in the world had flaws with ups and downs but in the end after it all the conclusion was to just spend all their money to fight for their son. Where two fight for their son or just ego? I guess that is for the audience to figure out.

Perhaps too real for some but one of the most honest looks at the difficulties of relationships and shows that Adam Driver is one of the best actors in Hollywood.

« Couldn't stop crying ». « I would not suggest to watch that movie with your lover ». I wanted to watch this movie with my lover and I wanted to cry. I like to cry when the right emotions hit the screen. But i've been warned. 

A preset fragile mood. The movie started. Five minutes later I thought that I was already there, ready to cry. But I quickly changed my mind. My time wasn't right yet. I kept asking myself when would the time be right? So many moments seem to be right. 

It came naturally. I felt everything. Emotions of all kinds. 

An end is never an end, it's the beginning of something different. The weight of the small conflicts existing in a relationship when you put them all together. What could have been done differently? Should we have tried to make things differently? 

The movie is not only about the crying. I laughed more than I cried, but those laughs come from a place of sadness. In the representation of the chaos of the separation everything seemed to fall in the right place.

Sitting right next to my boyfriend as the movie ended. I felt something special. Aware of the fragility of a relationship. I wanted to realize the present moment. Refusing to take anything from granted. Purrr

Just watched Marriage Story. 10/10. It is incredible nuanced and delicate in its story telling, while still hitting the heart wrenching moments full force. Its elements of foreshadowing are so natural that they are hardly acknowledged until their true purposes are revealed through incredibly dramatic and powerful means. It deals with such a complicated period in a families lives in such a masterful way. It is grounded in brutal reality, but manages to evoke a sense of something etherial. It exposes the harsh reality of marriage, while simultaneously being a commentary on humanity and love at large. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson arguably give the best performances of their careers so far, and Noah Baumbach's attention to detail, precision, and pace are extremely commendable.

I didn't expect to enjoy Marriage Story as much as I did, thanks in large part to the fine acting of both Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson. The topic is sensitive to those who've been through divorce but handled with aplomb by the entire cast. The script is well written, casting ideal for the characters.
A movie that keeps your heart feeling every fight, every deception and every last drop of love from the couple starring this story

Good movie. Emotional. Seemed sincere, like I imagined the filmmaker really lived this. Being single myself, it was fun to watch the dark side of marriage and relationships and how they can end so badly! Noah Baumbach's style is really nice, classy, smooth, subtle, rich and real, with a lightness and a sadness at the same time. It works well, especially with Randy Newman's beautiful score. And the performance of Adam Driver was exceptional, once again. The songs at the end were a sweet touch and I found them personally challenging; Is it really better to have loved and lost than to never have loved at all? I suspect the filmmaker was just trying to find a positive in his grim situation by claiming, 'well, at least I really lived'. But I'm not so sure going through awful divorces is really what life is all about. Good movie, though it felt like a movie made by 'Hollywood Luvvies' FOR 'Hollywood Luvvies'. I couldn't really relate all that much. But it was still well made none the less and felt poignant.

Yet another movie featuring a filmmaker baring their soul for the audience to celebrate, lament and understand, Noah Baumbach's "Marriage Story" follows in the footsteps of movies like "Lady Bird," "Roma" and the very recent "Honey Boy" in that it's not just an undeniably personal exercise. It's also a supremely well-executed artistic experience on a structural, dramatic, thematic, and technical level. It's rare to have a film operate so meticulously in its characterization process, yet remain so fascinating and emotionally impressive. In many other films, you'd label it a potential issue to have your average scene length be somewhere between 7-10 minutes, and to have most of those scenes involve characters simply talking to one another. But these are very carefully constructed moments of build-up, allowing the audience to breathe these characters in and empathize with every action taken and word spoken, no matter how hurtful or diabolical it may seem on the surface. At the end of the proverbial day, we find we're dealing with nuanced human beings trying desperately to navigate their respective ways through a tragic phase of existence (a kind of death, as the movie so aptly puts it). It's sad, heartwarming, brilliant, and earnest -- an experience I know I'll carry with me for some time.

When I first heard that this movie was "a beautiful story about divorce," I was confused to say the least. Tonight, I finally sat down to watch it. While it isn't my favorite movie of the year, I'd definitely recommend it.

As a start, the acting in this was some of the best I've seen in a while, personally, Adam Driver's performance was a huge stand-out. I think Adam Driver did alright in the Star Wars franchise, but this really helps me see him as a really good actor. On the note of great acting, I'd also like to point out Laura Dern's performance as the lawyer, which was also a notably good performance. Another strong component to this movie was the screenplay, Laura Dern's story about reading the script for the first time really sums it up. Baumbach used a great progression to convey the way the characters felt without simply stating it.

On the other hand, I had a few issues with the movie. I felt that there were certain unresolved threads. For example, this is getting into some light spoilers, the punch in the wall was hardly brought up again. There were a few other things that were never brought up. Another complaint for me would be some of the cuts the movie makes. I also felt that certain comedic bits were misplaced. Other than those complaints, this movie is great.

In retrospect, this movie is one of the best of 2019. Adam Driver's performance was a stand-out. While I know the Oscar will go to Phoenix for the Joker, I hope Adam Driver gets recognition for his performance in this. The movie's use of emotion kept me invested until the very end. I'd give this a solid 3.75/5

It's also really well-shot and well-edited. This is one of those rare movies where there really isn't anything bad about it at all. Well, maybe the score is a little weird and distracting sometimes. This film... No film in recent memory has taken me through such a vast array of emotions while being utterly captivated by its perfection. That's right, I said perfection. 'Marriage Story' is an exceptionally beautiful, raw, and realistic look at the highs and low of a marriage; as well as the immense toll divorce it takes on the participating individuals, whether it be financially, mentally, etc. The performances by the actors and their characters are phenomenal. Scarlet Johansson and really every cast member is fantastic, although it was Adam Driver that outright blew me away. He gave the performance of his entire career thus far, and easily the best performance of 2019 and possibly 2020 (we'll see). Everyone in the film is simply faultless, the actors and actresses disappear and all that is left is real people that you feel you are watching. The story is simple and yet powerful, and the script is a masterful blend of realism and gritty emotion. Throughout this entire experience I felt everything from warmth and laughter, to frustration and sadness. I was simply hypnotized by the film from the start. The casting, performances, plot, cinematography, score, it was all-too immaculate. There were even several moments within this film that almost had me tearing up, and that has almost never happens to me when watching a movie. There is an argument scene within this movie, and wow... All I have to say, wow... I don't know what else to say. Hop on Netflix, turn off your phone, and watch this film. If you don't have Netflix, start a free trial. Just watch this movie.
10/10

Marriage Story is simply put raw and true. I have no personal experience of this situation but it didn't matter. It is not a rollercoaster of emotion but a ripple all the way though. Even the light hearted and joyful moments provide no rest for the audience as it hits home what is worth holding on to but could potentially be lost. It is a wonderful and exceptional story that is brilliantly written from start to finish. There are no scenes without purpose. I can't put into words how great Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are. This film must be considered the best performance of their careers so far and in the future. They bring to life characters that have an undying love and respect for one another as a family and a devotion to their son in a failed marriage. Their genuine good intentions for their son mirrored against the clinical and legal battle of divorce that threaten to ruin their future are truly heartbreaking. 
   This film does not have any intention of being anything but true. It does not try to teach you anything or make you question anything. It's intention is simply to make you feel, and it does. The story and fantastic acting not only makes you feel the characters emotions but your own. That is why it is film that stays with you. The best film I have ever watched.

The story of Charlie and Nicole... One, a highly respected New York Theater director and the other, an L.A. Actress who, in a period of burnout, leaves her L.A. life and moves to New York where she meets, works with, and eventually marries Charlie.

Narration starts the story, where the two characters describe all that they love about each other while we see examples of those words depicted on screen. We then come to find that these "narrations" are actually the written words each has been asked to write about each other as they begin the process of divorce.  A beautifully well crafted and concise way of introducing the characters, establishing their love for each other, and why they married without delaying the main focus of the story... the pains of divorce.

Charlie and Nicole wish to end things as peacefully as possible. However, self-interest (or perhaps a bit of self-preservation) for the lives each wish to live beyond marriage interfere with those goals. The process of divorce, particularly when custody of a child is involved, picks at the wounds that led to the divorce, making it easier to forget what people may have once loved about each other.

Most divorces are a result of paths going in different directions, realizations of things that you may not have seen during the infancy of a relationship. Careers, ambition, feelings of self-worth... they all come into play and are depicted as fuel for the gradual demise of their relationship.

Now, enter the many vultures that surround these two looking to divorce. Divorce attorneys that you almost feel have developed their approaches or styles, perhaps based on some bad divorce they, themselves, had gone through. They do not always seem to have their client's best interests in mind. Their aim to score the win for their client simply fans the fires of pain that may already be encircling the soon to be ex-couple.

Without going further into plot, the biggest success of this film is how each character is a sympathetic character but at the same time, guilty of sins that may have led to current events, signifying there is no ALL Good or ALL bad... no main villain.. but simply two people whose paths intersected at one point, met each other's needs for a time, then ultimately drifted in different directions.

At the center of all of this is their son, who clearly loves both mother and father, who has some connection issues due to distances between father and son, both geographically and emotionally. But through it all, the son serves as catalyst for the rising contentiousness of the interaction between mother and father as they fight for custody.
All told, the story progresses to a moment that showcases some of the best acting I've seen from BOTH actors to date.

I would love to comment on the ending but I hesitate, not because of spoilers, but because I almost feel that the uncertainty of how it ends is part of what gives the ending a satisfying feeling.

Not since Kramer vs Kramer has a film about divorce given such a painfully earnest look at divorce. Fair, yet honest, and, at times, emotionally gut wrenching look into divorce. This movie is a must see.

Very flat. Boring. I have myself gone thru divorce and custody battle , and I can not relate too this film at all. The only time it comes alive is the scene in his empty, rented apartment in LA..and they have a heated argument.
The film managed to upset so many people because it brought something never realized before, wonderfully performed and accurate as few movies should be accurate
I did not expect that Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver would be this amazing in their dramatic acting.

One of the best of 2019 (although I saw it in 2020). A lot of heart, pain, and honesty. Had me smiling, laughing, crying, and captivated in a way that few films do. Adam Driver and Scarlet Johansson give the performances of their lives. Tremendous acting. Highly recommend.

I don't have a kid. I've never been divorced. Or even married. Though I guess I was once a kid myself, I'm not the product of a divorced couple. I'm not even the product of a married one. Everyone I know who has gotten married or had kids did it before I met them, or stopped hanging out with me almost immediately afterward. Everyone I've ever met who got divorced either did it before I met them, or is someone I stopped hanging out with beforehand. So I don't come to the subject of Marraige Story with a wealth of experience, which means it doesn't exactly scream "relatable content" to me. 

Let me start where it's easiest and everyone seems to agree: The performances. Everyone in Marriage Story is pretty great, none of the characterisations changed my life, but I get it. As a chance to display what these actors are capable of in a mundane setting where all that matters is their performance, yes, absolutely, Marriage Story has buckets of success. 

Outside of this though... I'm not even going to say that it "fails" elsewhere, just that it didn't win me. I like bleak movies, I like movies that make me feel something, even if it's sad. But Marriage Story isn't really that. It poses you the question of whether both Charlie and Nicole are good or bad people, and shows you each from their own and other's perspective. The ending seems to imply that they're good, or at the very least both good and bad (and aren't we all?) but that really doesn't matter very much when we just spent all this time watching both of them be horrible. I know that's life, that's real, that's people, and blah bl-blah bl-blah, but that's little consolation when I've just spent two-plus hours of my life being not at all compelled by a bunch of people being awful. Being awful convincingly, to the actors' respective credits, but in this setting that is not my idea of a good time at the movies.
My disdain for Scarlett Johansson’s acting wasn’t enough to make me dislike this movie.
Some of Johansson and Driver's best work in years; this emotional tale of a stressful and expensive divorce has the audience empathizing with both sides.
Great acting, really sad, super boring!
Adam Driver and Scarlett Johanson are brilliant. This film is a work of art. Laura Dern also makes a powerful performance.
Derivative and boring.

really didn't care for the movie at all. Scarlett Johansson's character is not presented consistently. First she is a loving wife and mother then sells her son's life short for her own ambition and vanity

Wow, extremely well done this film. The performances of Johansson and Driver were really the highlights that carried the thing, but the writing was real and the conflict visceral. Be warned- it's really depressing and it'll put you off of having kids, that's for sure.  But in the end it's a beautiful portrait of messy human emotions.

This movie is amazing! The cinematography was fantastic, and the same goes for the score. The acting was phenomenal, Scarlet Johansson and Adam Driver both did incredible in their roles, and I felt like it was a good chance to express all their acting skill. As a child of divorce, it was incredibly moving to see what divorce looks like from the inside. It was surreal for me to see it so organic. I highly recommend to anyone and it's overall an amazing movie.
Marriage Story almost (if not fully) represents what a divorce is. as me, I totally relate to their kid. one of the best movies I've seen in 2019. I highly recommend it.

Very impactful film. A few instances that felt out of place in the film, but overall it was very well executed with the story and acting. 
Rating: 4/5
A modern day’s Kramer Vs Kramer, except ScarJo isn’t Meryl Streep and AD is no way near Dustin Hoffman. Story is underwhelming to say the least. Don’t get all the raves about this movie.

An "everyday tragedy" highlighting how a divorce can turn nasty so seemlessly and suddenly that even the audience hardly notices the increase of horror until the emotional climax, Marriage Story is a powerful and magnificently-acted look into an extremely real and common collapse of family life, that any viewer who hasn't witnessed such a tragedy will walk away feeling as though they have.

This was my favourite movie of the year. Marriage story was a pleasant suprise. Every element of this movie was incredible. The two main characters, especially Charlie, played by Adam driver were absolutely outstanding. Scarlett Johansson also put up one of the best performances of her life. The cinematography was superb, the acting and script felt real and emotional, and the ending felt satisfying. Incredible job by everyone involved in this project!
This was fine, I enjoyed it, but I really can't see what all the excitement is about. It's a good script with convincing performances, but it's still got the feel of a made for TV 1970s drama.
Excellently told story, and Adam Driver's performance is particularly stunning.
The movie was uncomfortable to watch, which I think is the point.

Marriage Story is a very engaging look at a divorce in today’s day and age. It captures the emotional and financial struggles of a couple that is deciding to split up. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are excellent leads and make the character struggles very real. I thought they could have made the character direction a bit clearer and the two obviously cared for one another...so that was a bit confusing. But it was top notch and definitely one of the better movies of the year!

A very raw, real, and personal feeling story of a marriage crumbling by infidelity and unappreciation. I felt why Driver's character felt betrayed, why Johansson's character felt justified but never completely ruthless. Both leads are extremely human, which is what a film like this, obviously goes for. What a roller coaster of emotions this was. Divorce truly can bring out the best of intentions(for yourself and your children), but the worst in us.
Masterpiece. 10/10 performances. 10/10 direction. 10/10 storytelling.

Adam Driver deserves the nod for this one and "Marriage Story" is another prime example that those who decide who gets an Oscar are not always thinking straight. That's not all what this film accomplishes though ... The lovable Scarlet Johanssen I managed to hate and love as I mentally and vocally reprimanded the couple throughout the duration of the film. "Marriage Story" is an excellent lesson on how not to fall in love with people in the same line of work as you while depicting the griminess of the family legal system as well as the stuffiness of how those types of court battles can leave a person feeling. As I watched the movie I became stressed and belaugared like I was actually in Driver's seat.
 And speaking of Driver's seat, that Invisible Man scene was poetic on so many levels in regards to how father's are treated in patriarchal society. The whole of "Marriage Story" provides great commentary on that as well as marriage as an institution and how the inherent selfishness of humanity ultimately can make such an institution dysfunctional , yet in an odd way by the end of the film, still function on some level.
 As a male viewer, I empathised with Driver's pain and selfishly deluded ways throughout the whole film. "Marriage Story" is as effective as a condom for viewers in my demographic when looking at Driver's characters situation and the lengths he goes just to spend time with his son on the surface, but truly gain a sense of control over what he built and now calls his "life", that he so desperately wants to live and share with those around him as he so eloquently belts out in tenor at a club towards the end of the film.
 "Marriage Story" is a tale of letting go, listening, and honesty and the lengths we as humans will go to keep others around ourselves just to make ourself feel better irregardless of the feelings of the other. "Marriage Story" is what happens when introspection, existentialism, neediness, and slavery walk into a bar and have a loud conversation.
It was such a great movie, the photography loved it, they had great actors or they made each actor show the best of them, Adam is such a great actor, save this, he is Oscar material.

Many people like me, who went through the pain that only death or divorce gives to us, will understand this movie and will see it over and over and over....
After it ended all I could do is sob. Although the ending is beautiful, it made me feel so distressed. It is a wonderfully made movie. I am not sure everybody should see it  though and, I understand why people who did not go through a divorce, find it boring.  Having said that, I highly recommend it! It is a diamond in the rough.

One of the best films you will see that deal with real life struggles/triumphs. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson carry the movie with their believable and extraordinary performances. I admire the structure as the audience will get an insight to each of their characters, which will add to the overall story. At times the slow pacing may result in the film not being for everyone. However Marriage Story still stands high with the best of the best this year.
A remarkable movie! The story is very engaging and the performances are strong, especially by the two leads.
Touching and compelling

Evaluating this movie fairly is difficult for me, because my experience with divorce was much, much uglier than what was depicted in the film (which was already quite ugly). I never felt particularly emotional as I watched it, possibly because my own past was preventing me from doing so.

That being said, I can not deny that Marriage Story is a true achievement of film making. The courage and self-reflection that Baumbach displayed by telling us the story of his own divorce is remarkable and commendable. Perhaps this is most prevalent in the exquisite screenplay. From the opening scene through the final moments, every line of dialogue feels so cleverly written, yet also completely genuine, as if they are real conversations one might overhear at a coffee shop. The predicaments that the characters find themselves in are heart wrenching, or can become so with a single line that hits the viewer straight in the heart. It tells the story in satisfying ways when needed, and uncomfortable ways when necessary, and these moments transition seamlessly.

The exceptional script would be a waste without an all-star cast, and this movie had talent to spare. The cast is led by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson in the lead roles. The chemistry (and intentional lack thereof) between the two is among the strongest and most genuine I have ever seen. Driver excels in his role by bringing realism and likability to a character which the script sometimes depicts as selfish and cold. The audience is convinced that this is an authentic, loving father who struggles to adapt when his world turns upside down. Johansson is excellent as the mother; She delivers as the strong, caring mother when with her son, but below the surface, plays the part of a talented artist being trapped and held back, desperate to "find a piece of earth that's hers". 

The ensemble deserves much praise, but the standout is Laura Dern, playing the part of Johannson's divorce attorney. Dern puts on a clinic in "tactics", an acting term referring to the methods characters use to get what they want out of others. The way she manipulates her clients is subtle enough to be mistaken as friendliness, but strong enough to be effective. 

On a technical level, the film's technique is misleadingly simple and plain. The editing, production design, and cinematography don't draw any attention to themselves, but dance together to create a seamless flow to the narrative. Much acclaim goes to Randy Newman's score, which is the lifeblood of several key scenes. 

As mentioned, my biggest disappointment in the film was that i wasn't brought anywhere near to tears, though I wanted to be. I suppose that this can be chalked up to my personal horrid experience with divorce. Even though it didn't strike many chords with me, I appreciate the craftsmanship that went into it and look forward to future works by this director.

7/10.

I love how the film focuses on the broken relationship between Black Widow and Kylo Ren's character and focuses on how they take care of their child. The Cinematography IS STUNNING and the atmosphere makes you feel relatable if you're in that type of situation. Very nice feature.

Very real-life.  Doesn't pull any punches about the pain and complexity of divorce, but never tries for cheap, sentiment.  Surprising camera work - the camera remains still in many of the shots so it never upstages the acting.

I've never felt emotion for a movie a deeply as in marriage story. The story had such an authentic feeling. I got angry, became despaired and cried more than once because the actors create such immersive characters, so much so that I felt I was in that story too.
The evolution of the story and emotions are truly felt. Both sides are deeply analyzed and the acting is unparalleled. It is a truly beautiful story.
Although it never feels like more than a small-screen endeavor, the performances are excellent.
Very good story and well acted.

One of the best movies I have ever seen. I don't think I have ever sobbed or been as touched emotionally as I had with this movie. The opening scenes were done so well that it just setup everything so perfectly for the rest of the movie.
Scarlett Johansson gives the best perfomance of the season, holy god, Adam Driver is the name of this decade, i'm sure he will be floating in the oscars every single year.

No one can hate you as strongly as someone who loves you deeply. A grown-up Baumbach gives us a Kramer vs Kramer for the 21st century, his personal best film, & the best of the 2019. Everything about it is perfection. Driver & Johansson are heartbreaking & phenomenal, though with writing this perfect, it'd be hard to imagine anyone really screwing it up. It's a perfect mixture of real & beautifully heightened, quintessential Baumbach. "I'll never stop loving him, even if it doesn't make sense anymore."
Fantastic acting, no cheesy endings or scenes.

I usually cry easily, but didn't shed a tear in this film.  What can I say - for some reason, this film just left me cold; I just didn't get it.

This film is really good. I like the way Noah shows about the relationship of Charlie and Nicole. I feel how they're feel cause the performance of Adam and Scarlett is very good. They did it well. I'm so lucky that have seen this film.

By far one of the best movies of 2019. Truly an excellent take on such a prevalent story. I mean divorce is such a commonality nowadays and yet those who have never been through it have no idea how bad it can truly get and why it can take such a toll on your life, especially when kids are involved. This tells the story of a relatively average couple who even though they still have love for each other they just don't know how they can stay together and stay themselves. The acting amazing. The direction makes the experience feel even more reapl and when they argue the tension radiates off the screen as if you are in the room with them. Absolutely excellent, no complaints.
An amazing film. I was skeptical going in, but I ended up loving it!

Marriage Story is packed with incredible performances. Both Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson deserve serious consideration for academy awards, the acting in this film is some of the best I have seen in a long time. I found Marriage Story to be more emotionally impactful than I had expected and I found myself very emotionally connected with the story's characters by the end of the movie. The movie can be somewhat slow at times but it always picks up after too long. I think the majority of people will enjoy this movie and if nothing else will appreciate the talent on display from the film's cast.

Colorless tale of divorce nothing to do with marriage.  Change the name.  Badly told by two actors who just didn't seem to get it that this was not going to end well.  Depressing tale and a total waste of a couple of hours.  Slow, dragged out story about what happens in everyday life, marriage, boredom, troubles, fight, badly fight then exit from each others lives leaving carnage along the way.  Depressing wish I had stayed home.

'Marriage Story' is written and directed by Noah Baumbach, depicting the divorce of Charlie and Nicole, and showing the inhumane nature of the judiciary system and how it affects their relationship. This film is well written by Baumbach, with the opening scene taking the audience on an unexpected turn, which keeps us on edge for the rest of the film. In his writing and directing Baumbach shows us the hostile nature of the corporate lawyer's world and the toxic effect it has on Charlie and Nicole's relationship, although they are getting divorced, they are by no means on bad terms. Comedy is also excellently weaved into the movie, and not shot or acted in a way that make it over the top. In Charlie and Nicole's argument scene, some lines didn't feel like they suited the character and situation, which in turn lead to overacting, and one character was dull, for comedic effect, however was so overly dull you couldn't buy into it. The cinematography in this film, done by Robbie Ryan and the editing, done by Jennifer Lame, place a lot of focus on shots of only one actor, which does a great job at showing the characters emotions and bringing the intensity to a scene, however, at times it can become a headache for the audience, cutting to and fro from Charlie and Nicole, where a different shot used could still encapture the same intensity and atmosphere to the scene. This film was excellently acted, with Scarlett Johansson (Nicole) and Adam Driver (Charlie) both playing their roles excellently well, with as mentioned before only one moment in the film being slightly overacted. The acting means we never take one side throughout the film as we empathise with both characters which creates a moral dilemma to those audience as to who to agree with and who not, which brilliantly points out that just because two people are divorcing, it isn't necessarily one person's fault. Overall, this film is well worth watching, a really well directed and acted drama with moments of comedy, with the whole film showcasing perfectly the unnecessary wedge being driven between these characters because of how society perceives divorce should happen.

What can I say? Just... Wow... That is as real as cinema gets.

Okay first off, I started watching it without knowing anything about the characters, the setting or any other detail. I hadn't even seen the trailer for it. So when I understood both of them, Johansson and Driver respectively, were a stage actor and a director I was a little bit let down because I thought this was a more "down to earth" kind of a story and not one of the high life of New York and LA. I was surprised that this factor did not affect the story that much or almost at all.

So in some short words - the movie is at times lighthearted but is mostly one really riveting and heart wrenching story from start to finish. It starts off pretty light with some warm and even funny moments but when it actually gets going stuff goes down so hard you cannot control yourself and start feeling empathetic towards both the characters no matter who you have chosen to side with for the time being. 

The whole direction, the writing, the actors' work makes it so easy for you to feel the same amount of pain as the person you are seeing onscreen. The movie is truly that powerful. By the time you are done with the movie you will be left with this bittersweet taste in your mouth and the feeling that you went through this whole family ordeal yourself. 

But the thing is that only mentioning Driver's and Johansson's performances dos not simply cut it, it does not give them enough credit. I can see that I have seen them in different roles here and there but together in this is something else entirely. This might be just a bit of an overstatement but for me both of those great actors give a career best performance.

So in other and a bit simpler words, that's what I think makes the movie one of a kind - a story and a premise so simple and yet one that makes you feel as if you were the person in front of the camera. Just a bit funny and filled with all these bittersweet moments that we all know so well from our own lives, the movie is the most "real" flick I have seen in recent memory.
It wasn't a total tearjerker but made me cry for a bit twice. I really enjoyed the acting and the truthfulness of it. Well-made. Can be one of my favorite romantic dramas.
Very good performances by the lead actors. I found it a little slow at times but overall a well done movie.

It was like watching a year 2000 version of Kramer vs Kramer except the characters did nothing for me whatsoever. I didn't feel much emotion from the story and certainly didn't see anything worthy of an award.

Modern day Kramer v. Kramer.  Very well written and incredibly acted.  It will break you a little bit as you blame, empathize, and ultimately root for this couple and their child.  Driver and Johanson are amazing with Laura Dern, Ray Liotta, and Alan Alda turning in strong performances as well.  Multi layered characters in a really simple straight forward marriage story.
I think this shows the reality of what truly happens sometimes.  I had a lot of different feelings and emotions coming up while watching this.
Every scene was too drawn out. I was so frustrated with both of the main characters and honestly wasn't rooting for either of them by the end. Unimpressed and the story line was not great
really well done, moves along.  great cast.

Powerful and brilliant performances by Johannson and Driver! Great supporting cast rounds out, at times, awkward and difficult moments of tension that is intelligently acted out. Although the scenarios may not connect with many, the emotion is real...
Adam Driver continues to deliver. He can carry a film with his offbeat charm like few can. I definitely won't watch this again, but it was very good for a once-off drama.
Driver and Johansson deliver exceptional performances. The story is deep and feels very real. Netflix is figuring out this movie thing (finally)

Absolutely gut wrenching but sadly very accurate portrayal of a ‘civilised' divorce. Johannsen is superb but it is Adam Driver's performance that absolutely broke me. What a portrayal. That song.... Brilliant
Marriage Story??? More like Divorce Story!  The acting is tremendous however, which is the only thing that makes it watchable.  Despite the excellent acting, this was a waste of 2 hours for me...
Excelente los actores, se siente real.
Hard going good acting the only saving grace
Incredible emotional! Both actors were tremendous.
The acting was excellent, but I couldn't enjoy people being pulled apart even further by lawyers who wouldn't listen to their client's wishes...

Awful. Loved Adam Drivers acting but the plot is frustrating. Vindictive woman gets own way at the expense of husband and child's best interests. Not a good message. It comes across as a therapy exercise of a man who has been taken to the cleaners. The situation regarding money and lawyers not realistic for normal people only for rich Hollywood types.  Self indulgent nonsense. Think the critics have completely misread the films intention.
a wonderful, raw, passionate exploration of two lovers who no longer are.
This movie was so incredibly awful it prompted me to legitimately create a rotten tomatoes account to leave this review

If you want to watch 2 privileged first worlders waste their child's college fund on a disgusting divorce that honestly was based on the dumbest of reasons then this is for you. Basically the mother (Scarlett Jo) ends up having a mid life crises and lies to her husband , kid naps and disrupts her child's life to bring him to LA so she could live out a selfish fantasy instead of being a good mother and sacrificing  her needs for a sense of stability and normalcy  in her kids life. The poor dad gets railroaded (as usual) while the mother acted like she was not going to make a big deal out of the divorce. Overall it was just cringe, and showed how little upper middle class Hollywood types fight for their marriages. It now makes sense why so many ppl in LA have multiple marriages. There was some good acting, but overall it was bland , bounced around genres and you didn't know if it was a comedy or drama.... I'm surprised how this is getting so much attention. But then again most critics can relate to the selfishness and insanity that is  "A Marriage Story".

The film has the incredible ability to make you feel the same way as the characters, and as the time goes by, our feelings towards the whole story evolves, just like the characters'. It's a simple, yet real and honest story with fantastic performances and dialogues. Fantastic script!

Do you want to feel sad for absolutely no reason? Then this is a must see. Do you want to get 100 minutes into the movie to have it crumble into nonsense? This movie is for you! 
I wouldn't recommend anyone watch this film. Would watch cats twice in a row before watching this again
Incrível! O ponto forte da história é que ñ romantizam absolutamente nada! É a verdade nua e crua de um relacionamento desgastado. E, sinceramente... ñ dá para escolher a quem defender🤷‍♀️
Great movie about the wonderful struggle of a divorce when a child is involved. Scarlet and Adam are fantastic.
The guy from all of those bad Star Wars movies makes a roma-drama, and it's very good.
Strong , heartfelt drama with incredible performances

I was very disappointed by this film. First of all it was there was to much dialog. They could hav chopped about a half hour of talking out it would have been much better. There are scenes that go on and on with just talking that are way to long. Secondly there is a major tonal issue. The movie jumps between very serious and Rom-com. Which got really annoying. The scenes with the lawyers , while very funny took away from the serious nature of the film. Lastly, I could not understand why this couple was getting a divorce. They clearly loved each other but their issue were so minor. I was left scratching my head as to why they were not together anymore. I didn't make any sense to me. Also why did Laura Dern win a golden globe for this? A huge letdown. I just don't get this one.
El guion es precioso, buenas actuaciones! Realmente recomendada
Riveting !! I couldn’t keep my eyes off the screen as the acting , screenplay , and plot was unbelievably compelling !
