Boring, and a great sleep aid. Cannot believe this won anything on the Globe Awards. Too bad Netflix doesn't allow reviews anymore. Do have to say the acting was great, it's just the dialogue and plot is simply stupid.

I literally made a profile to make a point of noting how absolutely toxic and off-putting/how "West Coast way of life" this movie was. I understood the dichotomy of East vs West and all that, but this glorification of ill-advised marriages ruining kids' lives trash was damn near insufferable and frankly a trainwreck to watch. Scream fighting is bad on screen. If anything, this flick was a call to would-be parents to be less selfish/horrific potential parents.
Moving and powerful, driven by strong and painfully real performances, Marriage Story is a beautiful, honest, and well rounded look at its subject matter.
A great, realistic take on marriage and divorce with an outstanding cast
A must see!  Excellent screenplay.  Exceptional acting.
Fantastic. What a performance from both Adam Driver and Scarlet Johanson. Amazing dialogue. Amazing directing. Good concept, excellent execution.

Netfilx brings a new story to our screens in the shape of Marriage Story. This film depicts a husband (Adam Driver) and wife (Scarlett Johansson) going through a divorce whilst trying to keep their family intact. Noah Baumbach follows both characters equally across the film with neither coming across as an antagonist nor protagonist. Noah Baumbach's talent as a director as well as Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson's incredible acting ability created one of the best argument scenes in cinema history, the 4 minutes long take showing the decline of Adam Driver's characters showed pure emotion and almost heartbreak towards the audience. The overall cinematography was near flawless with nothing eccentric but was still able to keep the audience interested. Overall, I thought this film was full of emotion and passion from both actors who gave out some of their best performances to date.

It presents a real and profound analysis on marriage separation, divorce and lawyers' lack of empathy, exquisite dialogues, fine camerawork, perfect pace and mesmerizing, ever-engaging performances from Adam Driver, Scarlett Johansson and Laura Dern. For these reasons and more, "Marriage Story" ranks very high among similarly-themed films and also as one of the best films of 2019.
Good acting by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson but a rather boring movie. Seemed a lot longer than 2 hours 15 minutes
Bittersweet account of a marriage break down.  Superb acting from the main protagonists, including the boy child.

First, kill all the lawyers. Next, I'll discuss Marriage Story, a film that gripped me from start to finish with incredible acting and camerawork, which made the 136 minute run time fly-by. Nicole's (Scarlett Johansson) monologue in her lawyer's (Laura Dern) office was beautiful acting, only beaten out by the couple's argument in Charlie's (Adam Driver) apartment. I love that Charlie went back to his first attorney, Jay (Ray Liotta), when he decided to neglect Bert's (Alan Alda's) advice to his detriment. The courtroom scene showcases the hyper-combative nature of Family Court that too many experience in their lifetime. Lastly, the court-appointed evaluator (Martha Kelly) is electric (probably not the best adjective) with her awkwardness. Marriage Story is a film that doesn't offer anything new in terms of plot, but is so well-acted and engaging that anything less than a (90) wouldn't do it justice.

A well acted and mostly well written film with some problems and it’s a bit overrated. What’s Baumbach’s point? Worth seeing for ScarJo’s and Driver’s great performances. But when we see the mediocre and eternally struggling life Charlie has in NY, we spend two hours hating him for needing so long to make the obvious fix to save his family. This marriage story was too rigged in Nicole’s favor.
Artistically speaking it was brilliant. Writing was fantastic. Acting amazing. But the romantic in me wanted them to fall back in love!
Story, C Acting B+ Directing C- never quite develops into a motion picture. Has the feel of a made-for-tv movie which it is
Laura Dern the true Star of the film. It's a Nice half comedy half drama.

I enjoyed Marriage Story – it's performances, it's melancholy nature, it's expose of the inhumane system of U.S. divorce law – the first time I watched it. However, I think I only really appreciated it at second watching. That's when you notice the subtleties you miss the first-time round, the glances, the sighs and twitches, which uncover a whole layer of subtlety to the story of this fading marriage. While originally I thought the way the collapse of the relationship was presented was a bit exaggerated and unrealistic, this feeling was gone at second go, when the realisation of how important the small things can be really sunk in.

So amazingly real and refreshing on what many divorced couples go through today. It is deeply insightful, and while not action-packed, keeps the viewer engaged in the storyline the entire length of the movie. Even people who aren't going through a divorce or aren't married can still relate to the emotions and shifts in relationship dynamics; that makes it a universally appealing movie. The acting is superb; a wonderful, heart-wrenching performance by both leads, especially Adam Driver, who displayed a wide range of emotion and gave a truly legendary performance. This is my favorite movie, and probably will be for a long time.

The film conveys a sense of unruly genuineness that is perfectly represented by two monumental performances by Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver. The direction is excellent and gives a sense of theatricality suited to the central theme of the film. Very well-kept sound compartment. For sure one of the best films of 2019.

Where do I start? 

Driver and Johansson were both phenomenal, you really felt what they were feeling.

Noah Baumbach wrote an amazing script where we got an inside look into a very toxic and destructive nature of divorce. 

We didn't see biases toward either side. We saw both sides employ lawyers that wanted to fight dirty and smear the other sides client. We saw the heartbreak affect not just Charlie and Nicole but those around them be that family or co-workers. 

We didn't make it to the end rooting for one and wishing the worst for the other. Instead, we reach the end of Marriage Story rooting for both Charlie and Nicole to find happiness.

I personally loved every second of this film and I think you will too.

It is quite good, also sad and dark in a fragile way, it has sincerity to it that would make it easy to connect to.
too much fuss about Adam driver, he was good, a little too much, but that is it.
too much drama about everything, it is a very good movie for some introverted sad time and easy to recommend, certainly not the greatest of all time or anything!

This movie, man... I never log in into anything, no matter how interesting an article may seem, I'm not keen on giving away my information. But I finished watching this movie, proceeded to googling it (or DuckDuckGoing it) and here I am. Everyone should see this movie, everyone. It's so uncomfortably real, the performances are unbelievable. I've never seen anything so close to real life on a screen, it just blew my mind.

There were times when I had to pause because the scenes and the emotions were too heavy for me. I pressed play again, several times, because it was worth it. This is the Kramer Vs. Kramer of our time and my praise is with Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson for portraying such real, flawed, and incredibly adoring characters.
It's frustrating, heart-wrenching and there's not much entertainment involved. Everything you would expect a divorce to be.
Slow moving and rather boring.
Totally pointless, it's a really boring divorce  case, doesn't have a lesson to learn or message, complete shit show.
Marriage Story feels deeply personal and does an amazing job of showing both sides of a divorce.

When I say that Marriage Story (dir. Noah Baumbach) made me feel things, I mean it. To be fair, it was 4 am and I wasn't feeling the best mentally when I watched it, but still. As a sucker for just about any rom-com, I was cautious of this film simply because I knew it wasn't going to have a happily-ever-after at the end. In spite of that,  I reccomend this particular movie to anyone who needs a good cry or a good think. I stayed up for at least an hour after finishing the movie, just replaying each of the scenes in my head, examining everything, from the physical take to the stunning dialogue between the characters. I think that's what so excellent about this movie; there aren't any "throw-away" scenes. Every scene in the movie must be there or it wouldn't tell the same story. Adam Driver talked about this phenomenon in an interview he did on a press tour for the release of Marriage Story. He said that every scene in this movie required his utmost focus and care when performing and he couldn't "space out" on any of them or the movie wouldn't be complete. I believe it. This film is rife with metaphor, subtle and not too subtle with the perfect blend of joyous and heart-wrenching moments.

Mad props to Adam Driver and ScarJo for their acting in this film (I personally think it's their best work thus far); their on-screen chemistry sold audiences on their deep love and respect for the other, despite their failing marriage. The very nature of the characters in Marriage Story, Charlie and Nicole (director and actress respectively), lend themselves perfectly to Driver and Johansson because of their careers and the industry they belong to: Hollywood. Their careers end up as the ultimate downfall of their relationship, shedding some light on why so many Hollywood marriages seem to end just about as quickly as they started. If I had to choose a favorite scene from the entire film as a whole without spoiling, it would have to be the opening scenes. The beginning scenes for each character (Charlie and Nicole) parallel each other elegantly, while setting up the story that will soon follow. The voice over is reminiscent of 80's teen dramas and I adore it. The cinematography alone will amaze you not to mention the moods that Baumbach can create with just a lingering shot. The emotions you feel will run the gamut of second-hand embarrassment to straight-up rage, all developed through those elements of film. It's a cinematic masterpiece. 

All I can say after this ENTIRE rant about how much I love this movie is please watch it. I couldn't ask for anything more than to give this amazing film 136 minutes of your life. You won't regret it.
The story of a marriage falling apart and finding sense in all of it. Great Story telling with Driver and Johansson making me feel like I was going through it as well.

the drama, the emotions i got it all. intimate and very layered acting from both adam driver and scarlet. the final argue scene is super emotional and true. tho at the end i was not moved - i felt like all the emotions just passed around me.

This movie was very weak. The acting was okay, there was zero plot, I don't watch a lot of movies because most of them are terrible, scripted series TV is where the best acting/writing is today. I kept shaking my head trying figure out if the movie would go anywhere and it didn't. When Adam Driver does the song at the bar at the end I burst out laughing the whole thing was so absurd. Don't bother. Nothing about it was interesting.

Marriage Story is a personal and beautiful look into the modern world of divorce. Baumbach has made this relatable, warm and heart-wrenching, all at the same time. It's a story we never wanted to end.
A story that makes you feel for both sides of the argument, makes you choose who you want to come out on top with gripping acting and amazing directing. My movie of the year.
Such an interesting story and fantastic performances. You can't take your eyes off of Adam Driver.

After hearing all of the buzz surrounding this movie and seeing it has so many talented people in the cast from an also talented filmmaker, I knew I had to check this out. Now that I've wiped my tears away, it's time to discuss Marriage Story.  This is the story of a married couple that is going through a divorce, but not wanting to put the stress on their young son, they try to stick together as a family while going through a long legal process to finalize their divorce. 
This film was about as perfect as you can get when it comes to telling this type of story, and it's packed with two of the best performances I have ever seen. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are the best they have ever been and have my votes in the upcoming Oscars for best actor and actress respectively. The only one that can rival Driver is Phoenix which I probably will still ever so slightly side with. Having witness my parents go through a divorce, this movie effected me personally on a deep level. By far the biggest strength of this film is in the screenplay and story, how it's not about the arguing, but how it just destroys a family. Mentally, financially, and in other ways its hard to explain. There were a couple of moments in this film where I was just losing it with tears and again that lies in the performances. They are pitch perfect. THE argument scene was some of the best acting I've ever witnessed in my life. Hearing these characters pour out this heartbreaking dialogue just killed me in a way. The music was so simple and so sad at the same time. I cannot stress enough how much I was impressed by the acting in this movie it's truly mesmerizing. So many extremely long takes of dialogue and the dialogue is not only heartbreaking to listen to, seeing these actors not break character while delivering them is the best part. The ending of this film took me back to the beginning of it and had a big what if scenario in my head. That perhaps was the most heartbreaking part about it, and that goes with the writing and the screenplay. So many people have Netflix today and they better not pass on this one. I really can't find a single flaw with this movie, I honestly can't. This movie took me on an emotional journey I won't soon forget, and Marriage Story ABSOLUTELY gets an A+
Adam Driver is a gem.
The movie is cliched. From the typical self absorbed egotistical lawyers to the messed up marriage partners. Painful to watch. Cannot believe this is up for any awards. Awful!!
It was good acting however it was just too long, people arguing or singing. I would not recommend.
Words can't describe this film at all. It would only dumb down the experience. Art is very abstract and surreal that must only be experienced firsthand, which is what this film succeeds in.
Absolutely terrible. I don't understand the hype

I didn't think I was going to like this movie based on the title -- but it's exceeded expectation. The ending is a solid finish and showcases Adam Driver's acting. The support cast (the girl from Nurse Jackie & Alan Alda) are equally solid!

Adam Driver and Laura Dern were great in their roles.  His pain (as a person getting divorced) and her joy (at being an attorney) played well against each other.  Overall this movie made me sad because it never felt like this couple ever really liked each other - it felt like a relationship of convenience.  The most memorable line was “you should be worried that I laughed with her.”  Can’t remember if I’ve ever watched a movie that made me feel that being married is definitely NOT for me, until this one.
A perfect film and a must watch.
Adam Driver should get an Oscar nomination if not win it.
While I appreciated a lot of the directorial and editing choices, I wouldn't rush to see it again.
Great acting! Great story! Great theater!
Amazing! Adam Driver is outstanding in this movie. A pivotal scene in the film is so raw and emotional it's truly heartbreaking. Would highly recommend watching.

Never reviewed a film before but this film is absolutely perfect. The person I was watching it with half way through said ‘when's it going to start'

I just saw this movie, and right now, I think it is absolutely a very good film. Adam Driver and Scarlet Johanssen (Not sure if I spelled that right) are absolutely fantastic in this. Not only that, but the movie looks great and isn't too long or too short. The story itself not only taught me a lot of things I didn't know about divorce, but it gave me a deeply personal look into what it's like. The characters in this movie didn't seem like characters, but real people that we were watching the lives of. Everything about the story to the conversations between characters was deeply human and can connect with just about anyone, even if you've never been through a divorce. It made me cry at least twice, and I came close to crying a whole lot. The only few issues I have with it is that the score doesn't really suit my tastes. I don't know what it is, I just don't feel like it suits the movie, and maybe it could've had a better impact with a better score. And despite the amazing performances, there were a few lines in the movie that made me remember I was watching a movie, they felt a bit forced, but I was pulled right back in after a few hiccups. It's really great overall, I'd definitely recommend it.
As a child of divorced parents, I felt the story was emotionally deep, well written, and relatable to what I had experienced.

I'm finally getting caught up with the highly rated flicks of 2019 and this is another best of the bunch. Noah Baumbach's heartbreaking, genuine and unique examination of a normal couple going through divorce is without a doubt one of the best films I've ever seen. Scarlett Johansson delivering her second amazing performance of the year and the oddly  sexy and powerful Adam Driver delivers a career high performance as her husband. Theres also a fine cast of supporting performances from Laura Dern and Ray Liotta amongst others. It's a truly powerful and realistic examination of the material that's explored in such a way that it resonates with you long after it's over from the powerful arguments to the subtle touches. But it's not all sad, it's joyous, heartwrenching and supremely engaging. I found myself absolutely captivated and honestly i didn't want it to end. I felt like I knew these people and I wanted to know what would happen in their future.

Great fantastic phenomenal movie. For most of the movie it didn’t feel like a movie. It felt like real life and I really got behind both Adam drivers character and Scarlett Johanssons character. I thought it was real but then when I saw the credits roll I remembered and I was in awe. This is a beautifully sad but happy movie all in one. It’s a dose of real life and many people won’t like that because it’s too real. I liked it because I believed that it was real and that they were actual people and that they were family. This is by far the saddest movie of 2019 hands down. Both performances are stunning and deserve Oscar nominations possibly wins.
Realistic story of a family going through divorce. Heart wrenchingly sad at times. Incredible acting.

It feels true, probably because it is inspired  by some autobiographical material, and it feels fair to both sides of a divorce, or at least it suggests a real effort to be fair, by a wounded man.  The beginning and ending are both moving and excellent. The middle plot is dominated by the intervention of the lawyers. which adds the extra dimension needed for the film to be more than simply the story of a personal tragedy, to become a timely social critique.  I certainly learnt something.  Both Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver are at their best, despite a certain lack of personal chemistry, which in the context, oddly, helps. Their big cathartic row feels a bit too theatrical, though. By contrast, the scene when she gives him notice of the divorce proceedings is pure genius.
A good film but not a great one.  Feels long.  Driver's performance is better than SJ's.   Covers the turmoil of divorce competently.  Doesn't break any new ground, nonetheless, still worth watching.

An extraordinary, beautiful, depressing, and fulfilling movie by Noah Baumbach. This view into a divorce of a marriage that felt real and felt believable, a divorce not stemming from abuse or absence but from a loss of purpose. The two actors Adam Driver and Scarlett Johnson are absolutely phenomenal and give you a sense that you are going through this time with them. Their relationship is maintained and feels consistent throughout the film although the obvious tearing of the marriage that binds them. Through the film you learn the hardships of the relationship from both sides the mental toll from the marriage and from the split, the moments where both people messed up and where they succeeded. Comedy plays an important role within the movie not only so the movie doesn't drag your emotions too deep but to show how both characters use it as a median to the bad and good. It proves that a sense of humor is human and a path to get through what you may not think you can. The movie does a wonderful job at providing everything you need to see clearly that neither party is the fault of the marriage but the marriage itself. Both Nichole and Charlie are great parents to their kid Henry and share a love for him that is the same love they have for each other, which plays into the story beautifully. The movie starts and ends with the same thing which is positive and very touching. Both Charlie and Nichole are seen pushed to their breaking point, both cracking open and bouncing back within the film making you feel for them as if they are real. Although I do not have any direct view into the world of a divorce it teaches you how horrible it is but how peaceful it can be afterwards. The ending is redeeming and shows how a divorce can better a relationship rather than destroy it. Wonderful movie, absolutely one of Netflix's best so far and justifies itself for many awards.

I didn't believe for a minute that they had ever really been in love.  Where was the love, the romance, the passion?  Oh yeah, there was that one passionate moment where they got into a fight...but they apologized to each other right away.  Their attorney's felt like the comic relief because they were both overblown to almost being cliched cartoon characters.  Who was that lady that came to visit Adam Driver's apartment?  That was the worst acting job I have ever seen, by anyone, ever.  The two "musical" numbers should have been cut because they were truly awful.  This movie missed the mark on so many things.  Everything seemed so superficial and the dialogue was overwritten.  This could have been a great movie if it had been told from "truth" instead of from a "they were just so darn nice to each other" place.  This movie shouldn't have been called "Marriage Story" because it didn't really show us anything real about their marriage.  It should have been called "A Pretty Nice and Civil Divorce Story Between Friends".   I did think that Adam Driver's acting was excellent and so was Alan Alda's.  I just think the writing needed a lot of work to make it a more intense and believable story.  I don't know, I may watch it again and give it another chance as sometimes I like movies better the second time around.
Bittersweet like life itself. Nothing is painted black and white.

The movie is touching in so many ways. The audience can feel the characters emotions and understand them, even if the audience has never experience a divorce before. It is an absolute must-see. Driver and Johansson are amazing and deserve all the praise and recognition!
One of the best movies of the year. It makes you think about your past, present and future relationships. Sad yet hopeful. Amazing.

I rate this film at five stars without any reservations whatsoever. I watched Marriage Story the first time out of boredom but quickly realized it deserved my full attention. A couple days later I revisited the movie again with others who were watching with fresh eyes. It was even more stimulating to watch the second time and I was impressed by the amount of foreshadowing  included in the dialogue and early scenes. This is a relatable movie particularly for more recent generations of viewers who are likely to be able to project their own experiences of  divorce, separations, being the subject of split custody as children, etc. onto the main plot line. Scarlett Johansson fully embodies a character more complex than she's often been given in the past and Adam Driver proves he has what it takes to be a "leading man" in a dramatic film. Written with sufficient witty humor to make the more emotionally visceral scenes palatable without being overwhelming.
Not a tearjerker but still a sad deep story. Definitely worth watching.

Amé este guion Noah Baumbach se esmero en esta oportunidad. Toda la fortaleza de esta película están puestas ahí, junto con una maravillosa actuación de Scarlett Johansson y Adam Driver.
Driver puts in a career defining performance.

Marriage Story was definitely the best movie I've watched over the past year. I've never got married, had a kid, or divorced. But after watching this movie, it makes me feel like I have gone through the entire struggling, painful process. There are no dramas throughout the movie, rather, all the stories sounds real, normal and could happen to any married couple that are trying to get divorced.
Time is always cruel and powerful: It can set apart a couple, who used to love each other deeply and exclusively, and now make them fight against each other, (with the help of each's lawyer) , for money, assets and custody of children. All these changes don't take too long — just in few years. 
In the movie, Charlie (the husband) and Nicole ( the wife) had a very intensive fight for over 15 minutes, I was impressed by how angry, unsatisfied, nagging they were. Those negative emotion, that had been suppressed and controlled for years had finally exploded and became devastating. They used the most harsh words to hurt each other. The husband even said he wanted the wife to die. Not surprisingly, they finally divorced. But I was very sad about the ending of the story. They could have had a happy family, watching their kid grow up together, but they terminated it because of disputes on chores and small things in lives. Had they communicated their negative emotion timely and thoroughly whenever the issue arose, and weren't leave it accumulated, a divorce can be avoided.
But it was too late to say this. Nicole had already started her new life in LA with her boyfriend. A divorce was already a divorce, nothing can get back. 
What I've learned is: life won't give you a chance to regret, and move backward. A broken heart will never be healed completely. You have to move on to embrace your new life, And let the past be an unforgettable memory. 
I highly recommend this movie, because it gives you a good chance to rethink about marriage, life and divorce.
Awesome. It's weird that a realistic depiction of divorce can be so amazing.
Adam Driver and Scarlett's performances alone are enough reason to watch this movie. Very effective writing that pulls you in and makes you feel as though you're in these characters shoes.
Boring. Plain. Movie doesn’t deserve a Oscar
Contrived. What could have been an honest look into the transformation of a marriage views more like an autopsy.
:( I thought it was weird. Am I the only one?

Review:
‘Marriage Story' is a comedy-drama film directed by Noah Baumbach.
This movie was in contention of being my favorite of the year. ‘Joker' just slightly edged it's way to be my number one.
The film follows a married couple (Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver) going through a coast-to-coast divorce.
Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson hit it out of the park with these incredible performances. They're great throughout the whole film, but there is a certain scene in this movie that everybody will talk about and it floored me. They way they act towards each other, they have great chemistry. Laura Dern also did a great job, playing a slimeball lawyer who keeps taking Johansson's character into things she doesn't want to do.
The real hero of this story however is Noah Baumbach, who also wrote the film and deserves all the praise. He is a true master in writing and directing. He makes all of it seem effortless, with unprecedented results. He could truly be one of the last true story tellers working today.
Overall, the movie to me is basically flawless. It makes you laugh; it makes you cry; it even makes you feel things you can't identify. It's a heartbreaking story about how two people can love each other, but still know they aren't good for each other.
5/5
Scarlet Johansson's role was mean and too empowered at the end when she is nominated for an Emmy out of nothing...
The acting was great but the story was hackneyed.

An updated "Kramer vs. Kramer" (1979), Noah Baumbach's divorce drama "Marriage Story" is already engendering backlash for being a drama about well-off white people bickering. It's more than that. It's a beautifully written and observed piece about what brings us together, and what remains when our bond grows brittle and shatters. Baumbach's script is a revelation (and a likely Oscar nominee or winner), but so are the powerful performances by Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver, both at their best, whose characters we alternately root for or despise as if we are breaking up with each of them ourselves. That fight scene! That show tune scene! Laura Dern and Alan Alda make the most of well-crafted parts as lawyers, one a shark (Dern, uncomfortably close to her work on "Big Little Lies" from 2017-present) and one a confoundingly laissez-faire pushover (Alda) ... or is that wisdom? Do not sleep on the work by Julie Hagerty as a mom who refuses to choose sides and Ray Liotta as a counselor who swims in the same school as Dern's character. If the mounting backlash to the film doesn't damage it, it could sweep the major categories at the Oscars in February. P.S. If you missed Baumbach's "The Meyerowitz Stories" (2017), as I did until recently ... it's even better.

Marriage Story is a perfect combination of great writing and great acting. When you write great characters it allows the actors to excell and make the movie that much better. This is the case with Marriage Story. There are so many scenes that will stick with you. This film isn't great because of one scene but many. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson both deserve all the recognition they are getting. This is one of the best film's of 2019.
Laura Dern and Adam Driver continue to impress with their acting range but the writing just fell flat.

This incredibly-acted movie follows the difficult divorce of a stage director and his actor wife, for whom doing everything they can do to stay together as a family with their son is simply not enough. The movie does not make a villain of any of the main characters, but makes us feel for both of them in equal manner. It is very compassionate and the genuineness of the relationship and everything around it makes it so enthralling. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson kill it with their challenging performances and only the argument scene is enough to give them their deserved nominations. Also, what a score, Randy Newman! Good luck at the awards season!

"Story of a Marriage" is a difficult film to evaluate, since its core is to talk about the end of a marriage, the American-directed feature Noah Baumbarch is good but it didn't touch me, his sentimentality is strong, especially in the third act, but it is a contextual film, people who have experienced the same trauma will identify more and feel their pain, feeling and anguish at the top of their skin, which I was unable to feel.

As the name suggests, "Story of a Marriage" deals with the breakup of a relationship of an established couple and a child, the long brush outlines the reasons for the breakup but focuses on showing the consequences of a breakup, his drama sometimes escalating. too much, and its hatred and ramifications are strange in the very sense established and created by the film, but as already had, its conclusion is beautiful and poetic, a charming third act that concludes and circumvents its errors very effectively.

The direction is simple but has an exquisite use of the camera and framing, always highlighting the distance of the couple and opening up to monologues and views, which are always filled with great performances, the whole cast is fine, Adam Drive and Scarlett Johansson has phenomenal chemistry, and both actors are great in their roles.

"Marriage Story" is a good movie, it deserves and will take some Oscar nominations, but again, it's a very contextual movie that needs a previous viewer experience, those who don't have that traumatic experience, will see the qualities of the movie but will not feel all your sentimentality. NOTE 7/10
One of the most boring movies I have viewed

This movie was super cute, but I felt like it was a bit overrated.  The acting from Johansson and Driver was fantastic, with both of them elevating their games to new, emotional heights.  I was quite impressed, because I've been mostly bored with SJ's career ever since Lost In Translation.  I'd recommend this if you are considering not signing a prenup.
Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson put on an impressive performance with riveting acting. 10/10 would recommend!
Slow boring cinematic torture. Maybe if you have kids or are a child of divorce you'll like it.
One of the best movies of the year. Heart wrenching to watch.
This is a love story shown, from it's end, it will make you question about the relationship that you are in, don't read the reviews,  go and warch it.

This movie did not go at all the way I was expecting. That's neither a good or bad thing. Both Scarlet Johannsen and Adam Driver are excellent in the film. I would not be shocked if either got award nominations. If I had to choose one, it would be Adam Driver who is pretty much great in everything and quickly becoming one of the best actors working today, if he isn't already. I know the direct is also getting awards buzz, and deservedly so. 

As someone who's married with kids, some of the scenes hit home for you and in some respects things you hope you never have to experience. The story does a great job of relating to married people, or even unmarried people with kids, and showing how it can go so wrong so fast in the blink of an eye. It really makes you think. 

There's only two small nitpicks I had with the movie: 1) it's a tad long, maybe 10 minutes or so and 2) I couldn't quite tell if it's set in present time or not. Some of the clothing maybe question whether it was. What year it is has no bearing on the story though, just something I noticed.

I was surprised That this movie was as good as it was. The acting was fantastic. The film shows both sides of a divorce which is a breath of fresh air. You really begin to care about the two characters and want things to turn out well for both of them. This is one of the best films I have seen in 2019.

What a true endurance test. It's well-acted, especially by Adam Driver, but every single aspect of the story and its characters is utterly detestable. To accompany its insufferably neurotic coastal elite couple and their apparently intellectually compromised son, this film includes moronic musical numbers guaranteed to leave viewers wishing they'd just heard fingernails down a chalkboard instead. There are far better ways to spend your time and abilities to see and/or hear than on this cringeworthy schlock. I'm only giving it 1.5 stars because Driver and Johansson really do a fantastic job of transforming themselves into two giant jerks.

I think this movie might be brilliant for people that have gone through a divorce with a child custody battle in it. I have only gone through a divorce, no kids, and cannot understand why this movie is so highly rated! I could not relate to the characters at all, I mean zip, zero, non whatsoever. There was no personal connection to either of the main characters built up in the first 30 minutes of the movie, and after that I just did not care. The dialogue was incredibly stupid on occasion, like for example there's a pecan-pie scene in the movie, which some critiques are saying is the "best scene in the movie". What the hell? Are you deaf AND blind? It was so awkwardly written and played out that I could believe listening to that ridiculousness! Is the dialogue meant for idiots? It's so slow and unnatural, that it's difficult to think that this movie is meant for intelligent adults. But hey, whatever rocks your boat, opinions are like...well you know.

For anyone who has gone through a divorce, or has witnessed the pain of suing for custody, this film is a moment of deja vu. Marriage Story captures the pain of dividing and transplanting a family as well as the redemption and clarity found in establishing individual identities and desires. While Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson's characters are really the optimal parents for a child (kind, playful, engaged and involved), the story isn't saccharine or trite. It reminds us what it is to be cast in the most negative light - to be seen at our worst- and then reminds us of the importance of love and why love, even waning love, is never futile. Experiences, even negative ones, can teach us lessons about who we are and what is important.

If I had any complaint about this film, it would be its chosen scope. While the emotion and arc of the story is universal, it would be nice to see a movie stripped of the privilege of wealth. These are two people who can afford costly lawyers and transcontinental flights every few weeks. The writers and producers lost the opportunity to show how divorce affects those who don't have the money and social standing these characters enjoy. The average salary in the United States is $47,000. It would be interesting for the writers to create a film with the same emotions while the divorcing couple figure out how to live separately within those financial constraints. I guarantee the "do it yourself" divorce would be given more consideration.

Just watch this movie! Great story, lots of depth. Pleasantly shot. Very mature look at a divorce. As the movie ended I found myself sad I did not have more than the 2 hours 15 minutes spent with the characters. Emotionally riveting.
It totally worked for me. Combination of great actors and subject that is very important yet not so much touched these days.
Smoothly directed, going through everything that want to express, Marriage Story is raw and realistic in its subject. Thanks Johansson and Driver, made me believe in everything they delivered.
Really great. The acting was superb.

Different from other movies where you see couples meeting each other and marrying, on this one, it represents a realistic but yet not boring story of a divorce. You get involved with the characters in such a way that you want them to stay together.
Real, and has all of the feels. Good stuff.

For a movie that could maybe be criticized as slow-moving, I found myself surprisingly engrossed in all 2 hours and 15 minutes. It's not particularly earth-shattering (and predictable at times), but it is well-acted and intimate.

Even in it's ugliest, most raw moments...the characters make us love them each and want both sides to win and in the end...well, you'll have to watch. It does not disappoint, as much as real life sometimes does, which makes it an excellent reality-like drama with just a dash of excellent comedy.

I'm a little surprised by this one.  With all the praise flying around about this movie, I thought it would be better.  Not that it's bad; it's definitely a good movie.  I just expected to be blown away, and was not.  It's just not as powerful or as emotionally devastating as I was led to believe.  It's a poignant, true-to-life drama about two utterly believable (if not so sympathetic) characters that more than a fair share of the population will relate to, whether they are willing to admit it or not.  But it did not affect me in the way some other movies with similar subjects have.  A more apt title for this film would have been "Divorce Story" – it's more about the grueling legal process of a contentious divorce and custody battle than the marriage that led up to it.  It's often uncomfortable to watch; the emotion it evokes is anger more than empathy, watching what that process can do to two otherwise reasonable people that care about each other.  The movie does a good job of showing both characters' viewpoints and bringing you along on their journeys, so you feel like you are going through it all with them.  Both characters are flawed and are hard to root for, but that was the intent – marriage is messy and divorce is a goddamn disaster, even for the best of people.  The film just didn't make me care much for either of them until I was pretty deep into it, when all the tension that has been subtly building over the course of the film comes to a head in one explosive scene (if you've seen the film, you know the scene I mean… it's a gutter, and Driver and Johannson could not have been more convincing together).  This film is what you call an "actor's film" – it's focused on character and heavy on dialogue, (plus some whopper monologues), to the point where it often feels like you're watching a play.  It has all the makings of an Oscar winner:  a celebrated auteur writer/director in Noah Baumbach, two stellar actors at the top of their game, and a resonant drama at its core.  It's the kind of movie that Academy voters eat up with a spoon and it's a shoo-in for Best Picture, Best Actor/Actress, and Best Director nominations, plus a writing nomination thrown in for good measure. The only question is whether or not its affiliation with Netflix will kill its chances for the big prize come Oscar night.
If I could give it 6 stars I would. Adam Driver was amazing. Scarlett Johansson so good too. Heart breaking.
This movie was the most pretentious film I've ever seen. It was like an acting class exercise. Everyone is doing their best to get an award
Adam driver and Scarlet are both absolutely unbelievable.
Just i have some words for describe this movie...beautiful, human and breakheart.

Director Noah Baumbach triumphs again with another most humanistic storytelling that draws out the best, ultimately resulting in electrifyingly emotional performances, excellent handling in the starring topic without animosity, and lovely composed score. (A)
Incredible movie! The acting is superb and the situation presented feels very real. Each character arc is great and you really do feel empathy for all involved. Must see, 10/10.
Nobody really wins in a divorce. This movie gives bite size glimpses of that. Sobering and, at times, laugh out loud funny.
Genuine, authentic look at how the break up of a family works. Sweet, heartbreaking and funny.
Love the acting. Fantastic story.

Is it possible to simultaneously dislike and really like a film? Because that's how I felt about Marriage Story. The dialogue was so well written, and the performances were so realistic that I felt uncomfortable watching the story unfold. It was as if I were intruding on some strangers' very personal experiences. And yet this movie also features warm humor and a positive message. I hope to never experience the pain of divorce, but I'm glad I was able to experience Marriage Story.
Marriage Story is a truly compelling hard look at divorce that will leave you wrecked.
Certainly not an uplifting movie...but the acting is superb and there are lessons to be learned here.
Heart-wrenching, hilarious, and incredibly authentic. Bravo!
Depressing, bummer of a movie. My parents went through a long, contentious divorce and watching this was misery even though I like the actors.

A great movie that had me whipping back and forth in my allegiance to both main characters. It is difficult not to cringe at outside people and forces try to tear down a relationship, but impossible to look away from Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson when they are on the screen. Fantastic!

Marriage Story is so powerful and real in its presentation of a divorce that I almost hated it. I am not a big fan of movies that focus on couples bickering a lot, because I generally seek escapism in film, and don’t want to spend my time watching relationships fall apart. However, I simply couldn’t bring myself to hate this movie because it is perfectly acted, has moments of levity among the sorrow, and feels so genuinely heart-wrenching in how far the relationship has fallen. We can see, as their divorce draws closer, they still retain some faint echoes of the love they once felt for each other. I’m fairly confident that Noah Baumbach must have written this based on personal experience, because it is too authentic to be entirely fabricated out of nowhere (and at times the film seems to cast the wife in a more negative light than the husband.) Scarlett Johansson brings her A game here, and it’s hard to deny her talent. Yet it’s Adam Driver who impressed me even more, because he delivers a truly astounding performance loaded with nuance and emotion. There are some scenes in Marriage Story where so much is communicated by Driver with only looks and body language. You can feel the hurt hiding behind a casual conversation, and when it explodes, the vitriol is truly shocking. There is no denying that, for those who like a realistic relationship drama, Marriage Story might be one of the best films in years. However, while I tip my hat to the quality of the film (and commend them for making the movie that Blue Valentine wishes it could have been) it’s still a style of story that is a tough sell for me. I appreciate that it exists, but I never want to watch it again.
Wonderful acting and great drama without the usual, unrealistic Hollywood romance helps MARRIAGE STORY overcome its occasional slow or cheesy moments.
Very realistic...  terriffic acting!
Well acted but that doesn't necessarily translate into a rewarding or enjoyable watch.

Un guión que te lleva por la historia de una forma muy limpia, aunque llega a ser un poco lenta a veces, genera una inmersión en la historia increíble, sintiendo paso a paso la evolución en los personajes.
Actuaciones brillantes y escenas que te quedan en la retina por horas.
Pero sobre la inmersión, algunos volúmenes de efectos de sonido mal ajustados te sacan de esa dinámica y te devuelven al cine, sillón o donde sea que estés. Detalles.

Noah Baumbach does it again, even better. Some films inspire me to continue putting energy into developing scripts. This films relaxes me, gives me peace to know such a film exist to give others solace in whatever fucked up, confusing family shit that may be putting them on the edge. I could die content knowing I made art for others to receive sanity. Now I could die content knowing even if I don't, this film exist to mediate haha.

4/5.  Great writing, clean cinematography, and good acting all around.  The lead male actor steals the show but that is mostly because the character he plays is more likeable then the female lead.  I would have gave it 5 out of 5 if it was more balanced. It is intense at parts, so watch it alone. Netflix took a big swing and knocked it out of the park.
Some of best performances I've ever seen. Made me very uncomfortable, exactly in the way the film intended.

I'd love a tv series of this where we can get more time with the characters and genuinely feel and live with the family on a standard pace compared to the quick boiling point where they kitchen sink is thrown at us and we just get a few hours of a personal relatable story
Too slow! Not my cup of tea
What a stressful damn time. Beautiful and heartbreaking

It´s a great movie. It shows how adults struggle when they go through this process. It shows both perspectives about the situation, how they feel about each other when they are or are not together. This movie shows how fragile people can be when they are hurt and how reckless they can be when they are angry.
Intense, great acting, not the end I was expecting yet it is truly how conflictive marriages ends up.
Being a child of divorce, this movie really hit home with me. Adam Driver and Scar Jo were both incredible. The best thing about the film is how human it really is.
Scarlet was absolutely fantastic, her best role in life. So was Adam (but is more her movie then him apparently). It Was a little boring in the beginning, but it is a nice movie
Fresh movie! Loved every moment! Great acting, great story, and a movie that I can recommend

Marriage Story is supported by Oscar-Worthy performances from Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver. Marriage Story shows the horror of going through a divorce by telling a very real and emotional story. One of the best movies of the year!
I don't get what all the huff is about. I mean sure great acting by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson but yeah idk...

If there was ever a movie to make me never want to get married because of the ugliness of divorce this is it. Marriage Story should really have been titled Divorce Story because we follow couple Charlie (Adam Driver) a theater director, and Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) an actress, who are getting a divorce. They have agreed to not use lawyers and to settle this just between themselves. They have a son named Henry (Azhy Robertson), so of course that complicates matters. Nicole lands a pilot in Los Angeles, so she decides to take Henry and move in with her mom temporarily. While in Los Angeles someone tell she should get a lawyer for the divorce, so that she doesn't get screwed over. Nicole hires Nora Fanshaw (Laura Dern) who specializes in divorce. Suddenly, Charlie is thrown into this and has to scramble to get his own lawyer. The rest of the film portrays the hard decisions of divorce and how two people that still may love each other slowly start to unravel and change. It's some pretty deep stuff here and I would say it's a great movie, but not a film I'd watch more than once because of the somewhat depressing subject matter. The two leads performances in Driver and Johansson are great here. They have some scenes together that are so realistic that it's hard to believe this was all scripted. You feel for both of their sides and I personally couldn't side with either or during it all. It's a heartbreaking film and I have my own opinions of the ending and what could be happening here, but I won't spoil it all. This is an incredibly well acted movie, but also not exactly pick me up kind of film. Definitely, recommend checking it out though on Netflix!
Interesting but very little action and disappointing ending.
The movie shows how suprisingly good both the actors of Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson and how they can portray such deep and complex roles. The movie is a must see
Felt very real, brilliantly acted and emotional.

Structured beautifully, Noah Baumbach has finally created a masterpiece despite it being an excruciatingly tough watch.  Hubby and wife viewed this and hubby loved it while wife liked it.  Brilliantly cast and framed, 'Marriage Story' rings true.  In a film about big things the small things aren't glossed over.  This should be seen  If you need to hit the pause button go ahead. If it hits too close to home it will be cathartic.  If you don't like this film you probably don't like movies.  Wife summed things up thusly:  " It was a difficult movie to watch which perhaps has confused me into not believing what a good film this was. I can't find fault in it, but maybe because it was so emotionally close to home for me, I could appreciate the superiority of the reality of the story. Adam Driver and Scarlett Jo gave convincing performances that felt far too familiar. A coworker warned me that it would be a difficult movie to view and not to watch it. Maybe it wasn't the worst idea to sit down and give it a chance after all because now that I have sat with it, I've grown in appreciation for the performance, score and attention to detail."  Frankly this movie stays with you long after you have digested it.  It makes you uncomfortable and your rooting interest may change mid-swing.  It's one of the best films of 2019 (no matter what wife says!  Wife: 8.4/Hubby: 9.8 Average Score: 9.1/10

Marriage Story is a movie that will touch many people around the world. People who have been through difficult separation situations will be very moved by this story. It's an emotional movie, with excellent performances by Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver, (both are at their best work in their careers), they deserve an Oscar nomination. Noah Baumbach's direction is quite simple, but at the same time manages to entertain the viewer with the story being told. The cinematography is interesting, the editing work is decent and the soundtrack is very well mounted to the progress of the film. Laura Dern's performance can also be cited, a very good performance and full of emotion, she deserves an Oscar nomination for best supporting actress. Marriage Story has long scenes that further demonstrate the brilliance of the editing and script, which is very well written. In addition, the movie has memorable performances and unforgettable moments, is a great movie.
Good movie, a little depressing in some parts but overall awesome
La película es un poco lenta pero la calidad de los personajes y la actuación excepcional de Driver y Johansonn hace que no te quieras perder un instante.

I really wish I could give this movie more stars.  It was executed perfectly.  The character development was flawless.  The acting was impeccable.   The directing, editing, and execution were all on point.  On top of that, the movie was quite relatable.   With divorce plaguing 50% of couples, the movie really captured the love, resentment, hardship, and confusion of the situation.   

The reason I just can't give this movie more stars is because it's insanely depressing.  I don't watch TV or Movies very often, so if I do spend my time watching something, I want it to be worth it.   For me, this movie was not.  The fact that it's relatable is not a compliment unfortunately.   If you wanted to talk someone out of getting married, all you would need to do is show them this movie.   I kept waiting for Charlie and Nicole to get caught in a moment of lust at least once.  I was left dissatisfied by the lack of the intimacy despite the chemistry that was built up between them.   The movie is called "Marriage Story," but it's nothing of the sort.  It starts off with Charlie and Nicole reading over a list of things they love about each other only to find out it was an assignment from their mediator.  This is not a story of Marriage.  It's a story of divorce, heartbreak, and grief.   I don't know about you, but I have enough of that in my life.  Movies are supposed to be an escape from reality, not a reminder.    When Charlie finally gets to read Nicole's list, the emotion is so real and raw, you'd think the ending would have been more satisfying, but nope...  It's just as depressing as the entire movie.   

Sorry Adam Driver...I still think you're great!

Superb acting in this film by Johansson and Driver.  In fact I never have seen Adam Driver show off his amazing acting range until I saw this. The story Itself is a clever examination of the division and transformations that many people undergo over time.  Overall a really enjoyable film for its ability to deliver a quick dose of reality.

Scarlett and Adam both deserve Oscar nominations for their powerful, poignant potrayals of a couple who love each other so much, that they can't see beyond their own foibles that are bringing down their once very happy marriage.

More optimistic than I expected. Sane people are hurt the most by a divorce system that rewards cruelty. A simple story told with passion, contempt, and love. Entertaining watch with some charming off-kilter moments and direct, painful conversations. Careful watching with significant others...

I do not get all the hype unless people want to see a Woody Allen copy with more emotion.  As a divorce/custody movie, it doesn't come close to Kramer Vs Kramer. The script, direction and performances are okay but are not award-worthy.

8 8 8 8 8 8 9 9 8 8 = 82
2019/12/15
Another great work from Noah Baumbach. Witty and touché dialogue, good frame choice on composition and great casting on actors, particularly Adam Driver. I can't help recalling his great performance in Paterson which is much better than this one. Overall, this film is not a bad continuation for director Baumbach after heart-warming Frances Ha.

Dramatically draining with an appropriate amount of humor to leaven things up. A stylish updating of the Woody Allen comedic dramas from the ‘70's and ‘80's.
Adam Driver and Laura Dern have Oscar nominations locked in, deservedly. And Scarlett Johansson may finally get her first nomination.
It's surprisingly not a depressive movie.
One of the best movies I've seen this decade and without question the greatest of the year. Adam and ScarJo are perfection. EVERYTHING in this movie is perfection.

This is the movie I expected. With incredible moments about marriage: discuss, love, hate, lawyers and return to the same routine over and over again, this film will be remembered as the best of 2019. CONCLUSION: Noah Baumbach, makes Marriage Story a fantastic, intense, excellent movie and a game change of a couple that will have to overcome the obstacles of their separation and will prove that Scarlett Johansson & Adam Driver are perfect, emotional and beautiful in their performances, while going to the Oscar as best actors and as best film.
Brilliantly written, brilliantly acted. Marriage Story is a bittersweet tale of divorce and the fallout it brings to people's lives.

One of the worst movies I have ever had to endure, every chapters was a self loathing hipster, or a self entitled yuppie, just shows how screwed up USA laws are when divorce is concerned, and how if you are a man you are totally screwed by draconian  laws, big surprise !  Even the child was totally unlikeable, and couldn't wait for this crap to end.

What a heartbreaking and yet beautiful film. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson deliver big-time, and the supporting cast of lawyers bring their A game as well. Baumbach's writing blows me away. Is it bad that I saw elements of my personal relationship throughout the plot of this entire movie? I kid, but I think any viewer will find elements of their own relationship experience portrayed either through Driver or Johansson's characters.
It tells a story that is happening all around us...how people drive away from each other.
It's impossible to stick with a characters side. The sympathy you will feel for the couple will make you want to "punch divorce in the face".
This was tender and gritty my favorite mix. Real. Penetrating portrayal of an ordinary loving couple who get lost in the maze of developing as adults
Great performances with great photography but nothing happened un the whole movie. Also excruciatingly long. It doesn't worth the time.
It's intense! And the performance by Johansson and Driver was phenomenal.

An acting master class from Johansson and Driver. It's only fault is you will be left wondering...why are they fighting over this completely unlikable child? You will also need to watch little women after to cheer yourself up. Overall though, I really enjoyed this movie

A beautiful and aching portrait of a marriage past the point of no return.  It's beautiful and painful--all the more so, because of how truthful it is.   Despite their turns in the MCU and Star Wars franchises, I think I will love Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver  in this movie over all else.  I hope they both get many accolades in the awards season, because they certainly deserve them.
Great acting, great story! This movie is really moving
Amazing performances by Driver, Johansson and Dern

Brilliant writing, acting and directing, this movie is a tour de force portrayal of the breakdown of a relationship. Not black and white but realistically nuanced to show both points of view. You cannot help but smile at times despite the seriousness of the situation ...and that's what makes it very watchable.
Wow.  How can a movie be so realistic and yet so magical?  Honestly, every minute of this movie was a treat.  Even the dark and gritty moments had reality and soul and I just...wow.

All the details of this film are spectacular. It made me laugh, it made me cry, and it impressed me with its range. I never knew I'd like it this much but there is so much to appreciate in this little unassuming package.
Adm Driver was good. All the Lawyers too.  The mom of the main woman was fun.
Career-best performances by Driver and Johansson. Baumbach makes the most compelling relationship put in to the big screen in a looot of time. Glad to see Ray Liotta rocking again too.

Beautifully shot. Adam Driver is sensational (and the only reason I was able to watch any ep of "Girls," back in the day). I would have like to see the plot of the custody battle delve a little deeper. As anyone that has ever gotten divorced with kid(s) knows it always gets to a point where it truly gets ugly, before it gets better. The ending was not only satisfying but rings pretty true to real life when experiencing divorce and co-parenting. (SPOILER: don't read if you haven't seen the movie yet.) But in the end, the courts really do go away and divorced people who no longer love each other really are stuck with each other for life when there are children involved. And I think Noah Baumbach really drives that message home. And this movie is a very gentle and beautiful way to tell people that. Some people need to hear it.
Superb acting by Adam Driver.  Very human story.  Avoided cliche ending.

I couldn't stop crying, it was beautifully written—every emotion of the story felt real. The writers really knew what was going on in a relationship. Both Scarlett and Adam were great too! I would not forget this movie in a long while, for sure.

Filled with honest and heart wrenching performances. Give Driver the Oscar now. If Rene Zwellenger didn't own "Judy", Scarlett Johansson would be joining him at the podium. Great screenplay and cinematography as well. The extended tracking scenes are wonderful and vital to the actors portrayals.
Adam driver couldn't be more magnificent. Such a raw story. Well written and the emotion pulled from each actor/actress makes the film.

This movie is the reason behind the creation of filmmaking. It is insanely intelligent, comedic, serious, involving, and emotional. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson's acting is flawless. Every scene, no matter its weight or length is done with precision, passion, and dazzling realness. The film will pull you out from where you are and bring you into the characters' world. It is what all movies should aim to be. Weather you are currently in a relationship or if you are observing that of your parents, this is a movie that will twist your stomach into knots and remind you of just how difficult it is to be human, and to balance our lives with other humans. A must watch & well needed masterpiece of 2019.
"But alone is alone, not alive". Brilliant, funny, heartbreaking and real. Driver and Johansson are pitch perfect.

A pleasant film. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansen act off of each other like they've been doing it forever, and Randy Newman's score once again proves that he can make an audience cry in a matter of seconds. However, the Company songs are just weird. They don't fit. Adam Driver can sing it very well, but why does Adam Driver sing it? The movie also seems to justify divorce in a marriage that has no problems other than personality differences and an affair. To some that may seem like the right decision, but all I saw was a broken family that would never be the same, and a kid who'd have to grow up with parents who were too arrogant to stay married. Brilliant acting, score, and filmography, wish I could say I enjoyed the story.
Noah Baumbach has created an ultra realistic depiction of divorce turmoil, highlighting the effects of it in a economic and emotional sense. Maybe a career best for the distinguished Baumbach.
2 hours of bickering. Frustrating to watch and horrible ending.
Incredible movie, I recommend it.
So wondefull and deep. This is Passion

I liked it a lot but found the recently divorced & defeated ex husband's bar song to be an inexplicable scene. If not for that bit of unnecessary weirdness I'd give it another star. I thought it was really well acted by both leads though & I loved how the woman came out ahead. I have to say that from divorces I've known personally it seems to usually work the other way around. 

Also watching this made me feel really happy I've never had to go through that - never married and never divorced. Phew.

In my opinion, the best parts about marriage story is how it begins, and how it ends. For a movie like this, it can be difficult to see where it starts, and even more difficult to see where it ends, because no matter what you probably won't have a happy ending. But Noah Baumbach does it so well, and I congratulate him for that. The performances from Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver are incredible, maybe even their best. And the script- that too is also basically perfect- every moment of the movie I felt so compelled by the characters, so enticed to keep watching more. I did wish that they would've had more 50/50 time split between the two leads. It felt like at the beginning of the movie it leaned more towards Scarlett, but for the rest of the movie you were seeing more of Driver's perspective. This worked out okay in the end, I just feel like I was being pushed to like Charlie more than Nicole. But in the end, this movie really tugs at your heartstrings in a way that feels well earned.
Oscar level performances from Johansson and Driver, a topical storyline and just beautifully shot.

This is an amazing movie that is as funny as it is heartfelt. Johansson and Driver carry this movie beyond what is already amazing material. Noah Baumbach has finally found the balance between meaningful art film and something capable of mass appeal. A must watch.
Wow, eu achei esse filme fantástico, fiquei impressionado com a atuação do Adam Driver

Anyone thinking of going through a divorce, or especially getting married, for that matter, should watch this film. An engaging and fascinating account of a contemporary divorce with all the warts and pimples, brought to life by incredible actors, Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson. The movie is not just about divorce, however. It's about the complexity of relationships, and the fact that there is no black and white. Marriage Story teaches us there is no shangri la at the end of the road, But there can always be something even better.

A tragic tale amplified by such a tour-de-force display  from Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson, Marriage Story highlights the struggles of an everyday situation and the real efforts to maintain it; leaving audiences with heavy hearts and thoughts. 4/5
Great acting! Absolute raw drama... Brought me back to the bad times in previous relationships and how awful arguments were.

I enjoyed parts of this film. I particularly thought Alan Alda was fantastic. I couldn't really relate to the characters despite having gone through a divorce and I found the big fight scene to be overacted.

Marriage story is an outragouesly over produced parade of celebrities  pretending to be mad at each other about famous people foolishness. Terribly disappointing.  And critics, what's going on with you? Did you see a different film?
A captivating and beautiful masterpiece. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson give some of the best performances of the year and of all time.
Incredibly captivating and moving. Adam Drivers acting was just.. wow.
Adam Driver and Scarlet Johansson give amazing performances. the film is both funny and sad, and overall very bittersweet. would not be surprised at all if Driver takes home the Oscar.

Undoubtedly one of top 10 movie of this year. The acting is breath taking and everything works perfectly. The real depiction of marriage is so raw and emotional. A must see movie!

I loved this. The emotions were so authentic. The characters felt real. The only thing I didn't like was the culmination of the big fight between the main characters. Falling to the ground and hugging her knees in desperation? Agony? Was way over dramatic. The way the divorce progressed from amicable to severe was believable. And the way it ended was nice too. I was worried it would end after Charlie's/Driver's song performance but it didn't. The post battle settling down was necessary to be able to walk content with a sense of resolution. Definitely worth the watch.

Felt like the whole movie was based on the scene that he screams at her in the new apartment,  that was the only time I felt emotion in the dialogue,  great actors don't have to make a good film, it was worse then average movie with some better then average parts,  very small parts, the good things I can say about it are that sometimes in the movie I felt like I was in a play rather then a movie, I hope that was intentional...

MARRIAGE STORY by Armen Pandola

Netflix's Marriage Story, written and directed by Noah Baumback (The Meyerowitz Stories) and starring Scarlett Johansson as Nicole and Adam Driver as Charlie, tells the story of the divorce of two young artists at the beginning of their careers. She is a young actress known for a topless scene in her last movie (this is according to the people in this movie) and he is an avant garde theater director and head of his own company in New York City.  When they meet by chance, they fall in love and she moves to NYC where she becomes the 'draw' for his theater company. Eventually, they have a son. At the beginning of the movie, they are getting a divorce after 10 years and are seeing a mediator in the hope of having a  friendly divorce.

Is it a spoiler to tell you that a friendly divorce is rarer than a vegetarian meal at Mar-a-Lago? I knew a couple who mediated their divorce and everything was going well until they got to the jazz album collection (this was back in the day) which they were to split evenly. He objected - she didn't know Dizzy Gillespie from Dizzy Dean when I met her. She countered - yes, he introduced me to jazz but I was the one who actually bought and cared for our collection of over a 1000 albums - if it were up to him, he'd still be using his albums as coasters at the drunken parties he and his friends threw every week. And so much for mediation.

The upshot of Marriage Story is that good people get divorced and often do terrible things, things they'd never dream of doing except for the divorce. And that's what happens to Nicole and Charlie. The contested divorce legal process is unfair and incredibly expensive. Laura Dern is Nicole's lawyer and she explains to Nicole that she cannot admit to any wrong-doing or even any flaws since our world treats women/wives/mothers so differently than men/husbands/fathers. Women/wives/mothers must be like Mary, mother of Christ and a virgin to boot. Men are like Joseph - who is absent when the going gets tough and isn't even the actual father who is away somewhere doing whatever it is that gods do.

The other side is represented by Ray Liotta who tells Charlie that he had better get ready to be demonized and pay legal bills and costs that would make a lottery winner cringe. At first, Charlie is represented by a nice lawyer played by Alan Alda who tells him, "We have to prepare to go to court hoping we don't go to court." When Charlie sees that Dern is crushing Alda at a meeting, he switches to Liotta who can talk faster and be meaner than anybody else.

Along the way, there's a custody dispute. At the very beginning of the divorce, Nicole goes to LA to do a TV pilot (her first acting job outside her husband's company in a decade)  and takes their son with her. The expectation is that she will return to NYC when the pilot is completed but then - she doesn't. Her family is in LA where she grew up and made a career as an actress. The money is exponentially better than doing theatre work. So, Charlie can only see his son by traveling cross country on weekends.  As is usual in divorces where there are children,  the child becomes the center of the divorce with each side claiming that it knows best for the child. Of course, the divorce is devastating to children, but that is a different movie and Baumbach concentrates on the adults.

It gets complicated quickly. The heart of the story is told in long takes where both Johansson and Driver communicate their rage at what is happening to them and the man/woman they loved. These longs takes show both Johansson and Driver's acting chops - each of them is able to build a scene to the point where real emotions are on display. The hateful argument  they have at the end of the divorce process is contrasted with the tender affection for both their partner's qualities and deficiencies that they talk about at the beginning of the process. In fact, it is probably true to say that if you can find a person who loves not only your wit and charm, but your surliness and bad habits, then you should chase him/her until you catch him/her because that is the person who loves you.

Two songs from Sondheim's Company are sung - "You Could Drive a Person Crazy" by Nicole and her actress mother and actress sister, played beautifully by the under-appreciated Julie Haggerty and Merritt Wever, and "Being Alive" from the same musical sung by Driver. Each song speaks to what their characters are feeling about each other. Strangely, in Company, there is even a more appropriate song they could have sung - The Little Things You Do Together:


It's the little things you share together,
Swear together,
Wear together,
That make perfect relationships.
The concerts you enjoy together,
Neighbors you annoy together,
Children you destroy together,
That keep marriage intact.

It's not talk of God and the decade ahead that
Allows you to get through the worst.
It's "I do" and "you don't" and "nobody said that"
And "who brought the subject up first?"
It's the little things,
The little things, the little things, the little things.

There is so much to recommend this movie that I hesitate to mention a few missteps. While money is mentioned, often, it isn't really talked about in substance. The fact is that many people never recover, financially, from a divorce. This is partially solved in the movie by a gift from the gods that drops in their lap during the divorce. A bigger problem is that Baumbach wants it both ways - the great angry scenes where people say things to each other that they don't mean, but once said can never be unsaid, and the happy ending. One of the best angry arguments that Nicole and Charlie have is negated by their embrace at its end. The fact is that arguments drive people further apart and don't end in an embrace but, usually, a slammed door.  There are some maudlin scenes whose purpose is to show that they have moved on with their lives and are doing fine, and still think of each other with love and affection. And a divorce that ends that way is rarer than a 2-for-1 meal at Mar-a-Lago.

This movie is great at both story-telling and realism with relationships, you really feel what they feel, and hurt when they hurt. You start to feel sad to see everything unfold, and in an amazingly realistic way. I enjoyed this movie way more than i believed i would, and oh my god, this is the type of thing that will have an effect on me later in life. The acting is superb and I cannot give enough props to Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson for their performances, which are really what give this film heart, along with the director's perfect encapsulation of their feelings through cinematography and general realism that many movies skip out on. 9.5/10

I can't believe this film has a 95%. It may as well have been a documentary about a divorce. Many scenes were drawn out, overly dramatic, painful, breaks from the tension were far too few and too short. Adam Driver was the only good thing about this film as he is always spectacular. Scarlett Johansson looked like she was crying or in the verge of tears in practically every scene. Laura Dern was shockingly terrible and overacted. I do like the way Buambach tied the ending, but really? Marriage Story? Why was this not called Divorce Story? That's exactly what it was.
A must see movie! Goes real as real can go with a great story, acting and directing. Reality bites... will make you think twice about getting married or getting a divorce lawyer.
Great movie! It's pretty much a remake of Kramer vs Kramer.
I was disappointed.  Driver is really, really good. Supporting cast esp Dern js excellent but the story really went nowhere...didn't love the script either.
Great love-drama, that missing star I didn't give, might just be the mixed feelings it leaves lingering in you, but good overall.
Except for Scarlett Johansson mind blowing performance, i did not like this movie.
Terrific acting and not bad scenario. Never bores, keeps the attention alive for a story that can easily gets dull.
The acting is amazing! Such a beautiful and painful story about marriage and divorce.

Admittedly, I only watched this movie because of my love for Adam Driver, but I was taken aback at how real this movie was. It didn't feel like I was watching a movie, it felt like I was actually watching someone's life. The scene where Driver's character breaks down...it broke me. I was a puddle on the floor. But nothing hit as hard as the part at the end where he's reading the list of all the things Johansson's character loves about him. "I'll always love him even though it doesn't make sense anymore." Driver pauses mid-sentence, his lip quivers, and just like that I'm a puddle on the floor again. Give them all the awards.
Absolutely beautiful and heart wrenching movie, the acting is incredible.
'Marriage Story' is a melancholic, heavy-hearted yet joyously bittersweet film that works excellently thanks to its zinger script and superb cast.
Led by amazing performances from Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson, "Marriage Story" is a well-crafted overall story that draws your investments from start to finish.
I cried. I felt like the whole time I was watching a real marriage fall apart and it was heart wrenching. Both Driver and Johansson deserve oscars.

This movie was depressing, boring, and not fun. I really liked Laura Dern and Ray Liotta though, especially Laura Dern, because I'd never seen her be kind of a bad guy, so to speak. Her speech about God is the best part in the movie.  I wouldn't call it a bad movie, but what's so great about it? I didn't think the two leads were really that convincing as a couple that could ever be together anyway, sorry.
