I read an article calling 2019 the year of Adam Driver, and you have to agree after seeing this.  The guy is great.  I can have a love/hate relationship with Noah Baumbach at times, but I feel like this is a great portrait of a real relationship.

MARRIAGE STORY seems personal to both characters, and yes, both sides of the story are shown in passionate detail. Emotional outbursts propel the film to a climax where someone has to give in, not to sate an ego, but for their kid's sake. It's also important to note this is a movie about a divorce and not Divorce. This is slightly hinted at in a courtroom scene, which the judge concludes by saying they have to go because there're a lot more cases to go over that day. So really, there could be 100,000 movies about divorce, and this is one. 
The film has many moments of interpersonal interaction and doesn't feel like the 2hr 30min it is. Both sides seem to have justified arguments, but one side clearly has the advantages until Laura Dern performs this great, power shot monologue. 
The most painful part is watching as they write out the checks.

i absolutely loved this movie. going into it i expected nothing from greatness, adam driver and scarlett johansson are both incredible. once you are ten minutes in, the film already allows you to feel an emotional connection to the two, getting annoyed at them and forming a love hate relationship, not knowing which side to chose. i ended the film bawling my eyes out. the plot sounds dry when just explaining it, but the amazing acting, writing and directing really gets one to keep watching and rewatch. 10/10

Marriage Story is one of the best films of the decade and one of the very best films this year. I have lots to say, so, first off, it's beautifully shot and told by Scarlett, Adam, and everyone else. Another thing that absolutely blew me away that I applauded at was the fight with so much dialogue it was unbelievable. I mean was any of that improvised? The casting is phenomenal. This is a truly well told story that teaches a lesson, divorce is terrible and Jesus is our only hope. The morals and telling of moral story might be mixed but I'm still just so proud.
Marriage Story succeeds in simulating a grounded look at a tough topic, with support from its stars and Noah Baumbach's filmmaking

Walking into this movie, you wouldn't really see it. It's a good movie with great acting from both Johansson and Driver, but then you'll think about it, you'll keep thinking... this movie doesn't try to be a drama, it doesn't try to be funny, it doesn't try to have a satisfying story or ending and it doesn't even remotely have a misleading or baity title, this movie only is a marriage story and nothing else. Just characters doing their thing so naturally, it sucks you in because it's so real, you never realize how real it is (due to acting, writing, directing, and even camerawork) until you look at it from outside. It really all just fits in, it's so emotional, not just because of the acting or writing but because Baumbach trusts you to get it, the emotion behind just singing "Being Alive" and realizing so much just from listening to himself singing. it's poetic in a way, somehow.
I'm speechless... this is astounding

The combination of the incredible acting of Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson, the painfully realistic writing, and the heart-wrenching yet cathartic storyline lands this film as an instant classic in my heart.
What a movie, I have nothing else to tell just watch it.

this film is amazing good the acting of both lead rolls are fantastic, scarllet Johansson is amazing her acting is stunning and dont forget Adam driver is top notch in this as well, a story of a Hollywood marriage that we wont expect very recommended.

It was just slow, very slow. There are some very good moments, but they are few and far between. I wouldn't recommend this movie.

Noah Baumbachs complicated story about love and divorce hits you in the emotional gut by simultaneously make you angry and compassionate for the people involved. Its a strong cast, and most of them are outstanding, but it is Driver who does drive (no pun intended) the plot to greater heights.
Adam Driver's performance is nothing short of Oscar Worthy.

Honestly, I do not understand the hype of this film. It's long, tedious, and has no point. Generally, I love Adam Driver, but he could not save this film. Scarjo is her typical narcissist self and does not redeem this film in anyway.

Driver and Johansson turn in amazing performances and really dial in to their characters. The film challenges us to reevaluate the importance we place on relationships and the casual resentment that builds to an explosion when we don't deal with it. The ugliness of divorce from the legal side to the vicious disparity of hateful words is on full display. The film is loaded with great supporting cast (Alan Alda, Ray Liotta, Laura Dern are especially memorable) and the march towards the inevitable conclusion feels both agonizing and satisfying altogether. Driver shows depth and dimension as the controlling Charlie and Johansson buble up energy and apathy as the awakened Nicole.  It's interesting to see how 2 actors who in real life portray the divorcing pair - Johansson, a very public figure on marriage #3 and Driver a very private figure still on marriage #1. At times Charlie seems shell shocked by the whole process while Nicole can transition between wresting the couple's child from her husband while at the same time lovingly cutting his hair.  The film is a great comment on moden divorce and worth a look.
All over the place! What a waste of our time watching this.
Devastatingly beautiful. Heartbreaking, raw emotion. Some of the best work by both leads. This film is fully deserving of the nominations, awards, and media.

I appreciated the strong central performances by Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver, the score, and the script that gave an even-handed treatment to both husband and wife in a divorce.  I look back and cringe at the uneven, male-centric KRAMER V KRAMER that we all thought was so good.  MARRIAGE STORY is a terrific film with strong direction and supporting cast in Laura Dern and Alan Alda.  One of the best of the year.

Wow. What a great story about relationships and the beginnings and endings of them. Marriage Story is a flawless, heartbreaking story led by two of some of the best performances of the year. Adam Driver is phenomenal. Most people know him from the new Star Wars Trilogy but people should really see some of his other films. He usually does a great job but in this film, he is 100% dedicated to the role. They are certain scenes in the film where it doesn't feel like he is acting. It feels as if he is actually this character and going through all of these troubles. He puts so much emotion into his performance that it is heartbreaking yet mesmerizing. Scarlett Johansson gives yet again another fantastic performance. While her performance isn't as mesmerizing as Driver's performance, it's still perfect. She also conveys a huge amount of emotion with her role but adds a slightly more comedic and relaxed atmosphere to Driver's serious and hardworking atmosphere. Both actors play off each other perfectly, even in scenes where their characters are fighting with each other. Every other performance in the film is pretty great, especially from Laura Dern. The script for Marriage Story is fantastic. It compliments the performances and feels very natural. It knows how much the characters need to say to get a point across or when to restrict them. The music and cinematography are great. The music is done by Randy Newman (Toy Story) and fits the depressing tone the film is going for. The film makes the good choice of not using music during certain dramatic scenes which helps make those scenes more emotional. The cinematography isn't groundbreaking by any means but there are a lot of beautiful shots. Towards the beginning of the movie, there is a 5 minute uncut shot of Scarlett Johansson talking about why she stopped being in love with Adam Driver's character and it's great. There is one sequence in the film that is perfectly shot, acted, and scripted and it's the argument scene. I felt sad and a smidge emotional for the characters throughout the film but this one scene made me feel a whole lot. It's one of the best scenes in cinema this year. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson completely disappear in this scene. It doesn't feel like acting. It feels like the filmmakers just filmed real people breaking apart. The emotion displayed in this one scene is off the charts. It cemented for me that Adam Driver is a masterclass actor that people should pay more attention to besides being known as "the guy from Star Wars". The rest of the film has its emotional moments but they don't top that scene. The film's plot is pretty straightforward but the way the characters interact makes the film feel unpredictable. Noah Baumbach used his direction to make a straightforward story feel unique. I'm going to start paying more attention to Baumbach from here on out. Overall, Marriage Story is a fantastic film about relationships and divorce with some of the best performances of the year, an outstanding screenplay, unique direction, and some great cinematography and music.
A great story about the relationship at the end of a marriage, this movie could be the best drama movie of the year.
I can't think of any director as consistently brilliant as Noah Baumbach in Mike Leigh.

A marriage story is as good as it is heart-breaking. No doubt Adam Driver is the best actor in this generation. Next to his roles from Girls to the Star Wars saga, he is a rising star who will endure not because of his physical assets but his enormous talent.

This movie will be well-known in the Awards circuit because of the exquisit direction by
Noah Baumach as well as for the brilliant performances, which besides Driver, includes Scarlett Johannson, an astonishing Laura Dern -fire on the screen- and crowns itself with a unique acting duel with Ray Liotta. 

One of those tremendous dramas, independent style -but produced by Netflix-, without grandiooquence in budget but with unique acting sequences. It will stay printed in your memory, with a hint of chest opression and a lump in your throat just because is real. No one portrait divorce like this ever before. 

I stand up.

Incredibly well acted and entertaining. Though it's subject matter is dark it pulls you into the lives of the characters.

Excelent aching and depiction of a hard reality which grows to be more and more common as time passes. Facilitates empathy for children and couples who have experienced or are experiencing a difficult situation like the one portrayed in the movie.

This movie is a masterpiece. I spent the whole thing wishing for the classic happy ending - for Charlie and Nicole to work out their issues and come back together as a happy couple - but the true ending delivers so much more in the way of a true emotional reality for many families.
I am not sure what all the rage is about this movie. It is well acted but to me it was slow and had no real point to it. It should have been called A Divorce Story instead.
This film had an outstanding performance by Adam Driver, and Scarlett Johansson, but the plot was way too simple at times, and this got me very bored.

Good acting, screenplay simple but real.

Marriage Story was heartbreaking and beautiful. It felt like the culmination of Baumbach's skill that has been building for decades. The film had all the boundary pushing complexities that I loved in Frances Ha and was as watchable and hilarious as Meyerowitz Stories. 

Baumbach's dialogue, symbology and narrative design were incredibly rich. Johansson and Driver delivered performances that had me sobbing throughout my first viewing. I saw this film through the Telluride Festival earlier this year, but I watched it again the day it came out on Netflix because I couldn't wait to see it a second time.
Could be the best film I see this year.  Really stellar acting from the leads.  A leader in the award season and a must see on the small screen Netflix or the big one.

What a great movie! Not really in to these types of movies, but the hype on "MY" social media was real about this movie. It's truly incredible. Driver nailed his role and Dern really surprised me with her role. The movie does start off a little slow, but then you eventually get in to gear with it.

Coming from someone who did enjoy the rather long winded, Irishman, this is unequivocally the best movie of the year. Seldom do I tear up during a movie, but this masterpiece was incredibly emotionally compelling. The script hits all the right notes but the real piece de resistance is the performances given by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson, both are, just... wow. An exquisite drama. Very well directed with great performances. One of the best movies of the 2019.

This is a bit of a modern-day, Kramer vs. Kramer. It's a quite realistic story about a 21st-century marriage, with a great performance by Adam Driver and Azhy Robertson. No matter what background you are from, Marriage Story and the dramatic emotions delivered by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson will succumb you into anxiety over the state of a marriage that is not even yours. A really well done look at what happens during a divorce between two people who love each other.  You care about the two main characters, and sympathize with their struggles.  This is not a feel good movie.

A amarga história dos conflitos radicais que uma separação envolve, que com o talento da direção e das atuações, acaba se transformando em uma história delicada, íntima e palpável. Os protagonistas atuam em seu máximo, mas meus parabéns fica para a atuação coadjuvante que dá ritmo à história.

Best acting I've ever seen from Adam Driver!

A well honed and admirable capturing of a marriage between two artists navigating the tumults of the personal and professional in the 21st century. Crisply written, with an emotionally bristling performance from Driver, the film delivers us inside their relationship in Baumbach-ian form. Scenes shine where actors are given the time and language to build and gather momentum -- Driver and Scarjo; Dern and Liotta. While the middle clunks along with back and forths to and from NY-LA and Driver's incessant search for a lawyer, the authentic performances and attention to detail carry the film. While the writer/director lived his research, the personal doesn't get in the way of cinematic storytelling, instead, fuels it. Much of the magic here comes through nuance -- a juxtaposition of frames, a silent act of generosity, even a look. With dashes of much needed comedy, Marriage Story avoids the trappings of melodrama and sentimentality and is the kind of small intimate story we rarely get these days -- too often passed over by producers and audiences alike. Without a "happy ending" or a winning party, much less a clear battle between good and evil, instead, Marriage Story is a cross section of 2 lives, and a worthy contribution to the cinematic relationship canon.

Director Noah Baumbach reminds be a bit of John Cassavetes, that was a master of portraying everyday human dramas. But, while the acting is exceptional,  I can't say I was emotionally moved by the movie.

Also, there is a scene that was unnecessary: Adam Driver, singing in a bar; we figured out that Driver is one of best actor of his generation.  Let another movie show that the guy can also sing ;)

This film surprised me in that I never thought a movie involving both Kylo Ren (Adam Driver) and Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) would be as powerful as this was. Both performances were very impactful and are both Oscar-worthy performances, combined with great story telling and a very well done plot, Marriage Story gives us an insight in the process of divorce and how it affects not only the husband and wife, but also the kids.

Touching, comic and devastating. The simple script turns into a work of deep emotional appeal in the hands of Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver, who deliver remarkable and true performances. The work often moves between humorous and dramatic tones, while it is filled with a comforting and convenient photograph with the space in which the work is located. Incredible work by the director and absurd performance of the actors.
The fantastic direction, beautiful screenplay, and outstanding performances are what made this one of the best films of this year.
Painfully slow, do I really need to witness a child walking to the fridge, opening it and pouring some juice in all its detail? It was just a divorce story, not even a rocky one.
A near perfect movie and an incredibly visceral look into a very realistic relationship.  Driver should win an Oscar.

Adam Driver is an amazing actor. And never have I ever doubted Scarlett Johansson.
This movie is not for everyone, but it has something for everyone who is or was in relationship. It has shown how two people can find a way to be with each other and then can find a way to not be with each other, but still be with them. 
The true essence of love is not to be with the other and suffocate them, but to find a way to be for them. Also how marriage makes people change their priorities and how sometime we do not see when we are hurting the one we care the most about.
Overall it's a plain simple story that is worth watching.

terrific acting is the real star here especially from Driver who gives his best to date!

9.25/10. Performances of heart-breaking sincerity and depth meet a screenplay that explores the pain and cruelty that divorce can cause those sharing broken love to inflict on one another. It's searing honesty will resonate with anyone who has been in, been the child of, or has seen a loved one experience the suffering of a failed marriage. Directed with clear vision and emotional nuance, never making villains of either parent - both are flawed, but equally devastated by a tortuous marathon neither would wish on the other. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are award worthy in the roles of failed lovers who have no interest in hurting each other, while the supporting cast are stellar as they manipulate the two into becoming enemies. A painful, affecting experience with the power to simultaneously open wounds and prove that healing those wounds is possible.
Adam driver...enough said

A film that portrays raw emotions of how hard a divorce can truly be. Adam Driver amazed me yet again with performance. The same with Scar Jo! Both of them deserve Oscars for their beautiful portrayals.

While I understand the accolades it is receiving, I just don't want to watch rich people get divorced for two hours. Superbly acted, written and directed, but not my cup of (bitter, I'll always love you but actually I kind of hate you) tea.
Two and a half hours of watching someone else's therapy session.  It was painful.

It’s like when you start eating an apple and you bite your tongue, a little bitter sweet. It’s too much like a real persons life albeit in America, with the outrageous Hollywood style courts, not enough ups and downs to be rated this highly, like a puff of smoke, some parts are good, but it’s a very long good in terms of running time. I wouldn’t watch again, but I did like parts of it.

A bit inauthentic. It was a good attempt to show the male side of divorce and manipulation and exploitation around divorce. However it felt in parts things escalated for escalation reasons that were contradictory to the characters nature's. It was nice to see an alternative to Adam Drivers usual roles. The better is the movie, the more difficult is to review it, because at the end is all about the feelings that stirs up in you. "Marriage Story" is a great movie, one of the best in 2019, so just take this emotional roller coaster and stop reading reviews.

This movie was just so emotionally devastating and beautiful at the same time.
Just awesome. The move feels as though I'm watching real life. So many small aspects make it all so real.

Excellent - some of the most realistic acting I have a ever seen.

This is a true cinematic masterpiece. The shear brilliance of director Baumbach's portrayal of his own written works is something to behold. The build-up of intimacy and use of levity is operatic in its nature and pierces right through to the core.
 
The performances by Johansson and Driver are extraordinary. They have fully ingrained themselves into the character, tackling heart wrenching monologues and silent scenes with the same perfection.
 
This film delivers a timeless story of relationships. It truly is exquisitely made and heart breaking-ly touching. A very special film, Netflix are showing they can make some truly special cinema. They can expect some Oscar Nominations.

I was hating it while I was loving it. I hated it because I felt everything, things that I don't want to feel.  I saw the details, I knew what they meant. It reached my bones. It reached my heart. The story could have taken turns at so many points. So many actions taken slightly differently could have completely flipped the story, but it reflected life...little actions lead to big changes, or they don't. I was waiting and wishing it to be a movie but it ended up being real.

I'm not a fan of bicker fests. A movie about divorce is guaranteed to have a ton of idiotic bickering. Interestingly, this one doesn't have it in excess. It actually has a lot less bickering than most crumbling family movies. Still though, it wasn't all that interesting of a movie to me. It was an illustration on the nature of back stabbery in the legal profession for sure. But overall it was a tale that's either all too relatable or not at all. For me, and maybe I'm the lucky outlier on this one, but I was not in the group who can relate. Well done. Good acting. Just not that interesting. I have no idea who to suggest this movie to. Not sure if people who have dealt with divorce really want to see a movie reminding them of the hellish experience. For those who haven't, you probably don't want to think about this kind of nightmare. Who is left and what would the message be? Anyhow... Going to say no to this one.

Marriage Story is a perfect combination of great writing and great acting. When you write great characters it allows the actors to excell and make the movie that much better. This is the case with Marriage Story. There are so many scenes that will stick with you. This film isn't great because of one scene but many. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson both deserve all the recognition they are getting. This is one of the best film's of 2019.
This has wonderful performances. Adam Driver is, as always great. This is bleak though. Your relationship is on the outs, I might be watching something else.

The acting is amazing, especially Adam Driver's performance. But that seemed to be the only point of the movie... to showcase some amazing acting. Otherwise, it is kind of exhausting. I guess it serves as a cautionary tale in that we learn that divorce stinks and (most) divorce lawyers are jerks... but we knew that.

I watched this movie with my wife and we kept waiting for it to pick up. We truly wanted to love it, but the plot was a train wreck from the start. The acting in the movie was great across the board, but the story simply lacked substance.

Small films are (in my opinion) where Scarlett Johansson really excels, and boy did she ever in this film. She and Adam Driver did not hold back in this heartbreaking view of a marriage falling apart.

In many ways, Marriage Story was exactly what I expected from the premise, and the little press I had read before its release. However, there were treasures hidden among the tropes we've come to associate with divorce stories played on film, mainly those of the supporting cast. Though, for as great as some of the supporting performances  were, the leads must be complimented. They supported each other well alone, allowing emotional subtlety to grow into awkward or uncomfortable moments — most of which did not necessarily feel forced nor manipulative. It isn't a film for everyone, and I can't say that I will ever watch it again personally, but I did not feel, at any time, as though my time was wasted.
Such a great movie! Definitely a must see

A film with an absolutely intriguing exposition & complex characters that unfortunately fails to deliver in the end. While our two protagonists seemed interesting in the beginning, the plot devolved from a tragic romance to a dry & probably too-realistic legal battle that just seemed dry and uninspired, except for a few notable scenes towards the end.  The complexity of the main characters waned as the movie progressed. Johannson & Driver's performances however are flawless & to me it is truly a shame that this film couldn't stick the landing. Worth the watch.

Its as good as the critics say it is -- but one gets the sense that the critics either enjoy. or aspire to, the privilege of rich white people whose biggest concerns during a divorce are whether to get a second apartment in West Hollywood or Silver Lake.     Its already been done, repeatedly, by Woody Allen -- and a dozen other "rich white people get divorced" films, and nominations abound because everyone in Hollywood identifies with (or aspires to) rich white people with personal problems.
Excellent, brilliant, dazzling performance from Scarlett Johansson. A story of marriage and divorce breaking through all possible conflicts. A story of love, deception...and love after all again.
Very well done, superbly acted. I tough watch but worth it.

Love hurts.  So do lawyer fees.  Marriage Story writes a clear and compassionate thank you letter to the loss inside deep love.  Sharply written and observed as acted.  Accessible as indie gets.  *See also: Kramer vs Kramer, Annie Hall, When Harry Met Sally

At times this movie was painful to watch; the description of the legal process tracked a little too close to home. From your (ex) partner telling you different things than they're telling their attorney, to the attorneys taking extreme positions to maximize billing through the protracted meeting of the minds, to the emotional cost, the financial cost...the portrayal of the system is accurate, insightful, and visceral. 

Almost everyone becomes rewarded for selfishness. Attorneys get to bill more at ungodly rates for very basic work, and the parties are rewarded for only thinking of themselves in a zero sum game. Who loses? Well, everyone...but that loss becomes part of the process as well. The mental anguish becomes a sacrifice for the attorney fees/increased time, couples look back with bitterness, and children suffer from the cross fire. 

I'm not sure if it was therapeutic to see it's not just me, and to have something I could relate to so deeply...but this should definitely be seen as a very accurate warning sign for couples separating. I suspect that it was exorcism of a few demons for the writer/director as well. 

The acting is uniformly excellent, and it was especially nice seeing Allan Alda as the voice of reason that is completely useless in a process of the damned. 

On the negative side, the film's last half hour dragged, and it could have used heavy editing. I was ready for the fifth act at the end of the third act.
The best realist romantic drama of the year, Adam driver real theatre background come to the cinema and it perform as one of his best film so far

Marriage Story Review:

Marriage Story is written and directed by Noah Baumbach and stars Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver as a couple going through a divorce.  This divorce pushes them to their limits and changes them, but while this is affecting them they're also trying to provide a happy environment for their son.  In about August, this became my most anticipated film of the year.  I just love Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver proved to be great with his Oscar nomination for BlacKkKlansman.  Also I discovered Noah Baumbach last year with his film While We're Young which I think is very underrated.  He's had a few Oscar nominations and is just a great screenwriter and director.  Before Marriage Story my favorite of his was the slice of life Frances Ha.  This film affected me on so many levels emotionally.  I don't know how one could possibly watch this without shedding at least one tear.  It's so incredibly real and it's just amazing how it all played out.  Scarlett Johansson has her best performance once again.  I feel like every time she's in a film she just gets better and better.  Marriage Story is written and directed by Noah Baumbach and stars Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver as a couple going through a divorce.  This divorce pushes them to their limits and changes them, but while this is affecting them they're also trying to provide a happy environment for their son.  In about August, this became my most anticipated film of the year.  I just love Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver proved to be great with his Oscar nomination for BlacKkKlansman.  Also I discovered Noah Baumbach last year with his film While We're Young which I think is very underrated.  He's had a few Oscar nominations and is just a great screenwriter and director.  Before Marriage Story my favorite of his was the slice of life Frances Ha.  This film affected me on so many levels emotionally.  I don't know how one could possibly watch this without shedding at least one tear.  It's so incredibly real and it's just amazing how it all played out.  Scarlett Johansson has her best performance once again.  I feel like every time she's in a film she just gets better and better.  The hardest part about this film is that it shows both sides and you can switch back and forth between who you like more and who you like less.  But also you don't want them to split up.  Noah Baumbach did great with this because it's a frustrating film.  It engages you into the characters and story so much that you start to feel so much anger and frustration and happiness and comedy.  The tone has literally everything and blends it great.  Back to the comedy, this film has some pretty funny moments that helped with the depressing tone.  Marriage Story just made me depressed, especially the very end, and it still lingered after I watched it.  The very end just crushed me but it was also the best scene in the whole film.  Just everything blends so nicely in this.  Randy Newman's score is one of my favorites of the year.  It's so joyful and sad at the same time.  Listening to it before seeing the film I was confused how it would work with the story, because there are times where it sounded just so animated.  It just worked perfectly.  I also liked the aspect ratio choice of 1.66:1 because it felt more like a home movie.  To me 1.33:1 and 1.66:1 work nice for a home movie feel.  Everything was just so realistic in this and I didn't want it to end.  This has become my fourth favorite film of the year so far.  Also it's one of those films where I don't want to rewatch it too much so it surprises me every time with how great it is.  I do that with my favorite films.  Marriage Story is a film that should be recognized as one of the best of the decade.  It demonstrates peak storytelling, superb acting, and shows that Noah Baumbach is one of the best directors out there.  I really think it would be cool if it won best picture, screenplay, and acting.  There are so many words I have for this and I want to talk about it for a while.  I think I'll leave it like this so you can experience it for yourself.  Marriage Story is another perfect movie of the year.

My Grade: A+

Don't get sucked in by the bogus reviews (remember the lies about "Bird Box" and the fact that only 18% of all viewers could even finish "The Irishman"?!).  This movie is intolerably implausible and depressing.  Netflix has again spent a fortune trying to put lipstick and a high heels on a pig.

(Which, by the way, was met with a hug from her?) It felt bizarrely superficial and at times boring. Big waste of time.

What a masterpiece.  This movie is so raw and so emotional.  In the beginning it feels as though the story will be told in two halves split between Nicole and Charlie.  The emotional discomfort and tension that rises between the pair seems to build and deflate and rise even higher becoming that much more realistic in terms of divorce between two parents.  The story seems to bounce comfortably back and forth between perspectives and shift between heavy and light-hearted.  This was a beautifully constructed film, bravo to everyone involved.

Marriage Story is up for a lot of the critical awards (golden globes and such) and the performances are well done (I really liked Alan Alda in a small role that I hope gets him at least an Oscar nomination. The movie takes a look at the divorce of its two main characters. Is it is drama verging on melodrama with some great scenes (most of which involve lawyers) and some stuff that feels a bit bloated (both songs at the endish points of the movie for example). Having the characters be a Hollywood actress and a New York based director of "high art" plays had me roiling my eyes pretty hard for the first 40 minutes of the film, but it overcomes it by landing the ending. (3 out of 5 stars for me...if you hate melodrama then avoid at all costs...if you love it this is one of the best to come along in a while (4-5 stars depending on how much you want to hear Kylo Ren sing the work of Sondheim)

Noah Baumbach's indie divorce drama Marriage Story (2019) is a heartfelt retrospective on his failed marriage to Jennifer Jason Leigh. As awful as the divorce proceedings get, Marriage Story succeeds in entertaining and resonating as it's not a vitriolic or hateful movie. Baumbach's writing is reflective and fair to my perspective. He establishes how genuine and loving their relationship started with touching letters of positive aspects, then delves into what made with marriage fizzle out, and finally assigns blame to both parties. Noah Baumbach's Marriage Story is a resounding triumph of goodwill and heartbreak through an empathetic lens. He understands the pain and perspective of each of his leads making for realistic and honest writing. Noah has crafted a fine art film about marriage, divorce, and love in one of 2019's best movies: Marriage Story.

Scarlett Johansson is poignant as Nicole Barber, who felt held back and unappreciated in her marriage. Johansson gives her leading lady a striking voice of adoring wife, decent mother, talented actress, fun partner, vindictive divorcee, and resentful spouse. It's a complicated role that ensures you empathize with her disconnected experience and sympathize with her hurt pride and concerned persona. I appreciate her hurt eyes and nuanced faces. She says so much with subtle changes in expression and tearful monologues. She is intimate in this role like I have not seen Scarlett since Sofia Coppola's Lost in Translation. Considering Scarlett's best acting is in Lost in Translation, Her, and now Marriage Story, she should continue to delve into the emotionally devastating world of divorce. At least, I hope Scarlett Johansson acts in more serious dramas like Marriage Story!

Adam Driver delivers a masterful dramatic leading man role in Marriage Story as Charlie Barber. He is fascinating as a doting father, dedicated director, passionate artist, fun guy, and neglectful husband. Driver's finest acting is here in Marriage Story. I loved him in Silence and BlacKKKlansman, but Marriage Story is nuanced like few actors could ever hope to achieve. His shocked expressions are very understated. The way he puts his hand to his mouth to cover up his pain or his sudden outrage at his spouse displeasure is inspired. His quiet depiction of suffering is as riveting as his burst of frustration when he and Scarlett scream at each other in a phenomenally entertaining scene. He sings a sullen song in a depressing scene, but his refined performance equals Scarlett's all encompassing role. Adam Driver is a character actor with range as exemplified in Marriage Story with good humor, kind affection, gentle manner, dejected anguish, indignant disgust, rage filled fury, and defeated nonchalance. He displays Charlie's heart openly for all the world to feel.

I adore Laura Dern's viper divorce lawyer Nora Fanshaw going for everything. Dern demonstrates a phenomenal irreverence for the pain of others as a cold hearted woman beaten down by divorce herself, gunning for every last cent on behalf of her client. Dern is delightful to watch as she destroys a man's life with a determined glee. Her ruthless attitude would work for a mafia boss as well as it does in Marriage Story as an L.A. divorce lawyer.
Likewise, Ray Liotta brings cunning and sharpness to his brutally honest divorce lawyer Jay Marotta. He is the ideal verbal and legal duellist for Laura Dern. Their courtroom banter is like watching fire spit upon fire in hellish combat. It's one of Marriage Story's best sequences. I love Ray Liotta in Marriage Story as you are on edge in eager anticipation of his next argument.

On the other hand, Alan Alda gives a funny supporting role as a fatalist divorce lawyer already counting Charlie out named Bert Spitz. His dry wit is amusing, but his hopeless attitude is the saddest aspect to his intriguing character. Wallace Shawn even has a funny cameo in Marriage Story as the inappropriate veteran actor. I liked Azhy Robertson's performance as the young boy Henry Barber, who goes from indecisive to spoiled and back to affectionate all within a single scene. Julie Hagerty is hilarious as Scarlett's valley girl mom Sandra. I dearly enjoyed Merritt Wever's cameo as Scarlett's sister Cassie. Her anxious dread at having to serve Charlie is too relatable and hilarious.

Alongside Baumbach's empathetic lens as writer, his direction for Marriage Story is fantastic. He captivates you by telling each side of the story openly and in intimate spaces. Noah Baumbach's indie direction is simple and sleek so as to allow his cast to perform as if on a stage. His open and free style is earnest with stark images of hatred, loathing, disappointment, shock, betrayal, and affection alike. Noah Baumbach's indie direction feels more like you are watching a documentary of this divorce rather than a film. Marriage Story is akin to awkwardly sitting in a room with divorce proceedings occurring.

Jennifer Lame's editing is very pretty and smooth as she seamlessly shifts scenes from Charlie to Nicole with effortless cuts that keep you engaged. Marriage Story is nearly two and a half hours, yet it only feels like one due to Lame's gentle hand.

All of cinematographer Robbie Ryan's close-up shots of hurt faces and crying eyes made my own eyes cry tears. Marriage Story is deeply affecting and wholly engrossing as you absorb all the adoration and resentment of these characters. Many medium shots reveal all the awkward body language and unspoken feelings in impressively executed long takes. Baumbach and Ryan fasten your focus purely on the emotional distress caused in each scene with unwavering camerawork.

Randy Newman's score is beautiful with soft strings and melancholic classical to underline the sorrowful tone of Marriage Story. His music is nice to hear and never oversteps his boundaries to distract from the story, performances, or direction. Newman composes subtle melodies that chime in only when necessary like a warm blanket appearing when you need it.

Finally, I'm sure Marriage Story will prevail at The Oscars, deservedly so, for its powerful performances, personal writing, and grounded direction. Noah Baumbach opens his heart to ensure that Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver can depict complex, flawed characters that feel like real people. Marriage Story is sure to become a classic piece of Americana.

The pacing is slow, the characters are boring, and the entire script plays like an ego-stroking Hollywood awards show of self-importance. I didn't see the characters. I saw the actors trying to PLAY the characters...and playing them with such disingenuous intensity that I could picture them picturing themselves receiving an Emmy. In every scene, I only saw Scarlett Johansson, Adam Driver, and Laura Dern, not Nicole, Charlie, and Nora. This movie was boring and self-serving. It might have translated better as a stage play. If you want to see a poignant film about marital cracks, and the festering subtleties that lead to divorce, skip this bland snoozefest and go see the Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams film Blue Valentine from 2010 instead. That beautifully sad film nails it.

The strongest story of marriage. The most accurate portrayal of how married couple deals with each other's own opinions and how differences and arguments may lead them to unexpected yet unpredictable relationship ending.

The film showed me how irrelevant our concept of fairness is when it comes to marriage conflict. It makes it crystal clear that it's beyond the game of right or wrong.

Marriage is probably the most beautiful invention of human kind, but the most vulnerable at the same time.

History of a Marriage: nice movie with a very disappointed end... Once again Hollywood is scared to believe to take on serious love... My rate would be 10, but with this end is only 7. Perfectly acting from Adam and Scarlett.

Was a fantastic example of great acting and slice of life movie. Nothing much happens and it is slow, but not boring. Held my interest the entire time. Very interesting snapshot into situation everyone can relate to. Movies like this are rare and that is unfortunate.

Noah Baumbach's "Marriage Story" is a witty, tender and heartbreaking divorce drama that is propelled by a pair of powerful performances from Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson. With his latest feature, writer/director Noah Baumbach has crafted a powerful portrait of a couple going through a painstaking divorce. In spite of the serious subject matter, the film is by turns funny and heartbreaking. Baumbach's screenplay is excellent and captures the process of divorce in a piercingly honest and authentic way. Filled with compelling characters, witty dialogue and realistic situations, the script elevates the movie to another level. Aside from excelling behind the camera, Baumbach draws excellent performances from his cast. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are incredible in the lead roles, creating a fractured relationship that is utterly believable. Driver delivers his finest performance to date as Charlie. Intense, charismatic and emotionally resonant, he proves that he is one of the finest actors working today. Johansson, on the other hand, is award-worthy in one of her first dramatic roles. With emotional expressions, she captures the frustrations of a women that is dissatisfied with her relationship. Both actors carry the film firmly on their shoulders. Although "Marriage Story" offers heartwarming entertainment, ultimately it is not a film without flaws. If I had a minor issue with the movie, it would be the lengthy running-time. At over two hours, it is slightly long and could have been tighter in length. Nevertheless, fans of dramas will definitely enjoy "Marriage Story" and so will anyone that has ever gone through a divorce. It offers a heartfelt portrayal of a divorce that is sure to be remembered come awards season.
if you want to cry as a baby whatch it!

What great performances but not just the leads but almost everybody in this movie. Adam Driver delivered the best performance I've seen all year, while Laura Dern deserves praise for a role that you can't take your eyes off of. The film gets some comedic lift with the NY vs. LA rivalry...there is just so much space in LA. I'll be turning back to this film for years to come to put into perspective, life and love. A definite must-watch.

Some people actually divorce due to unsolvable problems of a greater magnitude. This movie is slow, boring and a huge waste of 2 hours of my Friday night. Please get Scar Jo another film role immediately so she can recover from this sad mess.  Adam Driver's "Let me show you my singing voice because I went to Julliard in real life" performance was Meh. As in very, very average. WHy was that in there? Just to show the difference between NY theatre people (they get up and sing in restaurants) and film people in LA? They say that in divorce only the lawyers win, and even with the performances in this dull little film, that is accurate. P.S. Rotten Tomatoes just asked HOW I bought my ticket and indicated my review might not be considered real if I didn't BUY a ticket to this movie. NETFLIX!  I watched it on NETFLIX, with my subscription. They need to add that as an option. It was December 13, and I watched it on NETFLIX. Thank you, Rotten Tomatoes! If this review is not published I will contact you personally to complain. If you're an actor, or someone who wants to be an actor but doesn't know where to start, watch MARRIAGE STORY. Noah Baumbach's feature is a two-hour long masterclass that dazzles with the performances of Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver. Both leads excel at their craft no matter if they share the same scenes or if they're isolated from one another; their chemistry could not be better, I think. What really assists in their performances is a well written screenplay (perhaps the best one of 2019). Baumbach's personal touch in the writing is present throughout, and the leads honour it very well. On a slight note, some people expecting a tear jerker may get exactly what they're looking for; others may not. I was personally more moved by the sheer acting and delivery rather than the arcs themselves. With its final scene, MARRIAGE STORY does well in showing that although going through a divorce can be a rather nasty business, people can still put aside the past and learn to live in a bittersweet harmony. See you at the movies.
brilliant, all these feelings presented very well. The love for there son, it's what keep them fighting.

Anchored by Noah Baumbach's keen empathy and at the peak of his writting abilities, Marriage Story delves deep into the beautiful - and sometimes hard - relationship crafted by the outstanding performances from the leads Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver.

Noah Baumbach outperforming his previous works once again. I can't lie  - alluding to the show - I watched this for the director and not the cast (although I bet many would for the reverse). The setting right from the get go, leading you to think this was a happy loving beginning is immediately turned on its head, which I am not sure was hinted in the trailers(didn't regret this decision). The cinematography - from the panning scenes to the scene angles (notably at the start and especially conversations) were executed sublimely. And the raw dialogue- that classic Baumbach brilliance, shines through; leaving me in awe of its realism and constant self reminder how every scene was set with an intention/message. 

I must give Johannson her due credit- the stunning raw scenes(her therapist session and heavy-handed interactions with Adam) would not have been possible without her superb craft, proving to younger audiences she is much more than just a one dimensional hot black widow. 

Adam who stuck with Noah through his best works: Meyerowitz Stories & While We're Young, albeit as supporting casts is finally given a lead role and does not disappoint. His reticence synergises well with his role, creating fair contrast to Johannson's role which lends realism with its semblance to archetypes of modern day relationships.

As a young evergreen man, the depth of development we follow the 2 characters through their emotional journey sheds much needed perspectives into the faintly covered theme of divorce.

It's too long, by about 30 minutes and the scumbag lawyers including Dern, are caricatures, the stuff that makes lawyer jokes funny.  I kept almost bailing on it for the first hour, but there was JUST enough to keep me watching.  I was rewarded by one scene where I think Driver might get an Oscar, it was BRILLIANT!   It was a pretty good movie that I'm sorry I watched.  It wasn't a waste of time, it just makes you feel kind of shitty.  If that's your goal, enjoy!

Laura Dern is very memorable and fun in Marriage Story whereas Adam Driver is reliably fantastic and Scarlett Johansson herself has never been better than she is here. The film also has terrific dialogue, a meticulous depiction of divorce in legal terms and it's quite emotionally exhilarating. The argument scene is amazing in its entirety. Unfortunately, the whole film isn't as great with the first act being rather annoying in its extensive narration, and the acting scenes are thoroughly unnecessary. Thus, it's a very good movie, but I expected much greater things from it, resulting in the biggest letdown of the year for me personally.

Il film è visivamente stabile e sicuro, senza prendere nessun rischio stilistico offre un'esperienza sobria e curata. Il palese punto di forza è una sceneggiatura semplicemente incredibile, sorretta dalle migliori interpretazioni dell'anno, dove realismo e concretezza fanno da protagonisti. La struggente fine di una relazione matrimoniale viene narrata con sentimento e sfocia in una drammatica evoluzione che porta lo spettatore a riflettere sul concetto di amore in generale. Da sottolineare ancora una volta le intepretazioni dei due protagonisti, il miglior lavoro svolto da entrambi in tutta la loro carriera.

This is what character piece films should aspire to be. I came out of this movie thinking it was perfect and watched it again immediately after and once again, I believe it to be a perfect film. This is by far my favorite movie of 2019.

Something of a modern-day Kramer vs. Kramer, but with all the personality and identity required to make it it's own thing, Marriage Story's power and poignancy rests largely on the acting talents of its 2 leads, who give arguably their best screen performances to date. Both are fraught and frequently on edge, but they both do a lot to convince you that the separating couple once had immense love and respect for one another, especially with the opening sequences which is brought back beautifully towards the end. It tells the story from both sides, and shows just how ugly a divorce can become, especially when a child is caught in the middle and doesn't fully understand what is happening. It also addresses the problems that both men and women, especially the former, face in obtaining custody, and the struggle a parent will go through for that right. Its informed by reality and keenly observes the mundane moments of court battles with wit and humour and the more contentious moments with sympathy and understanding. Noah Baumbach is a forced to be reckoned with in the movie world, with this and The Meyerowitz Stories demonstrating his prowess both behind the camera and the typewriter. Marriage Story shows how a separation can be both devastating and revelatory, how it can tear 2 people apart, but allow you to see things in the other person that you didn't before. It's mostly a showcase for its 2 actors, but everything it brings to the table make it a film worth seeing.

Until the Golden Globe nominations were announced I hadn’t even heard of Marriage Story. But, there it was: Best Actor Drama, Best Actress Drama, Best Supporting Actress, Best Drama, Best Screenplay and Best Original Score. Good grief! I haven’t exactly been hiding under a rock when it comes to movies! Fully chagrined I clicked on Netflix and settled in, fully expecting to be overwhelmingly impressed. I wasn’t but that’s not an indictment by any means. The film was really good just not over the top Bravo! The storyline is actually quite common, one many of us have lived: marriage adrift, divorce, child custody, division of property….“let’s keep this fair and civil, do what’s best for the kids.” If we’re lucky, amicable works. If not, our lives grind to a brutal, angry halt while attorneys screw everything up and money rolls downhill so their kids can relax about college tuition while our kids start applying for financial aid. Watching Marriage Story is like sitting through 136 minutes of bad lawyer jokes springing to life. The horror. Charlie (Adam Driver), a director of cutting-edge, avant-garde theater, positioned to take his latest work to Broadway, is married to Nicole (Scarlett Johansson), an actress fading from NYC stage renown but still popular in Hollywood. The couple have grown apart, recognizing, despite deeply caring for each other, the point of departure has arrived. Divorce is discussed. Their young son Henry (Azhy Robertson) is the beloved prize and both parents start out determined his interests be top priority. Then a wrinkle emerges. Nicole accepts a career revival offer to film a pilot in Los Angeles. She takes Henry with her to California, moving in with her Charlie-adoring mom (Julie Hagerty). On one of Charlie’s frequent coast-to-coast trips to spend time with his family, Nicole bullies her reluctant Charlie-adoring sister Cassie (Merritt Wever) to serve him with divorce papers, smuggled under a pecan pie, then hires Nora Fanshaw (Larua Dern) as her attorney, a bulldog lawyer who approaches divorce in a “there will be blood” crusade. Nora relishes in threatening Charlie with loss of all earthly possessions and any hint of custody. Charlie is forced to retaliate. Enter divorce Death Star Jay Marotta (Ray Liotta). At this point we strap in for a gut-wrenching saga of two legal vipers squaring off to pound the other side to pulp, not caring a whit that “sides” are flesh and blood people, parents at a starting line of good intentions. Charlie and Nicole recoil, shatterIng under scathing legal posturing and purposeful courtroom annihilation. Even Henry is a won/lost tally at times, the wretched center flag of a parental tug-of-war, Charlie pulling one arm, Nicole the other. Everyone is expendable as collateral damage, Charlie literally bleeding out on his rented California apartment floor in one grueling black humor kitchen scene. Lord, have mercy. What materializes below the waves of the legal hurricane are two decent people, Charlie and Nicole, trying—mostly futilely—but trying nevertheless to resist succumbing to emotional cruelty. Predictably, tirades of fury and fear simmer, seethe and eventually explode. Human combustion. As the vitriol flies, you regret on their behalf what they’re unleashing— hateful, damning words that can never be taken back, that will echo forever no matter how hard they may wish differently. We’ve all been there. The film taps our jagged relational regrets, remorse and repentance, making “I’m sorry,” a communal mantra of misery. You want to jump up and shout at the screen, “Stop! Don’t say it! Just stop, please.” Adam Driver is not a favorite of mine, he’s so Keanu Reeves with a distinctive monotone delivery, but he did stretch his dramatic persona for this role, perhaps his best performance to date. Petty question #1: how did 6’2” Driver gets cast with 5’3” Scarlett Johansson? He towered over her. Maybe it was to serve as a visual metaphor for their professional director/actress relationship. Truthfully, Johansson failed to win me over, I never warmed up to Nicole. I was rooting for Charlie, put off by Nicole and annoyed by Henry. Petty question #2: isn’t Henry way too big for a car seat? Cassie, Nicole’s witty sister, was my favorite of all the characters. For the record I am a total Merritt Wever groupie, my enthusiasm for her in Nurse Jackie morphed to sheer hero worship in Netflix’s Godless, the last scene I can watch over and over and over until I’m the last person awake in the household. There were enough funny exchanges in this film, comedy infusion, that thankfully lightened the heavy laden angst. While the attorneys square off, family members rise and fall in their humanness. It’s like taking a selfie of our worst selves against a background of laughter, kindness, and thoughtfulness. If the goal is to showcase the competing dualism of the human spirit then Marriage Story charges ahead of the 2019 drama pack. It didn’t win my vote but maybe because it hit too close to home, taking me on a walk down memory lane of my own awful, demolition derby divorce, fomented by two condescending attorneys who pitted us against each other in a hostile custody battle over our two young sons. 35 years later I still hate the shameful things I said or did. Marriage Story’s “Join the crowd” is small comfort. I’ll leave it at that. The 77th Golden Globe Awards will be held aired live January 5, 2020 by NBC, 8 EST/5 PST.

A very moving and uplifting story from a master of the genre.

I wonder if the people who disliked the movie have ever been through a divorce. This movie, while portraying wealthy people, was about people who have hearts. These hearts were clearly being broken through this process. Things kept escalating, and it was clear that no one was getting exactly what they wanted out of the situation. This is so true of real life divorce. No one really wins. Life goes on. Things change. It's heartbreaking to see any child go through this, but it happens every day in a country full of lawyers that will be as ruthless as possible to get what their client "wants". A courtroom battle of lawyers talking for their clients, instead of the clients talking to each other. It shows that communication- real, honest communication is the key to any relationship succeeding. The actors were all top notch, most notably Driver, who gives the performance of the year, and maybe this decade. The emotions so raw and real, that you can see the love and hate the estranged coupled have for each other. This is a must see for anyone, and a cautionary tale for anyone contemplating marriage or divorce.

Marriage Story (4 out of 5 stars). Marriage Story is a drama film that shows the hardship and struggles of a married couple who are distant. And going through a divorce. Following with the split parenting and living in different states. Dealing with Lawyer actions and custody battles. It is a realistic drama that shows the impact emotionally and mentally how it affects both parents. The plot follows Charlie (Adam Driver) and Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) a distant married couple. Charlie is focused in his theatre directing career. While Nicole is an actress who made it to the tv shows. Which she moves to Los Angeles while Charlie is in New York. Nicole wants a divorce. Which shocked Charlie. Nicole plans to have the lawyers do all the work with the custody battles with their child. Which Charlie does not want to be away from his child. Marriage Story is a great and raw drama about marriage and the nasty actions of going through a divorce. The impact it has on each individual and their child. Nicole is content on the divorce and lets her attorney do all the work. While Charlie is trying to focus on his career in New York and flying to LA to be part of his sons life. The performances by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are great with their characters. There are some powerful dramatic moments which can be emotional. It is realistic and raw. The script is moving and the direction is powerful. I did feel like the music score was a little dull. Overall, it was a good powerful drama that is worth checking out.
saw this at the local Indie joint, when it had to play in theaters to be eligible for Oscars. 100% watchable from start to finish. HIGHLY Recommend this film for grownups.

MARRIAGE STORY-2019(R)-Nov. 29. By:Clem The Movie Guy. Thanksgiving weekend, I got a chance to see an exclusive screening of Marriage Story, the new film from acclaimed writer & director Noah Baumbach. Loosely inspired by Baumbach’s own personal experience & further informed by conversations with friends & lawyers, Marriage Story is an intensely compelling & a realistic look at a married couple going through the turmoil of divorce. Once madly in love with each other, Charlie (Adam Driver), a gifted New York theatre director & Nicole (Scarlett Johansson), a former teen Hollywood film actress who now only performs in his off-Broadway plays, are having trouble with their marriage. Charlie is intensely & somewhat selfishly focused on his work. Nicole has grown tired of living in the shadow of Charlie’s aspirations as Charlie grows increasingly obvious to Nicole’s hopes & dreams. After receiving the offer of a starring role in a television pilot & with the divorce in early stages, Nicole leaves the theatre company & moves to Los Angeles with their young son, Henry (Azhy Robertson) while Charlie remains in New York to see to the process of his play going to Broadway. Later, arriving for a visit in Los Angeles to see Nicole & Henry, Charlie is stunned when he is served with divorce papers, believing that he & Nicole had agreed on an amicably split & to forego using lawyers. Nicole has been persuaded to hire a powerful attorney, Nora Fanshaw (Laura Dern), which inevitably forces Charlie to follow suit. Initially he hires Bert Spitz (Alan Alda), a retired family lawyer who favors a more civil & conciliatory approach but as the contention grows, Charlie must resort to a more aggressive lawyer, Jay Marotta (Ray Liotta). Marriage Story shows not only the difficulties of compromise & self-sacrifice in marriage, further complicated by trying to protect any children involved, but the legal system at its worst with ruthless lawyers manipulating their vulnerable clients. The performances from Adam Driver & Scarlett Johansson were raw & captivating. I believe that Adam Driver gives one of the best performances of his career. I won’t be surprised to see Marriage Story receiving major award consideration for Best Picture, Noah Baumbach for Best Director & Best Screenplay, Adam Driver for Best Actor, & Scarlett Johansson for Best Actress. Marriage Story is a MUST-SEE FILM that is now streaming on Netflix. It will be high on my list of Best Films of 2019.

Full of heart and soul. Marriage Story delivers a powerful message about love and hardship with a moving and arguably career best performance by both Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansen. Noah Baumbach portrays perfectly that there can be beauty in hardship.

Marriage Story is a beautifully written and perfectly acted piece of cinema. The film does a great job of pulling at your emotions, making you laugh when you should, and cry when you least expect. It's raw, it's powerful, and it's a must see!

Simultaneously heartbreaking and heartwarming, Noah Baumbach's latest film 'Marriage Story' is a breathtaking work of art. Something that should hung up in an art gallery and admired.
The movie is a compassionate yet incisive look at a family growing apart as well as staying together, told through the divorce of Charlie and Nicole Barber and their son Henry.

The acting is out of this world. I love Joaquin Phoenix's performance in 'Joker' but Adam Driver has now dethroned him. The emotional range he has is incredible. Scarlett Johansson gives her all. She sells the pain and suffering she is going through.
The argument scene is jaw-dropping fantastic. The two viciously fighting with their words made me freeze in my chair out of terror and awe. If the two either don't get an Oscar nod or win in their respective categories, I'm gonna riot. The supporting cast is also great. Laura Dern, Alan Alda and Ray Liotta deliever excellent performances as the Barber's lawyers. Azhy Robertson as Charlie and Nicole's son Henry is tremendous.

The writing is amazing. Feeling realistic and grounded, it's undramatic approach to the subject matter of divorce felt refreshing. The dialogue spoken between characters was at times wickedly funny and other times devastating. 
The movie also never took sides. It was never biased or one-sided. Both Charlie and Nicole had pros and cons that counteracted each other, leading to a nice, neutral middle ground.

The cinematography made the movie feel alive. It brought you into this world, and besides the writing and acting, kept you engaged. There wasn't a single frame where I looked away.

Emotional and raw, 'Marriage Story' is a masterpiece in every sense of the word as well as the best film of 2019.
Considering how sad and depressing this movie is there are some huge laughs throughout. A dark comedy about divorce!?

I think it is a great movie, the screenplay is very good, I feel the emotions of the characters. It has problems with the edition, but in general, I love the movie, the Scarlett's performance is amazing, all her gestures and movements. It was awesome!

The supporting cast for this film is also really good, Laura Dern and Ray Liotta was a combination I never knew I wanted but that one scene shared together was comedy gold. Noah Baumbach's latest film is about the crumbling of a marriage and the pains of divorce. I was completely blown away by the film. First, it portrays equally both sides of the divorce, which you don't see too often; both husband and wife are treated sympathetically with all of their strengths and faults. It also digs into its messiness and how all of the things that didn't work in the marriage come to the surface in unexpected ways. The screenplay is amazing. Adam Driver (Charlie) and Scarlett Johansson (Nicole) give the very best performances of their careers and probably the best portrayals ever of divorce. Every scene they are in is powerful. There is one scene during which the two of them get into an argument that is of such intense emotional power that one wonders from where they channel that kind of energy and rage. Laura Dern is exceptional as Nicole's compassionate yet self-interested lawyer; my prediction is that she will walk away with the Best Actress Awards for this performance. Driver and Johansson deserve all of the acclaim they are getting for the film. The film gets a huge thumbs up from me and is among my favorites of the year. I don't think the combination of great acting and razor-sharp screenplay can get much better than this.
Absolutely mesmerizing and Scar-Jo deserves and an oscar for her performance!
An excellent and sincere exploration of a dissolving marriage that favors empathy rather than sides.

Raw, honest and sweet. A compelling story about the difficult end of a marriage. Well-written and excellent acting from leads Driver and Johansson. Laura Dern, Ray Liotta and Alan Alda are a trio of lawyers who bring an effective mix of comedy and drama as they handle the divorce. The scenes with Johansson’s family are too funny. Driver singing Being Alive was a moment! Well done.

The acting alone is worth your time. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson, coupled with a string of solid, second-tier performances courtesy of Laura Dern, Alan Alda, and Ray Liotta, make the film what it is. I found myself a little befuddled after some scenes and thought the writing was weak in some key parts but the film is beautiful, yet tragic in many ways.
Feels like a classic 90's movie driven off pure storytelling, which is only to be outdone by the sensational performances by both leads.
Incredible acting by Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver. This film captures the real distressing nuances of divorce. At the time of this writing, this is my 2nd favorite movie of the year.

"All in all, Noah Baumbach delivers what I believe to be its career-best flick, Marriage Story. With the best screenplay of 2019, as well as one the best directions, this is the closest the world is ever going to get to a realistic depiction of a divorce. Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver also give the best performances of their lives, elevating every single scene, dialogue, argument, or joke. The long takes allow them to shine and actually work as actors, moving around the set and doing domestic/job tasks, while delivering their lines. Technically, both Baumbach and the entire cast are absolutely perfect. It's an extremely emotional narrative, very depressing, sad, and even uncomfortable at times, which might scare some people off, especially if they've been through this. Despite its replay value being affected (a rewatch is very unlikely), it's a phenomenal lesson in storytelling that stays with us long after it's finished. Easily, one of the best movies of 2019. Don't miss it, and try not to cry."

Marriage Story is a near faultless piece of cinema. If you grade films on their writing and acting and directing alone then this film succeeds in all of those areas without any doubt. The latest film by Noah Baumbach continues his rich tradition of pinpoint accuracy in the stakes of the human heart. He has an innate ability to write dialogue that is honesty writ large. And thankfully he employs incredibly talented actors to deliver his words. This film is probably his most serious and heavy to date. There are moments of light humour but this a piece of passion that wears its heart on its sleeve. It's the story of Charlie and Nicole and their son Henry. They work successfully in the New York theatre scene and seemingly have a happy marriage. But the marriage is at breaking point after years of quite disintegration and disinterest. When Nicole flies back home to Los Angeles and files for divorce the film sets in motion the protracted dissolve of their love. We see the minutiae of divorce proceedings in excruciating detail. Adam Driver and Scarlet Johansson have never been better with Driver in particular staking a claim for the finest actor of his generation. Driver is incredidbly adept at delivering emotions on a grandiose scale. The supporting cast is outstanding as well, especially Alan Alda who brings a warm humanity to the film. The writing feels so natural through out. Scenes flow, its editing is perfect, with ease and honesty. There are scenes that are heart breaking to watch, but it's all totally worth it for the emotional pay off. Aided by a subtle score by the great Randy Newman, this film rocked me hard.

On screen, this is as real as you can get when making a movie about a divorce. Each tear shed was the chillingly truth. It's those little moments that no one really gets to see that director Baumbach accomplished to zoom in on. 

The impeccable lead performers Scarlet Johansson and Adam Driver reel you in on everyday, real emotions throughout the divorce process. The story is told with just the right amount of grief so, as a viewer I ended taking sides sides with both the wife Nicole (Johansson), and husband Charlie (Driver). No happy hollywood ending here, just the truth. 

And the resolution is always there, just glad they didn't make a story of the ending... they kept it real. Except for her tying his shoe at the end... meh. 

I highly recommend... even for the less sensitive folks out there.

I've been trying to come up with a way of reviewing this film in a way that doesn't seem like I personally directed it or something, because movies like Marriage Story don't come along very often and I just feel like gushing about how incredible is. Netflix has been releasing tons of quality content this year and this may very well be the best of their entire catalogue of feature films. Alone with Roma and their recent release of The Irishman, I believe you'll be seeing Marriage Story in contention for many, many awards in the coming months. Here's why I believe Marriage Story is a must-watch. 

Not all relationships work out and if every single Romance film ever made had a happy ending, then that would just be a lie. It's nice to see a movie tackle this subject matter and stick with it from start to finish. Marriage Story is a look into the lives of Charlie (Adam Driver) and Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) as they are clearly not able to keep a working marriage, but also don't want to ruin the family they have made. From gut-wrenching scenes of excessively honest dialogue and a conclusion that feels raw and true, this movie is one of the best dramas I've seen in years. 

Take your pick at who outshines who here, because it really is a toss-up as to who is more incredible between Driver and Johansson. It does help that writer/director Noah Baumbach gave them outstandingly good dialogue to work with, but the way these two play off each other is as if they were given a year to prepare for these roles and get to know each other. Everything about this film felt authentic, which made the overall impact so powerful. It's not easy to watch a movie about a love story that's about how marriage sometimes doesn't work out, but this movie does it in such a way that it doesn't feel depressing throughout the majority of the duration. This is all thanks to Noah Baumbach though. 

From Greenberg to While We're Young, Baumbach has been a director I've been keeping my eyes on, as I believe he has gotten better with each of his films, for the most part. It wasn't until The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected) that I really started to anticipate his next movie, but now I'll be desperately awaiting to get another story from him. His talent as a director, especially on Marriage Story, is truly something else. He is best suited for movies like Marriage Story or While We're Young, where it's all about the characters because he very clearly has a knack at getting the best possible performances out of his cast. 

Marriage Story begins strong, easing you into what will be a very emotional film and concludes in a way that feels natural. Overall, from these award-worthy performances, superb writing and directing, a very minimal score, which lets you sit with these characters for extended periods of time, it's very hard to nitpick this movie. There is one scene that made me chuckle, purely because I felt uncomfortable, but this movie is otherwise perfectly done. By the time 2019 ends, I feel that I may have to say this is the best movie of the year. I absolutely loved every minute of this movie. I can't recommend it enough.

"Marriage Story" is a startling drama that manages to very delicately portray the life of a couple going through a divorce. Adam Driver (Charlie) and Scarlett Johansson (Nicole) deliver extremely forceful performances that seem to be on point with the characters they are representing. Yet, the movie surprisingly doesn't exert many feelings, making the audience "stay neutral" through the film.

A top-five movie from 2019 in my opinion. Johansson and Driver give phenomenal performances and Baumbach nails it as both a writer and director. This is a painful movie that captures the awfulness of divorce in a captivating way. Tremendous filmmaking. [****½]

Marriage Story is the best movie of 2019 and a contender to best movie of the decade. This is a flawless movie, beautiful writing, amazing casting and performances, and a great direction by Noah Baumbach. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson make the performances of their career with this movie. A must watch to anyone that loves movies or getting their heart broken.

Wow, what a phenomenal film this is, written and directed by Noah Baumbach, easily one of the years best, starring Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver. The story follows a married couple going through a rather messy divorce, and I applaud Baumbach for providing such an authentic look at what happens during a divorce – showing how critical the legal process can be. Possibly my favorite aspect of this film is that you cant really side with one character or the other. Both parties do and say things they normally wouldnt, all for the benefit of their child. This film is so wonderfully shot the long takes and zooms during scenes of straight dialogue from Johansson and Driver are definitely some of my favorite moments in any film this year.

This is some of Scarlett Johanssons best work, and may even be her finest role behind Lost in Translation – and if it isnt, its definitely the close runner-up. But my god, Adam Driver absolutely gives his best performance in this role, and I am not exaggerating when I say this just may be the best lead performance of the year. Powerful and heartbreaking, everything he brings to the table here. Having Johansson and an incredible supporting cast to work with, they all bring out something from Driver, this career-defining performance. Marriage Story is on Netflix right now, PLEASE sit down with it and check it out. And have the tissues ready, because one or two scenes in particular will crush you.
